POSIX for Nausicaa

Next: overview, Up: (dir)

POSIX for Nausicaa

This document describes version 0.1a3 of Nausicaa/POSIX, a distribution of libraries for R6RS Scheme exposing the POSIX interface to the Scheme language level; some GNU C Library and Linux–specific extensions are also exposed. This package is built on top of the Nausicaa/Scheme package, making use of its foreign–functions interface; at present, it supports only GNU+Linux systems and the Ikarus, Mosh and Ypsilon Scheme implementations.

The package is distributed under the terms of the GNU General Public License (GPL) and can be downloaded from:

http://github.com/marcomaggi/nausicaa/downloads

the project home page of Nausicaa is at:

http://marcomaggi.github.com/nausicaa.html

development of Nausicaa takes place at:

http://github.com/marcomaggi/nausicaa/tree/master

Copyright © 2008, 2009, 2010 by Marco Maggi marco.maggi-ipsu@poste.it

Permission is granted to copy, distribute and/or modify this document under the terms of the GNU Free Documentation License, Version 1.3 or any later version published by the Free Software Foundation; with Invariant Sections being “GNU Free Documentation License” and “GNU General Public License”, no Front–Cover Texts, and no Back–Cover Texts. A copy of the license is included in the section entitled “GNU Free Documentation License”.
  • overview: Overview.
  • file: File system.
  • fd: File descriptors.
  • sockets: Sockets.
  • streams: Stream functions.
  • time: Date and time.

Next: file, Previous: Top, Up: Top

1 Overview

Nausicaa/POSIX is a distribution of libraries for R6RS Scheme exposing the POSIX interface to the Scheme language level; some GNU C Library extensions and Linux extensions are also exposed.

The libraries are built on top of the Nausicaa/Scheme package, making use of its foreign-functions interface; some libraries depend upon the C language library ‘libnausicaa-posix’, which is built and installed by this package.

  • overview libraries: Libraries organisation.
  • overview interface: Interface organisation.
  • overview typedefs: Type definitions.

Next: overview interface, Up: overview

1.1 Libraries organisation

The distribution attempts to split functions compliant to the POSIX standard from functions available only through extensions; this splitting is meant to make it easier to port the distribution on non–GNU systems.

NOTE As of this version of the project, correct splitting is still an ongoing process (the manual pages on GNU+Linux systems should contain notes about POSIX standard compliance).

Unless otherwise specified, libraries are split in three sets:

(posix --- platform)
(glibc --- platform)
(linux --- platform)
The low–level interface: faster but raw. In this documentation, all the bindings from these libraries are prefixed with ‘platform:’, but they are exported without this prefix.

Some functions are exposed by these libraries but not by the upper level libraries (for example many non–reentrant functions which have a corresponding reentrant counterpart).

(posix --- primitives)
(glibc --- primitives)
(linux --- primitives)
The middle–level interface: does marshaling of arguments and return values, it is built on top of the platform libraries. In this documentation, all the bindings from these libraries are prefixed with ‘primitive:’, but they are exported without this prefix.
(posix ---)
(glibc ---)
(linux ---)
The high–level interface: slower but user friendly, it is built on top of the primitives libraries. We should really import these libraries by prefixing the identifiers; for example: 
          (import (rnrs)
            (prefix (posix fd)   posix:)
            (prefix (glibc file) glibc:))

Additionally, the following libraries are installed:

(posix sizeof)
Exports bindings for constant values (like ‘O_CREAT’) and data structure accessors and mutators.
(posix typedefs)
Defines new Scheme object types to be used as wrappers for system objects (file descriptors, pointers to specific data structures, etc.). This library defines a lot of record types, but it depends only upon the (posix sizeof) library; so it is fine to import it for the expand phase.
(posix extensions)
Defines extensions for the types exported by (posix typedefs), to be used with the (records) library (from the Nausicaa/Scheme package). For this purpose, this library must be imported for the expand phase.

Next: overview typedefs, Previous: overview libraries, Up: overview

1.2 Interface organisation

For all the functions only a brief description is given: We have to use the foreign function's own documentation to have all the details. Unless otherwise specified, the interface adheres to the following pattern for function x:

— Function: x arg ...
— Parameter: x-function
— Function: primitive:x arg ...
— Function: platform:x c-arg ...

This is an interface for the x() foreign function.

x and primitive:x do something with the arguments, which are regular Scheme values. They take the same arguments and return the same return values. If successful they return values representing the result; in case of error they raise an ‘&errno’ condition. C language system errors.

x does the job by applying to the arguments the current value of the x-function parameter, which must be a function; the parameter is initialised to primitive:x.

platform:x is the direct wrapper for the foreign function. It accepts C language level arguments (like C strings), and returns 2 values: the return value from the foreign function call and the value of ‘errno’ right after the call.

Notice that, for almost all the functions, the value of ‘errno’ is meaningful only if the return value from the foreign function call indicates an error; ‘errno’ may be non–zero even if the function call was successful.

For the meaning of the C level arguments we have to read the foreign function's original documentation.

This interface gives us 3 choices:

  1. To call directly the foreign function using the platform:x callout; in this case we are responsible to convert the Scheme arguments to the appropriate C language level values (beware to non–garbage collected values!).
  2. To call the Scheme adapter primitive:x; this gives us: automatic conversion of arguments, exceptions in case of errors, automatic retrying in case the foreign function call is interrupted by an ‘EINTR’ signal (unless otherwise specified).
  3. To call the high–level, parametrised, x interface; this gives us everything primitive:x does and additionally allows us to replace the primitive function with a version that returns controlled values, or raises an error, and/or logs the operation. This feature can be used to test Scheme code execution paths that handle exceptions.

Example of usage of failing primitive fork function: 

     (define (fake-fork)
       (raise-errno-error 'fork EINVAL))
     
     (parametrise ((fork-function fake-fork))
       ---
       (fork)
       ---)

Previous: overview interface, Up: overview

1.3 Type definitions

All the new record types are defined in the library (posix typedefs); all of them are nongenerative definitions. For example: 

     (define-record-type (<fd> integer-><fd> <fd>?)
       (nongenerative nausicaa:posix:<fd>)
       (fields (immutable object <fd>->integer)))

the nongenerative tag is always nausicaa:posix: with the record type name appended.

So, when building a package which may need type definitions usable with Nausicaa/POSIX, we just copy the definition from (posix typedefs) into a new library: 

     (library (my-package typedefs)
       (export <fd> <fd>? integer-><fd> <fd>->integer)
       (import (rnrs)
       (define-record-type (<fd> integer-><fd> <fd>?)
         (nongenerative nausicaa:posix:<fd>)
         (fields (immutable object <fd>->integer)))))

achieving compatibility for the type <fd> without forcing a dependency upon Nausicaa/POSIX for the new package.

The outlined mechanism works as shown in the following example: 
     (library (one)
       (export make-<T>)
       (import (rnrs))
       (define-record-type <T>
         (nongenerative the-t)
         (fields (mutable a))))
     
     (library (two)
       (export <T>-a)
       (import (rnrs))
       (define-record-type <T>
         (nongenerative the-t)
         (fields (mutable a))))
     
     ;;; the program
     (import (rnrs)
       (prefix (one) one:)
       (prefix (two) two:))
     (define o (one:make-<T> 123))
     (display (two:<T>-a o))
     (newline)

the two record type definitions are identical, having also the same nongenerative tag; the program will execute correctly recognising the types as equivalent.

But if we remove one of the nongenerative forms: 

     (library (two)
       (export <T>-a)
       (import (rnrs))
       (define-record-type <T>
         (fields (mutable a))))

the two type definitions are no more equivalent, so running the program will fail with (under Ikarus Scheme): 

     Unhandled exception:
      Condition components:
        1. &assertion
        2. &who: record-accessor
        3. &message: "invalid type"
        4. &irritants: (#[<T> 123] #<record-type-descriptor <T>>)

Next: fd, Previous: overview, Up: Top

2 File system

Unless otherwise specified, the bindings documented in this chapter are exported by the following libraries: 

     (posix file)
     (posix file primitives)
     (posix file platform)
  • file constants: Constant values.
  • file enumerations: Enumeration sets.
  • file working directory: The working directory.
  • file directory access: Accessing directory entries.
  • file links: Hard and symbolic links.
  • file remove: Removing files and directories.
  • file rename: Renaming files and directories.
  • file mkdir: Creating directories.
  • file attr: Changing file attributes.
  • file temp: Temporary files.
  • file times: Setting file times.
  • file stat: Inspecting file attributes.

Next: file enumerations, Up: file

2.1 Constant values

— Constant: F_OK
— Constant: R_OK
— Constant: W_OK
— Constant: X_OK

Constants representing requests for access permission testing with access. These bindings are exported by (posix sizeof).

Next: file working directory, Previous: file constants, Up: file

2.2 Enumeration sets

  • file enumerations access: Access flags.

Up: file enumerations

2.2.1 Access flags

— Enumeration Type: enum-access-flags

Enumeration type used to specify flags for access. It contains the following symbols: 

          existence
          read  write  exec
— Syntax: access-flags <symbol> ...

Expand to an enumeration set of type enum-access-flags holding the given <symbol> symbols.

— Function: access-flags->value set
— Function: value->access-flags integer

Convert to and from enumeration sets of type enum-access-flags and exact integer values being an inclusive OR combination of the following constant values: 

          F_OK
          R_OK  W_OK  X_OK

Next: file directory access, Previous: file enumerations, Up: file

2.3 The working directory

The following functions manage the process' current directory. Working Directory.

— Function: getcwd
— Parameter: getcwd-function
— Function: primitive:getcwd
— Function: platform:getcwd

Return a string representing the current working directory.

— Function: pwd

An alias for getcwd.

— Function: chdir pathname
— Parameter: chdir-function
— Function: primitive:chdir pathname
— Function: platform:chdir pathname

Change the current directory to the selected pathname, which must be a Scheme string or symbol. If an error occurs changing directory, because of access permissions: An exception is raised.

— Function: fchdir fd
— Parameter: fchdir-function
— Function: primitive:fchdir fd
— Function: platform:fchdir fd

Change the current directory to the one associated to the file descriptor fd.

Next: file links, Previous: file working directory, Up: file

2.4 Accessing directory entries

The functions described in this section handle accessing directories. Accessing Directories.

  • file directory access types: Type definitions.
  • file directory access open: Accessing a directory stream.
  • file directory access read: Reading a directory stream.
  • file directory access seek: Random access to a directory stream.
  • file directory access scan: Scanning a directory.
  • file directory access tree: Scanning a hierarchy of directories.

Next: file directory access open, Up: file directory access

2.4.1 Type definitions

The following bindings are exported from the sizeof library. Format of a directory entry.

— Constant: sizeof-dirent
— Constant: alignof-dirent
— Constant: strideof-dirent

Size, structure alignment and array stride of struct dirent types.

— Syntax: struct-dirent-d_ino-set! pointer value
— Syntax: struct-dirent-d_ino-ref pointer
— Syntax: struct-dirent-d_off-set! pointer value
— Syntax: struct-dirent-d_off-ref pointer
— Syntax: struct-dirent-d_reclen-set! pointer value
— Syntax: struct-dirent-d_reclen-ref pointer
— Syntax: struct-dirent-d_type-set! pointer value
— Syntax: struct-dirent-d_type-ref pointer

Accessors and mutators for the fields of the struct dirent type; some fields may not be present on different platforms. See below for the accessor of the d_name field.

— Syntax: struct-dirent-d_name-ref pointer

Accessor for the d_name field of a struct dirent type. Evaluates to a pointer to the first byte of the char d_name[] array.

— Constant: OFFSETOF_STRUCT_DIRENT_D_NAME

Offset in bytes of the d_name field in a struct dirent type.

— Constant: _DIRENT_HAVE_D_NAMELEN
— Constant: _DIRENT_HAVE_D_RECLEN
— Constant: _DIRENT_HAVE_D_OFF
— Constant: _DIRENT_HAVE_D_TYPE

Set to #t by the GNU C Library if the named field is present in the struct dirent type.

— Constant: DT_BLK
— Constant: DT_CHR
— Constant: DT_DIR
— Constant: DT_FIFO
— Constant: DT_LNK
— Constant: DT_REG
— Constant: DT_SOCK
— Constant: DT_UNKNOWN

Values for the d_type field of a struct dirent type. These are specific for the GNU C Library.

Next: file directory access read, Previous: file directory access types, Up: file directory access

2.4.2 Accessing a directory stream

The following functions manage opening and closing of special stream objects used to access directory contents. Opening a directory stream. Reading and closing a directory stream.

— Function: opendir pathname
— Parameter: opendir-function
— Function: primitive:opendir pathname
— Function: platform:opendir pathname-cstr

Open and return a stream associated to the directory selected by the Scheme string or symbol pathname.

— Function: fdopendir fd
— Parameter: fdopendir-function
— Function: primitive:fdopendir fd
— Function: platform:fdopendir fd

Open and return a stream associated to the directory selected by the file descriptor fd.

— Function: closedir stream
— Parameter: closedir-function
— Function: primitive:closedir stream
— Function: platform:closedir stream

Close the directory stream previously opened with opendir or fdopendir.

NOTE Applying this function to a stream that was opened with fdopendir, closes the underlying file descriptor, too. This is weird but I have tested it with libc-2.5.so, so believe me.

This means that we have to avoid closing the file descriptor with close (as it is very obscurely written in the GNU C Library documentation).

— Function: opendir/c pathname
— Parameter: opendir/c-function
— Function: primitive:opendir/c pathname

Like opendir but push the appropriate call to closedir on the current compensation stack. Compensation stacks.

— Function: fdopendir/c fd
— Parameter: fdopendir/c-function
— Function: fdopendir/c fd

Like fdopendir but push the appropriate call to closedir on the current compensation stack. Compensation stacks.

— Function: dirfd stream
— Parameter: dirfd-function
— Function: primitive:dirfd stream
— Function: platform:dirfd stream

Return the file descriptor associated to the directory stream previously opened with opendir or fdopendir.

Next: file directory access seek, Previous: file directory access open, Up: file directory access

2.4.3 Reading a directory stream

The following functions manage reading the special stream objects used to access directory contents. Reading and closing a directory stream.

As a usage example for the low level functions, let's see how directory-entries is implemented: 

     (define (%directory-entries dir)
       (let loop ((entry  (readdir_r dir))
                  (layout '()))
         (if (pointer-null? entry)
             layout
           (loop (readdir_r dir)
                 (cons (dirent-name->string entry) layout)))))
     
     (define (directory-entries pathname)
       (with-compensations
         (%directory-entries (opendir/compensated pathname))))

to read a directory and sort the entries: 

     (list-sort string<? (directory-entries "/home/marco"))

to read a directory using the file descriptor and the GNU flag O_NOATIME: 

     (with-compensations
       (letrec ((fd (compensate
                        (open the-root
                              (if (number? O_NOATIME)
                                  (bitwise-ior O_RDONLY
                                               O_NOATIME)
                                O_RDONLY)
                              0)
                      (with
                       (close fd)))))
         (directory-entries/fd fd)))
— Function: readdir stream
— Parameter: readdir-function
— Function: primitive:readdir stream
— Function: platform:readdir stream

Return a pointer to a statically allocated struct dirent describing the next entry from the directory stream, previously opened with opendir or fdopendir.

Notice that the returned strings are the names of the entries relative to the uplevel directory. No slash and no parent directory part are in there.

— Function: readdir_r stream
— Parameter: readdir_r-function
— Function: primitive:readdir_r stream
— Function: platform:readdir_r stream

Like readdir, but operates in a reentrant manner.

— Function: directory-entries pathname
— Parameter: directory-entries-function
— Function: primitive:directory-entries pathname

High–level functions that open the directory selected by the Scheme string or symbol pathname, read all the entries and return a list of Scheme strings holding the entry names.

— Function: directory-entries/fd fd
— Parameter: directory-entries/fd-function
— Function: directory-entries/fd fd

High–level functions that open the directory selected by the file descriptor fd, read all the entries and return a list of Scheme strings holding the entry names.

— Function: dirent-name->string struct-dirent-pointer
— Function: primitive:dirent-name->string struct-dirent-pointer

Build and return a Scheme string containing the name of the directory described by struct-dirent-pointer.

Next: file directory access scan, Previous: file directory access read, Up: file directory access

2.4.4 Random access to a directory stream

The following function handle seeking the current position in the special stream objects used to access directory contents. Random Access in a Directory Stream.

For the following bindings: The platform: functions return a single value, they do not use errno to signal errors.

— Function: rewinddir stream
— Parameter: rewinddir-function
— Function: primitive:rewinddir stream
— Function: platform:rewinddir stream

Rewind to the first entry the directory stream previously opened with opendir or fdopendir.

— Function: telldir stream
— Parameter: telldir-function
— Function: primitive:telldir stream
— Function: platform:telldir stream

Return an exact integer representing the current position in the directory stream previously opened with opendir or fdopendir.

Notice that returned values look like arbitrary integers, they do not follow a predictable sequence.

— Function: seekdir stream position
— Parameter: seekdir-function
— Function: primitive:seekdir stream position
— Function: platform:seekdir stream position

Seek to position the directory stream previously opened with opendir or fdopendir. position must be a value previously returned by telldir.

Next: file directory access tree, Previous: file directory access seek, Up: file directory access

2.4.5 Scanning a directory

The following functions implement the scan operation of directory entries. Scanning the Content of a Directory. All the following bindings are exported by the Glibc file libraries.

Usage example: Sort the entries in increasing lexicographic order, excluding the dots: 

     (scandir "/some/path/name"
              (make-scandir-selector-callback
                 (lambda (struct-dirent)
                   (let ((name (dirent-name->string struct-dirent)))
                     (not (or (string=? "."  name)
                              (string=? ".." name))))))
              platform:alphasort)

and if we want to sort the entries in decreasing lexicographic order: 

     (scandir "/some/path/name"
              (make-scandir-selector-callback
               (lambda (struct-dirent)
                 #t))
              (make-scandir-compare-callback
               (lambda (a b)
                 (let ((a (dirent-name->string a))
                       (b (dirent-name->string b)))
                   (cond ((string<? a b) +1)
                         ((string>? a b) -1)
                         (else            0))))))
— Function: scandir pathname selector compare
— Parameter: scandir-function
— Function: primitive:scandir pathname selector compare
— Function: platform:scandir pathname namelist selector compare

Scan the directory selected by pathname, which must be a string or symbol, and return a list of Scheme strings representing the names of the entries in the directory.

selector and compare must be raw pointers to C language functions, either native or built with make-c-callback. Calling Scheme functions.

The function referenced by selector takes a pointer to struct dirent as argument and must return: ‘1’ if the entry has to be included in the output, ‘0’ if it has to be excluded.

The function referenced by compare takes two pointers of type struct dirent ** as arguments and must return a ternary comparison result (as strcmp() does).

— Function: make-scandir-selector-callback scheme-function
— Function: make-scandir-compare-callback scheme-function
— Function: primitive:make-scandir-selector-callback scheme-function
— Function: primitive:make-scandir-compare-callback scheme-function

Given a Scheme function, return a callback pointer to be used as selector or compare argument to scandir. They are implemented as follows: 

          (define (make-scandir-selector-callback scheme-function)
            (make-c-callback int
              (lambda (struct-dirent)
                (if (scheme-function struct-dirent) 1 0))
              (void*)))
          
          (define (make-scandir-compare-callback scheme-function)
            (make-c-callback int scheme-function (void* void*)))
— Function Pointer: platform:alphasort
— Function Pointer: platform:versionsort

Raw pointers to comparison functions exported by the GNU C Library; they are meant to be used as compare arguments for the scandir function.

alphasort will sort the strings in increasing lexicographic order.

Previous: file directory access scan, Up: file directory access

2.4.6 Scanning a hierarchy of directories

The following functions manage to scan a hierarchy of directories. Working with Directory Trees.

Usage example to just list the tree entries: 

     (define-syntax set-cons!
       (syntax-rules ()
         ((_ ?name ?form)
          (set! ?name (cons ?form ?name)))))
     
     (begin0-let ((result '()))
       (ftw "/some/path/name"
            (make-ftw-callback (lambda (pathname stat flag)
                                 (set-cons! result pathname)))
            5))
— Function: ftw pathname inspector descriptors
— Parameter: ftw-function
— Function: primitive:ftw pathname inspector descriptors
— Function: primitive:ftw pathname-cstr inspector descriptors

Invoke the C language function referenced by the raw pointer inspector for each entry in the directory hierarchy whose root is pathname, which must be a Scheme string or symbol.

The callback function referenced by inspector can be a C language coded one or a callback built with make-c-callback; Calling Scheme functions. The callback takes three arguments: a pointer to the current pathname as a C string, a pointer to a struct stat for the current pathname, an exact integer holding flag values.

descriptors is the number of file descriptors the system is allowed to use while walking the directory tree.

— Function: nftw pathname inspector descriptors flags
— Parameter: nftw-function
— Function: primitive:nftw pathname inspector descriptors flags
— Function: primitive:nftw pathname-cstr inspector descriptors flags

Invoke the C language function referenced by the raw pointer inspector for each entry in the directory hierarchy whose root is pathname, which must be a Scheme string or symbol.

The callback function referenced by inspector can be a C language coded one or a callback built with make-c-callback. Calling Scheme functions. The callback takes four arguments: a pointer to the current pathname as a C string, a pointer to a struct stat for the current pathname, a pointer to a struct FTW for the current pathname, an exact integer holding flag values.

descriptors is the number of file descriptors the system is allowed to use while walking the directory tree. flags is an inclusive OR-ed combination of flag values used to configure the iteration; to select no flags, we can use zero.

— Function: make-ftw-callback scheme-function
— Function: make-nftw-callback scheme-function
— Function: primitive:make-ftw-callback scheme-function
— Function: primitive:make-nftw-callback scheme-function

Build and return a callback to be used with ftw and nftw; they are implemented as follows: 

          (define (make-ftw-callback scheme-function)
            (make-c-callback int
               (lambda (pathname-cstr struct-stat flag)
                 (guard (E (else -1))
                   (scheme-function (cstring->string pathname-cstr)
                                    (if (= 0 (bitwise-and flag FTW_NS))
                                        #f
                                      (struct-stat->record struct-stat))
                                    flag)))
               (char* void* int)))
          
          (define (make-nftw-callback scheme-function)
            (make-c-callback int
               (lambda (pathname-cstr struct-stat flag struct-ftw)
                 (guard (E (else -1))
                   (scheme-function (cstring->string pathname-cstr)
                                    (if (= 0 (bitwise-and flag FTW_NS))
                                        #f
                                      (struct-stat->record struct-stat))
                                    flag
                                    (struct-ftw-base-ref  struct-ftw)
                                    (struct-ftw-level-ref struct-ftw))))
               (char* void* int void*)))

The following bindings are exported by the sizeof library.

— Syntax: struct-ftw-base-ref pointer
— Syntax: struct-ftw-level-ref pointer

Accessors for the base and level fields of a struct FTW type.

— Constant: FTW_F
— Constant: FTW_D
— Constant: FTW_NS
— Constant: FTW_DNR
— Constant: FTW_SL

Flags used for the flag argument to the ftw and nftw callbacks; we should use bitwise-and to test for them.

— Constant: FTW_DP
— Constant: FTW_SLN

Additional flag values used for the flag argument to the nftw callback; we should use bitwise-and to test for them.

— Constant: FTW_PHYS
— Constant: FTW_MOUNT
— Constant: FTW_CHDIR
— Constant: FTW_DEPTH
— Constant: FTW_ACTIONRETVAL

Flags for the flags arguments to nftw; we must use bitwise-ior to compose them.

— Constant: FTW_CONTINUE
— Constant: FTW_STOP
— Constant: FTW_SKIP_SUBTREE
— Constant: FTW_SKIP_SIBLINGS

Possible return values for the callback to nftw when the ‘FTW_ACTIONRETVAL’ flag is used in the flags argument.

Next: file remove, Previous: file directory access, Up: file

2.5 Hard and symbolic links

The following functions manage hard and symbolic links to files. Hard Links. Symbolic Links.

— Function: link old-pathname new-pathname
— Parameter: link-function
— Function: primitive:link old-pathname new-pathname
— Function: platform:link old-pathname-cstr new-pathname-cstr

Link to the new name specified by the Scheme string or symbol new-pathname, the file selected by the Scheme string or symbol old-pathname.

— Function: symlink old-pathname new-pathname
— Parameter: symlink-function
— Function: primitive:symlink old-pathname new-pathname
— Function: platform:symlink old-pathname-cstr new-pathname-cstr

Symbolically link to the new name specified by the Scheme string or symbol new-pathname, the file selected by the Scheme string or symbol old-pathname.

— Function: readlink pathname
— Parameter: readlink-function
— Function: primitive:readlink pathname
— Function: platform:readlink pathname-cstr

Return a string representing the value of the symbolic link pathname, which must be a Scheme string or symbol.

— Function: realpath pathname
— Parameter: realpath-function
— Function: primitive:realpath pathname
— Function: platform:realpath pathname-cstr buffer-ptr

Return a string representing the absolute name of the file represented by pathname, which must be a Scheme string or symbol. The returned name contains neither ‘.’ or ‘..’ components, nor sequences of path separators (slashes).

NOTE The GNU C Library exports the function canonicalize_file_name() which does the same work of realpath; for this reason it is not exposed at the Scheme level.

Next: file rename, Previous: file links, Up: file

2.6 Removing files and directories

The following functions manage removal of files and directories from a file system. Deleting Files.

— Function: unlink pathname
— Parameter: unlink-function
— Function: primitive:unlink pathname
— Function: platform:unlink pathname

Remove the file selected by the Scheme string or symbol pathname.

— Function: remove pathname
— Parameter: remove-function
— Function: primitive:remove pathname
— Function: platform:remove pathname

Remove the file or directory selected by the Scheme string or symbol pathname.

— Function: rmdir pathname
— Parameter: rmdir-function
— Function: primitive:rmdir pathname
— Function: platform:rmdir pathname

Remove the directory selected by the Scheme string or symbol pathname. The directory has to be empty.

Next: file mkdir, Previous: file remove, Up: file

2.7 Renaming files and directories

The following functions manage renaming of files and directories from a file system. Renaming Files.

— Function: rename old-pathname new-pathname
— Parameter: rename-function
— Function: primitive:rename old-pathname new-pathname
— Function: platform:rename old-pathname new-pathname

Rename the file selected by the string or symbol old-pathname to the pathname selected by the string or symbol new-pathname.

Next: file attr, Previous: file rename, Up: file

2.8 Creating directories

The following functions manage creating new directories. Creating Directories.

— Function: mkdir pathname
— Parameter: mkdir-function
— Function: primitive:mkdir pathname
— Function: platform:mkdir pathname

Create a new directory with pathname selected by the Scheme string or symbol pathname.

Next: file temp, Previous: file mkdir, Up: file

2.9 Changing file attributes

The functions described in this section manage file and directory attributes. File Attributes.

  • file attr owner: Changing owner and group.
  • file attr mode: Changing file permissions.
  • file attr access: Testing access.
  • file attr size: Size of files.

Next: file attr mode, Up: file attr

2.9.1 File owner and group

The following functions manage file ownership attributes. File Owner.

— Function: chown pathname owner-id group-id
— Parameter: chown-function
— Function: primitive:chown pathname owner-id group-id
— Function: platform:chown pathname-cstr owner-id group-id

Change the file owner and group to the given numeric identifiers. pathname must be a Scheme string or symbol representing a pathname.

— Function: fchown fd owner-id group-id
— Parameter: fchown-function
— Function: primitive:fchown fd owner-id group-id
— Function: platform:fchown fchown fd owner-id group-id

Change the file owner and group to the given numeric identifiers. fd must be a file descriptor.

Next: file attr access, Previous: file attr owner, Up: file attr

2.9.2 Changing file permissions

The following functions manage file access permissions. Assigning File Permissions.

The mask argument must be an exact integer representing access permissions bits. fd constants perms for details about composing the the mask value as a bitwise combination of predefined constants.

— Function: umask mask
— Parameter: umask-function
— Function: primitive:umask mask
— Function: platform:umask mask

Set the umask to mask and return the old mask value. To query the current mask without changing it: 

          (let ((m (umask 0)))
            (umask m)
            m)

or use getumask, which has exactly this implementation.

mask can be an exact integer or an enumeration set of type enum-access-permissions.

— Function: getumask
— Function: primitive:getumask

Return the current umask.

— Function: chmod pathname mask
— Parameter: chmod-function
— Function: primitive:chmod pathname mask
— Function: platform:chmod pathname-cstr mask

Change the file access permissions bits to the given numeric mask. pathname must be a Scheme string or symbol representing a pathname. mask can be an exact integer or an enumeration set of type enum-access-permissions.

— Function: fchmod fd mask
— Parameter: fchmod-function
— Function: primitive:fchmod fd mask
— Function: platform:fchmod fd mask

Change the file access permissions bits to the given numeric mask. fd must be a file descriptor. mask can be an exact integer or an enumeration set of type enum-access-permissions.

Next: file attr size, Previous: file attr mode, Up: file attr

2.9.3 Testing access

The following functions manage testing if the process has access permissions for a file or directory. Testing permission to access a file.

Example: 

     (access "file.ext" (bitwise-ior R_OK W_OK))
— Function: access pathname mask
— Parameter: access-function
— Function: primitive:access pathname mask
— Function: platform:access pathname-cstr mask

Return #t if the process has permission to access the file selected by the Scheme string or symbol pathname as specified by mask; return #f otherwise.

mask can be an exact integer or an enumeration set of type enum-access-flags; in the integer case, it can be the bitwise combination of: F_OK, R_OK, W_OK, X_OK.

Previous: file attr access, Up: file attr

2.9.4 Size of files

— Function: file-size fd/pathname
— Parameter: file-size-function
— Function: primitive:file-size fd/pathname

Return the size of the selected file. fd/pathname can be a file descriptor or a pathname in the form of a Scheme string or symbol.

This function is implemented using lseek as described in Setting the file position.

— Function: truncate fd/pathname length
— Parameter: truncate-function
— Function: primitive:truncate fd/pathname length
— Function: platform:truncate fd/pathname-cstr length

Set to length the size of the selected file. fd/pathname can be a file descriptor or a pathname in the form of a Scheme string or symbol.

— Function: ftruncate fd/pathname length
— Parameter: ftruncate-function
— Function: primitive:ftruncate fd/pathname length
— Function: platform:ftruncate fd/pathname-cstr length

Set to length the size of the selected file. fd/pathname can be a file descriptor or a pathname in the form of a Scheme string or symbol.

Next: file times, Previous: file attr, Up: file

2.10 Temporary files

The following functions manage the creation of temporary files and directories. Temporary Files.

Usage example: 

     (let-values (((fd pathname) (mkstemp "/tmp/XXXXXX")))
       ---
       (close fd)
       (delete-file pathname))
— Function: mkstemp template
— Parameter: mkstemp-function
— Function: primitive:mkstemp template
— Function: platform:mkstemp template-cstr

Return two values: a file descriptor and a file pathname as Scheme string. The pathname is built from the Scheme string or symbol template, which must include the XXXXXX sequence of characters (six times X). template is not mutated.

— Function: mkdtemp template
— Parameter: mkdtemp-function
— Function: primitive:mkdtemp template
— Function: platform:mkdtemp template-cstr

Create a new directory and return its pathname as Scheme string. The pathname is built from the Scheme string or symbol template, which must include the XXXXXX sequence of characters (six times X). template is not mutated.

GNU C Library functions

The bindings documented below are exported by the following libraries: 

     (glibc file)
     (glibc file primitives)
     (glibc file platform)
— Function: tmpfile
— Parameter: tmpfile-function
— Function: primitive:tmpfile
— Function: platform:tmpfile

Create a temporary file, open it and return a file stream object.

NOTE This function is POSIX compliant, but it is exported by a Glibc function because it makes use of FILE * streams. It is decided that streams–related functions are not to be exported by the POSIX libraries.

— Function: mktemp template
— Parameter: mktemp-function
— Function: primitive:mktemp template
— Function: platform:mktemp template-cstr

Return a file pathname, as Scheme string, that, at the time of the call, does not exist on the system. The pathname is built from the Scheme string or symbol template, which must include the XXXXXX sequence of characters (six times X). template is not mutated.

— Function: tempnam directory prefix
— Parameter: tempnam-function
— Function: primitive:tempnam directory prefix
— Function: platform:tempnam directory-cstr prefix-cstr

Build and return a file pathname, as Scheme string, that, at the time of the call, does not exists on the system. directory and prefix can be Scheme string or symbols or #f (in place of NULL pointers). directory is used as directory pathname in which to create the temporary file; prefix is used as prefix for the file name.

— Function: tmpnam
— Parameter: tmpnam-function
— Function: primitive:tmpnam
— Function: platform:tmpnam

Return a file pathname, as Scheme string, that, at the time of the call, does not exist on the system. The implementation of primitive:tmpnam is reentrant.

Next: file stat, Previous: file temp, Up: file

2.11 Setting file times

— Function: utime pathname
— Function: utime pathname access-time modification-time
— Parameter: utime-function
— Function: primitive:utime pathname
— Function: primitive:utime pathname access-time modification-time
— Function: platform:utime pathname-cstr utimbuf-pointer

Set the access and modification times for the file selected by pathname, which must be a Scheme string or symbol. If access-time and modification-time are not given, set the times to the current time.

NOTE The SUS1 states that an implementation may choose not to set the access time of the file, even though it is requested by the utime() call.

— Function: utimes pathname
— Function: utimes pathname atime atime-usec mtime mtime-usec
— Parameter: utimes-function
— Function: primitive:utimes pathname
— Function: primitive:utimes pathname atime atime-usec mtime mtime-usec
— Function: platform:utimes pathname-cstr utimbuf-pointer

Set the access and modification times, both the integer part and the fractional part, for the file selected by pathname, which must be a Scheme string or symbol. If the time arguments are not given, set the times to the current time.

GNU C Library functions

The bindings documented below are exported by the following libraries: 

     (glibc file)
     (glibc file primitives)
     (glibc file platform)
— Function: lutimes pathname
— Function: lutimes pathname atime atime-usec mtime mtime-usec
— Parameter: lutimes-function
— Function: primitive:lutimes pathname
— Function: primitive:lutimes pathname atime atime-usec mtime mtime-usec
— Function: platform:lutimes pathname-cstr utimbuf-pointer

Like utimes, but does not follow symbolic links.

— Function: futimes fd
— Function: futimes fd atime atime-usec mtime mtime-usec
— Parameter: futimes-function
— Function: primitive:futimes fd
— Function: primitive:futimes fd atime atime-usec mtime mtime-usec
— Function: platform:futimes fd utimbuf-pointer

Like utimes, but act upon the file associated to the given file descriptor.

Previous: file times, Up: file

2.12 Inspecting file attributes

  • file stat constants: Constant values and structure accessors.
  • file stat record: Acquiring the file attributes.
  • file stat api: Interface functions.
  • file stat type: Type inspection.
  • file stat perms: Access permissions inspection.

Next: file stat record, Up: file stat

2.12.1 Constant values and structures accessors

The following bindings are exported by the (posix file platform) library; this is because struct stat is somewhat “special”, so we relay on the libnausicaa-posix.so stub library to deal with it.

— Constant: sizeof-stat

The size of the struct stat data structure in bytes. This binding is exported by (posix stat platform).

— Function: struct-stat-st_mode-ref stat-pointer
— Function: struct-stat-st_ino-ref stat-pointer
— Function: struct-stat-st_dev-ref stat-pointer
— Function: struct-stat-st_nlink-ref stat-pointer
— Function: struct-stat-st_uid-ref stat-pointer
— Function: struct-stat-st_gid-ref stat-pointer
— Function: struct-stat-st_size-ref stat-pointer
— Function: struct-stat-st_atime-ref stat-pointer
— Function: struct-stat-st_atime_usec-ref stat-pointer
— Function: struct-stat-st_mtime-ref stat-pointer
— Function: struct-stat-st_mtime_usec-ref stat-pointer
— Function: struct-stat-st_ctime-ref stat-pointer
— Function: struct-stat-st_ctime_usec-ref stat-pointer
— Function: struct-stat-st_blocks-ref stat-pointer
— Function: struct-stat-st_blksize-ref stat-pointer

Accessors for the named field of a struct stat. Notice that some field may be undefined on some platforms (examples: st_atime_usec, st_mtime_usec, st_ctime_usec), in this case the return value is zero.

Next: file stat api, Previous: file stat constants, Up: file stat

2.12.2 Acquiring the file attributes

The following bindings are exported by the (posix typedefs) library. The informations about a file or directory are stored in a Scheme record which mirrors struct stat. The meaning of the File Attributes.

— Record Type Name: <stat>
— Record Type Descriptor: <stat-rtd>

Type of record used to hold fields from a struct stat. List of fields follows: 

          mode            ino
          dev             nlink
          uid             gid
          size
          atime           atime_usec
          mtime           mtime_usec
          ctime           ctime_usec
          blocks          blksize

all the fields are immutable; we have to refer to the original documentation of struct stat for their meaning.

Some fields are not available on every platform in the foreign struct stat data structure; in this case the associated field in the <stat> record should be set to #f. For example atime_usec, mtime_usec, ctime_usec are not available on some common platforms.

— Function: make-<stat> mode ino dev nlink uid gid size atime atime_usec mtime mtime_usec ctime ctime_usec blocks blksize
— Function: <stat>? obj

Constructor and predicate for records of type <stat>.

— Function: <stat>-mode struct-stat
— Function: <stat>-ino struct-stat
— Function: <stat>-dev struct-stat
— Function: <stat>-nlink struct-stat
— Function: <stat>-uid struct-stat
— Function: <stat>-gid struct-stat
— Function: <stat>-size struct-stat
— Function: <stat>-atime struct-stat
— Function: <stat>-atime_usec struct-stat
— Function: <stat>-mtime struct-stat
— Function: <stat>-mtime_usec struct-stat
— Function: <stat>-ctime struct-stat
— Function: <stat>-ctime_usec struct-stat
— Function: <stat>-blocks struct-stat
— Function: <stat>-blksize struct-stat

Accessors for the fields of a <stat> record.

Next: file stat type, Previous: file stat record, Up: file stat

2.12.3 Interface functions

The following bindings manage file attributes inspection. Reading Attributes.

— Function: primitive:pointer-><stat> pointer

Given a pointer to a block of memory holding a C language struct stat, build and return a <stat> record mirroring it. All the fields that are not available in the foreign structure are set to zero.

— Function: stat pathname
— Parameter: stat-function
— Function: primitive:stat pathname
— Function: platform:stat pathname-cstr pointer

Return a <stat> record filled with attributes of the file or directory selected by the Scheme string or symbol pathname.

— Function: fstat fd
— Parameter: fstat-function
— Function: primitive:fstat fd
— Function: platform:fstat fd pointer

Return a <stat> record filled with attributes of the file or directory selected by the file descriptor fd.

— Function: lstat pathname
— Parameter: lstat-function
— Function: primitive:lstat pathname
— Function: platform:lstat pathname-cstr pointer

Return a <stat> record filled with attributes of the symbolic link selected by the Scheme string or symbol pathname.

Next: file stat perms, Previous: file stat api, Up: file stat

2.12.4 Type inspection

The integer in the mode field of a <stat> record can be inspected with the following functions. Unless otherwise specified, the following bindings are exported by the (posix stat) library.

— Function: file-is-directory? fd/pathname/mode
— Function: file-is-character-special? fd/pathname/mode
— Function: file-is-block-special? fd/pathname/mode
— Function: file-is-regular? fd/pathname/mode
— Function: file-is-fifo? fd/pathname/mode
— Function: file-is-socket? fd/pathname/mode

Return #t if fd/pathname/mode is associated to a file of the named type, #f otherwise.

fd/pathname/mode can be: a file descriptor, a Scheme string or symbol representing a pathname, an exact integer representing the st_mode field of a struct stat.

In the file descriptor and file pathname cases: the mode field of struct stat is acquired with a call to fstat or stat.

NOTE There is no file-is-link? function because, for symbolic links, we have to use lstat. See below for file-is-symbolic-link?.

— Function: file-is-symbolic-link? pathname/mode

Return #t if pathname/mode is associated to a symbolic link, #f otherwise.

pathname/mode can be: a Scheme string or symbol representing a pathname, an exact integer representing the st_mode field of a struct stat acquired with lstat().

In the pathname case: the st_mode field of struct stat is acquired with a call to lstat.

— Function: file-is-message-queue? fd/pathname
— Function: file-is-semaphore? fd/pathname
— Function: file-is-shared-memory? fd/pathname

Return #t if fd/pathname is associated to a file of the named type, #f otherwise. fd/pathname can be a file descriptor or a Scheme string or symbol representing a pathname.

Unfortunately, these predicates require access to the full struct stat, so, at present, they are implemented with the low–level platform:stat and platform:fstat. This prevents using parametrised functions like stat and fstat.

Low–level predicates

The bindings documented below are exported by the all the following libraries: 

     (posix file)
     (posix file primitives)
     (posix file platform)
— Function: S_ISDIR mode
— Function: S_ISCHR mode
— Function: S_ISBLK mode
— Function: S_ISREG mode
— Function: S_ISFIFO mode
— Function: S_ISLNK mode
— Function: S_ISSOCK mode

Return non–zero if the file or directory having the integer mode in the st_mode field of its struct stat is of the named type, otherwise return zero.

S_ISLNK is meaningful only if mode is acquired with lstat().

— Function: S_TYPEISMQ pointer
— Function: S_TYPEISSEM pointer
— Function: S_TYPEISSHM pointer

Return non–zero if the file or directory associated with the struct stat referenced by pointer is of the named type, otherwise return zero.

Previous: file stat type, Up: file stat

2.12.5 Access permissions inspection

The bindings described in this section are exported by the (posix file primitives) library in their raw version, and by the (posix file) library in their parametrised version.

Access permissions can be inspected with a bitwise combination between the st_mode field of struct stat and the permissions constants, fd constants perms. For example, the following evaluates to #f if /bin/ls is readable by its owner: 

     (= 0 (bitwise-and S_IRUSR
                       (<stat>-mode (stat "/bin/ls"))))

while the following evaluates to #f if /bin/ls is readable both by its owner and group: 

     (= 0 (bitwise-and (bitwise-ior S_IRUSR S_IRGRP)
                       (<stat>-mode (stat "/bin/ls"))))
  • file stat perms files: Files status.
  • file stat perms links: Symbolic links status.

Next: file stat perms links, Up: file stat perms
2.12.5.1 Files status

The fd/mode/pathname argument can be: a file descriptor, a Scheme string or symbol representing a pathname, an exact integer representing the st_mode field of a struct stat. In the file descriptor and pathname cases: the st_mode field of struct stat is acquired with a call to fstat or stat.

— Function: file-user-readable? fd/mode/pathname
— Parameter: file-user-readable?-function
— Function: primitive:file-user-readable? fd/mode/pathname

Return #t if the named permission bit is set, #f otherwise.

— Function: file-user-writable? fd/mode/pathname
— Parameter: file-user-writable?-function
— Function: primitive:file-user-writable? fd/mode/pathname

Return #t if the named permission bit is set, #f otherwise.

— Function: file-user-executable? fd/mode/pathname
— Parameter: file-user-executable?-function
— Function: primitive:file-user-executable? fd/mode/pathname

Return #t if the named permission bit is set, #f otherwise.

— Function: file-group-readable? fd/mode/pathname
— Parameter: file-group-readable?-function
— Function: primitive:file-group-readable? fd/mode/pathname

Return #t if the named permission bit is set, #f otherwise.

— Function: file-group-writable? fd/mode/pathname
— Parameter: file-group-writable?-function
— Function: primitive:file-group-writable? fd/mode/pathname

Return #t if the named permission bit is set, #f otherwise.

— Function: file-group-executable? fd/mode/pathname
— Parameter: file-group-executable?-function
— Function: primitive:file-group-executable? fd/mode/pathname

Return #t if the named permission bit is set, #f otherwise.

— Function: file-other-readable? fd/mode/pathname
— Parameter: file-other-readable?-function
— Function: primitive:file-other-readable? fd/mode/pathname

Return #t if the named permission bit is set, #f otherwise.

— Function: file-other-writable? fd/mode/pathname
— Parameter: file-other-writable?-function
— Function: primitive:file-other-writable? fd/mode/pathname

Return #t if the named permission bit is set, #f otherwise.

— Function: file-other-executable? fd/mode/pathname
— Parameter: file-other-executable?-function
— Function: primitive:file-other-executable? fd/mode/pathname

Return #t if the named permission bit is set, #f otherwise.

— Function: file-setuid? fd/mode/pathname
— Parameter: file-setuid?-function
— Function: primitive:file-setuid? fd/mode/pathname

Return #t if the named permission bit is set, #f otherwise.

— Function: file-setgid? fd/mode/pathname
— Parameter: file-setgid?-function
— Function: primitive:file-setgid? fd/mode/pathname

Return #t if the named permission bit is set, #f otherwise.

— Function: file-sticky? fd/mode/pathname
— Parameter: file-sticky?-function
— Function: primitive:file-sticky? fd/mode/pathname

Return #t if the named permission bit is set, #f otherwise.

— Function: file-permissions fd/pathname
— Parameter: file-permissions-function
— Function: primitive:file-permissions fd/pathname

Return an exact integer representing the access permissions bits from the st_mode field of a struct stat.

fd/pathname can be a file descriptor or a pathname in the form of a Scheme string or symbol; the mode is acquired with a call to fstat or stat.

The returned value can be examined and manipulated using the S_* constants (see fd constants perms) and also used as argument for a call to chmod or fchmod.

Previous: file stat perms files, Up: file stat perms
2.12.5.2 Symbolic links status

For the following functions, the mode/pathname argument must be: a Scheme string or symbol representing a pathname, an exact integer representing the st_mode field of a struct stat acquired with lstat(). In the pathname case: the the st_mode field of struct stat is acquired with lstat.

— Function: lfile-user-readable? mode/pathname
— Parameter: lfile-user-readable?-function
— Function: primitive:lfile-user-readable? mode/pathname

Return #t if the named permission bit is set, #f otherwise.

— Function: lfile-user-writable? mode/pathname
— Parameter: lfile-user-writable?-function
— Function: primitive:lfile-user-writable? mode/pathname

Return #t if the named permission bit is set, #f otherwise.

— Function: lfile-user-executable? mode/pathname
— Parameter: lfile-user-executable?-function
— Function: primitive:lfile-user-executable? mode/pathname

Return #t if the named permission bit is set, #f otherwise.

— Function: lfile-group-readable? mode/pathname
— Parameter: lfile-group-readable?-function
— Function: primitive:lfile-group-readable? mode/pathname

Return #t if the named permission bit is set, #f otherwise.

— Function: lfile-group-writable? mode/pathname
— Parameter: lfile-group-writable?-function
— Function: primitive:lfile-group-writable? mode/pathname

Return #t if the named permission bit is set, #f otherwise.

— Function: lfile-group-executable? mode/pathname
— Parameter: lfile-group-executable?-function
— Function: primitive:lfile-group-executable? mode/pathname

Return #t if the named permission bit is set, #f otherwise.

— Function: lfile-other-readable? mode/pathname
— Parameter: lfile-other-readable?-function
— Function: primitive:lfile-other-readable? mode/pathname

Return #t if the named permission bit is set, #f otherwise.

— Function: lfile-other-writable? mode/pathname
— Parameter: lfile-other-writable?-function
— Function: primitive:lfile-other-writable? mode/pathname

Return #t if the named permission bit is set, #f otherwise.

— Function: lfile-other-executable? mode/pathname
— Parameter: lfile-other-executable?-function
— Function: primitive:lfile-other-executable? mode/pathname

Return #t if the named permission bit is set, #f otherwise.

— Function: lfile-setuid? mode/pathname
— Parameter: lfile-setuid?-function
— Function: primitive:lfile-setuid? mode/pathname

Return #t if the named permission bit is set, #f otherwise.

— Function: lfile-setgid? mode/pathname
— Parameter: lfile-setgid?-function
— Function: primitive:lfile-setgid? mode/pathname

Return #t if the named permission bit is set, #f otherwise.

— Function: lfile-sticky? mode/pathname
— Parameter: lfile-sticky?-function
— Function: primitive:lfile-sticky? mode/pathname

Return #t if the named permission bit is set, #f otherwise.

— Function: lfile-permissions pathname
— Parameter: lfile-permissions-function
— Function: primitive:lfile-permissions pathname

Return an exact integer representing the access permissions bits from the st_mode field of a struct stat.

pathname must be a pathname in the form of a Scheme string or symbol; the mode is acquired with a call to lstat.

The returned value can be examined and manipulated using the S_* constants (see fd constants perms) and also used as argument for a call to chmod or fchmod.

Next: sockets, Previous: file, Up: Top

3 File descriptors

Unless otherwise specified, the bindings described in this chapter are exported by the following libraries: 

     (posix fd)
     (posix fd primitives)
     (posix fd platform)
  • fd typedefs: File descriptor related data types.
  • fd constants: Constant values and structure accessors.
  • fd enumerations: Enumeration sets.
  • fd open close: Opening and closing.
  • fd read write: Reading and writing.
  • fd seek: Setting the file position.
  • fd sync: Synchronisation.
  • fd control: Control operations.
  • fd dup: Duplicating file descriptors.
  • fd lock: File locks.
  • fd pipe: Pipes and FIFOs.
  • fd scatter: Scatter/gather input/output.
  • fd mmap: Memory mapped input/output.
  • fd select: Waiting for input or output.
  • fd custom: Custom Scheme ports.

Next: fd constants, Up: fd

3.1 File descriptor related data types

Unless otherwise specified, the bindings documented in this section are exported by the (posix typedefs) library.

  • fd typedefs fds: File descriptors.
  • fd typedefs flocks: File locking.
  • fd typedefs fdsets: File descriptor sets.

Next: fd typedefs flocks, Up: fd typedefs

3.1.1 File descriptors

Functions from the primitives and high–level file descriptor libraries accept objects of type <fd> as fd arguments. Functions from the platform libraries accept exact integers as representing file descriptors.

— Object Type: <fd>

Object type representing a file descriptor integer; it is disjoint from all the other Scheme object types.

— Function: <fd>? obj

Return true if obj is a file descriptor object.

— Function: <fd>->integer fd
— Function: integer-><fd> integer

Convert between a file descriptor object and an integer object.

Next: fd typedefs fdsets, Previous: fd typedefs fds, Up: fd typedefs

3.1.2 File locking

Functions from the primitives and high–level file descriptor libraries accept objects of type struct-flock as flock arguments. Functions from the platform libraries accept pointer objects as references to struct flock data structures.

— Object Type: struct-flock

Object type referencing a struct flock data structure; it is disjoint from all the other Scheme object types.

— Function: make-struct-flock malloc

Build and return a new struct-flock object, referencing a newly allocated C language struct flock value.

Memory is allocated using the function malloc, whose behaviour must match the one of malloc from (foreign memory). Exception raising functions. To release memory we have to convert the struct-flock object to a pointer object and call the appropriate free function.

— Function: struct-flock? obj

Return true if obj is a struct-flock object.

— Function: struct-flock->pointer fd
— Function: pointer->struct-flock flock

Convert between a struct-flock object and a pointer object.

The following bindings are exported by the (posix extensions) library.

— Extension Type: struct-flock*

Extension type which allows accessing and mutating the fields of a struct flock data structure using the facilities of the (records) library. It has the following fields:

type
whence
start
len
pid
One virtual field for each field of struct flock.

Previous: fd typedefs flocks, Up: fd typedefs

3.1.3 File descriptor sets

Functions from the primitive and high–level libraries acting upon file descriptor sets (C language type fd_set) accept objects of type fdset as fdset arguments. Functions from the platform libraries accept pointer objects as references to fd_set values.

— Object Type: fdset

Object type referencing a file descriptor set; it is disjoint from all the other Scheme object types.

— Function: fdset? obj

Return true if obj is a file descriptor object.

— Function: make-fdset malloc

Build and return a new fdset object, referencing a newly allocated C language fd_set value.

Memory is allocated using the function malloc, whose behaviour must match the one of malloc from (foreign memory). Exception raising functions. To release memory we have to convert the fdset object to a pointer object and call the appropriate free function.

— Function: fdset->pointer fdset
— Function: pointer->fdset integer

Convert between a file descriptor object and an integer object.

Next: fd enumerations, Previous: fd typedefs, Up: fd

3.2 Constant values and structure accessors

  • fd constants status: File status flags.
  • fd constants perms: Permissions.
  • fd constants control: File control flags.
  • fd constants seek: File positions.
  • fd constants lock: Locking.
  • fd constants mmap: Memory--mapped files.
  • fd constants select: Waiting for file descriptor events.

Next: fd constants perms, Up: fd constants

3.2.1 File status flags

All the following bindings are exported by the (posix sizeof) library. If a value is not defined on the underlying platform: the corresponding binding is to #f. File Status Flags.

— Constant: O_RDONLY
— Constant: O_WRONLY
— Constant: O_RDWR

File access modes to be used with open.

— Constant: O_EXEC
— Constant: O_READ
— Constant: O_WRITE

These are GNU only values. O_EXEC is used with open to open a file for execution. O_READ and O_WRITE are like O_RDONLY and O_WRONLY.

— Constant: O_ACCMODE

To be used with fcntl to query the open access mode of file descriptors.

— Constant: O_CREAT
— Constant: O_EXCL
— Constant: O_APPEND
— Constant: O_NONBLOCK
— Constant: O_NOCTTY

Open–time flags to be used with open.

— Constant: O_NDELAY

BSD only alias for O_NONBLOCK.

— Constant: O_IGNORE_CTTY
— Constant: O_NOLINK
— Constant: O_NOTRANS

GNU only file name translation flags to be used with open.

— Constant: O_TRUNC

Open–time action flags to be used with open.

— Constant: O_SHLOCK
— Constant: O_EXLOCK

BSD only flags to be used with open.

— Constant: O_ASYNC
— Constant: O_FSYNC
— Constant: O_SYNC

BSD only flags to be used with open.

— Constant: O_NOATIME

GNU only flag to be used with open.

— Constant: O_DIRECT
— Constant: O_DIRECTORY
— Constant: O_LARGEFILE
— Constant: O_NOFOLLOW

Linux specific flags to be used with open.

Next: fd constants control, Previous: fd constants status, Up: fd constants

3.2.2 Permissions

All the following bindings are exported by the (posix sizeof) library. The mode bits for access permission.

— Constant: S_IRUSR
— Constant: S_IWUSR
— Constant: S_IXUSR

Permissions bits for file owner access.

— Constant: S_IRGRP
— Constant: S_IWGRP
— Constant: S_IXGRP

Permissions bits for group access.

— Constant: S_IROTH
— Constant: S_IWOTH
— Constant: S_IXOTH

Permissions bits for other users access.

— Constant: S_IRWXU

This is the bitwise combination of permissions bits for user access; it could be defined as: 

          (define S_IRWXU
            (bitwise-ior S_IRUSR S_IWUSR S_IXUSR))
— Constant: S_IRWXG

This is the bitwise combination of permissions bits for group access. It could be defined as: 

          (define S_IRWXG
            (bitwise-ior S_IRGRP S_IWGRP S_IXGRP))
— Constant: S_IRWXO

This is the bitwise combination of permissions bits for other users access. It could be defined as: 

          (define S_IRWXO
            (bitwise-ior S_IROTH S_IWOTH S_IXOTH))
— Constant: S_ISUID
— Constant: S_ISGID
— Constant: S_ISVTX

These are the setuid, setgid and “sticky bit” values.

Next: fd constants seek, Previous: fd constants perms, Up: fd constants

3.2.3 File control flags

All the following bindings are exported by the (posix sizeof) library; the values are meant to be used as operation argument in call to fcntl.

— Constant: F_GETFL
— Constant: F_SETFL

Set/get the status of a file. Getting and Setting File Status Flags.

— Constant: F_DUPFD

Duplicate the file descriptor. Duplicating Descriptors.

— Constant: F_GETFD
— Constant: F_SETFD

Set/get the status of a file descriptor. File Descriptor Flags.

— Constant: FD_CLOEXEC

State that the file descriptor has to be closed if an exec() is performed. File Descriptor Flags.

— Constant: F_SETLK
— Constant: F_GETLK
— Constant: F_SETLKW

Set/get a file lock. F_SETLKW sets a file lock, but waits for completion. File Locks.

— Constant: F_GETOWN
— Constant: F_SETOWN

Set/get process to receive SIGIO signals. Interrupt–Driven Output.

Next: fd constants lock, Previous: fd constants control, Up: fd constants

3.2.4 File positions

All the following bindings are exported by the (posix sizeof) library. Setting the File Position of a Descriptor.

— Constant: SEEK_SET
— Constant: SEEK_CUR
— Constant: SEEK_END

File positions for the whence argument to lseek.

Next: fd constants mmap, Previous: fd constants seek, Up: fd constants

3.2.5 Locking

All the following bindings are exported by the (posix sizeof) library. File Locks.

— Constant: F_RDLCK
— Constant: F_WRLCK
— Constant: F_UNLCK

Flags for file descriptor locking.

— Constant: sizeof-flock
— Constant: alignof-flock
— Constant: strideof-flock

These are: the number of bytes required to hold a structure of type struct flock; the alignment of the structure when embedded in another structure; the number of bytes between two elements in an array of structures.

— Syntax: struct-flock-l_type-set! pointer value
— Syntax: struct-flock-l_type-ref pointer
— Syntax: struct-flock-l_whence-set! pointer value
— Syntax: struct-flock-l_whence-ref pointer
— Syntax: struct-flock-l_start-set! pointer value
— Syntax: struct-flock-l_start-ref pointer
— Syntax: struct-flock-l_len-set! pointer value
— Syntax: struct-flock-l_len-ref pointer
— Syntax: struct-flock-l_pid-set! pointer value
— Syntax: struct-flock-l_pid-ref pointer

Peekers and pokers for the fields of a struct flock.

Next: fd constants select, Previous: fd constants lock, Up: fd constants

3.2.6 Memory–mapped files

All the following bindings are exported by the (posix sizeof) library. Memory–mapped I/O.

— Constant: MAP_PRIVATE
— Constant: MAP_SHARED
— Constant: MAP_FIXED
— Constant: MAP_ANON
— Constant: MAP_ANONYMOUS
— Constant: MAP_32BITS
— Constant: MAP_DENYWRITE
— Constant: MAP_EXECUTABLE
— Constant: MAP_FILE
— Constant: MAP_GROWSDOWN
— Constant: MAP_LOCKED
— Constant: MAP_NONBLOCK
— Constant: MAP_NORESERVE
— Constant: MAP_POPULATE
— Constant: MAP_STACK
— Constant: MAP_AUTOGROW
— Constant: MAP_AUTORESRV
— Constant: MAP_COPY

Values for the flags argument to mmap; they must be composed with bitwise inclusive OR. One among ‘MAP_PRIVATE’ and ‘MAP_SHARED’ must be used.

— Constant: PROT_READ
— Constant: PROT_WRITE
— Constant: PROT_EXEC
— Constant: PROT_NONE

Values for the protect argument to mmap; they must be composed with bitwise inclusive OR.

— Constant: MS_SYNC
— Constant: MS_ASYNC

Values for the flags argument to msync; they must be composed with bitwise inclusive OR.

— Constant: MREMAP_MAYMOVE

Value for the flags argument to mremap.

Previous: fd constants mmap, Up: fd constants

3.2.7 Waiting for file descriptor events

All the following bindings are exported by the (posix sizeof) library. Waiting for Input and Output.

— Constant: FD_SETSIZE

Maximum number of file descriptors that a fd_set can hold informations about. It is meant to be used as max-fd argument to select.

— Constant: sizeof-fdset
— Constant: alignof-fdset
— Constant: strideof-fdset

Size, structure alignment and array stride of data structures of type fd_set.

Next: fd open close, Previous: fd constants, Up: fd

3.3 Enumeration sets

  • fd enumerations perms: Access permissions.
  • fd enumerations open: Open modes.
  • fd enumerations pipe2: Flags for pipe2.

Next: fd enumerations open, Up: fd enumerations

3.3.1 Access permissions

— Enumeration Type: enum-access-permissions

Enumeration type used to specify file access permissions. It contains the following symbols: 

          user-read   user-write   user-exec
          group-read  group-write  group-exec
          other-read  other-write  other-exec
          setuid      setgid       sticky
— Syntax: access-permissions <symbol> ...

Expand to an enumeration set of type enum-access-permissions holding the given <symbol> symbols.

— Function: access-permissions->value set
— Function: value->access-permissions integer

Convert to and from enumeration sets of type enum-access-permissions and exact integer values being an inclusive OR combination of the following constant values: 

          S_IRUSR  S_IWUSR  S_IXUSR
          S_IRGRP  S_IWGRP  S_IXGRP
          S_IROTH  S_IWOTH  S_IXOTH
          S_ISUID  S_ISGID  S_ISVTX

Next: fd enumerations pipe2, Previous: fd enumerations perms, Up: fd enumerations

3.3.2 Open modes

— Enumeration Type: enum-open-mode

Enumeration type used to specify file open mode. It contains the following symbols: 

          accmode   append     async
          creat     excl       exec
          exlock    fsync      ignore_ctty
          ndelay    noatime    noctty
          nolink    nonblock   notrans
          rdonly    rdwr       read
          shlock    sync       trunc
          write     wronly
          
          ;; Linux specific
          direct    directory  largefile
          nofollow
— Syntax: open-mode <symbol> ...

Expand to an enumeration set of type enum-open-mode holding the given <symbol> symbols.

— Function: open-mode->value set
— Function: value->open-mode integer

Convert to and from enumeration sets of type enum-open-mode and exact integer values being an inclusive OR combination of the following constant values: 

          O_ACCMODE   O_APPEND     O_ASYNC
          O_CREAT     O_EXCL       O_EXEC
          O_EXLOCK    O_FSYNC      O_IGNORE_CTTY
          O_NDELAY    O_NOATIME    O_NOCTTY
          O_NOLINK    O_NONBLOCK   O_NOTRANS
          O_RDONLY    O_RDWR       O_READ
          O_SHLOCK    O_SYNC       O_TRUNC
          O_WRITE     O_WRONLY
          
          ;; Linux specific
          O_DIRECT    O_DIRECTORY  O_LARGEFILE
          O_NOFOLLOW

Previous: fd enumerations open, Up: fd enumerations

3.3.3 Flags for pipe2

— Enumeration Type: enum-pipe2-flags

Enumeration type used to specify flags for pipe2. It contains the following symbols: 

          nonblock  cloexec
— Syntax: pipe2-flags <symbol> ...

Expand to an enumeration set of type enum-pipe2-flags holding the given <symbol> symbols.

— Function: pipe2-flags->value set
— Function: value->pipe2-flags integer

Convert to and from enumeration sets of type enum-pipe2-flags and exact integer values being an inclusive OR combination of the following constant values: 

          O_NONBLOCK  O_CLOEXEC

Next: fd read write, Previous: fd enumerations, Up: fd

3.4 Opening and closing

The following functions manage opening and closing file descriptors. Opening and Closing Files.

Example using compensations: 

     (letrec
         ((fd (compensate
                  (open "/tmp/marco/name.ext"
                        (bitwise-ior O_CREAT O_EXCL O_WRONLY)
                        #o640)
                (with
                 (close fd)))))
       ---)

with symbolic permissions bits (more portable): 

     (letrec
         ((fd (compensate
                  (open "/tmp/marco/name.ext"
                        (bitwise-ior O_CREAT O_EXCL O_WRONLY)
                        (bitwise-ior S_IRUSR S_IWUSR S_IRGRP)))
                (with
                 (close fd))))
       ---)

using enumeration sets: 

     (letrec
         ((fd (compensate
                  (open "/tmp/marco/name.ext"
                        (open-mode creat excl wronly)
                        (access-permissions user-read user-write
                                            group-read)))
                (with
                 (close fd))))
       ---)

mode user perms group perms other perms
#o640 rw- r-- ---
#o400 r-- --- ---
#o644 rw- r-- r--
#o755 rwx r-x r-x

Table: Octal number examples of the most common values, where: r stands for readable, w for writable, x for executable.

digit mode digit mode
0 --- 4 r--
1 --x 5 r-x
2 -w- 6 rw-
3 -wx 7 rwx

Table: The octal digits.

— Function: open pathname mode permissions
— Parameter: open-function
— Function: primitive:open pathname mode permissions
— Function: platform:open pathname-cstr mode permissions

Open with mode the file selected by pathname and return a file descriptor object; if the file is created, it is created with access permissions.

pathname must be a Scheme string or symbol.

mode must be an exact integer or an enumeration set of type enum-open-mode; when it is an integer, it can be built with bitwise-ior from the following constants: one among O_RDWR, O_RDONLY and O_WRONLY and optionally O_TRUNC, O_EXCL, O_NONBLOCK.

permissions must be an exact integer or an enumeration set of type enum-access-permissions; when it is an integer, it is better given as an octal number or a bitwise combination of constants (see fd constants perms). It can be zero if we are not interested in creating a new file.

— Function: close fd
— Parameter: close-function
— Function: primitive:close fd
— Function: platform:close fd-int

Close the file descriptor fd.

Next: fd seek, Previous: fd open close, Up: fd

3.5 Reading and writing

The following functions manage reading and writing with file descriptors. Input and Output Primitives

The bindings read and write defined below have the same names of the read and write defined by R6RS. So when importing the (posix fd ---) libraries, we have to make use of some augmented import specification. For example the following avoids importing the R6RS procedures: 

     (import (except (rnrs) read write)
       (posix fd))

and the following prefixes with ‘posix:’ all the bindings from (posix fd): 

     (import (rnrs)
       (prefix (posix fd) posix:))
Reading
— Function: read fd pointer number-of-bytes
— Parameter: read-function
— Function: primitive:read fd pointer number-of-bytes
— Function: platform:read fd-int pointer number-of-bytes

Read at most number-of-bytes from fd, starting at the current file position, and store them in the buffer referenced by pointer. The file position is advanced. Return the number of bytes actually read.

— Function: pread fd pointer number-of-bytes offset
— Parameter: pread-function
— Function: primitive:pread fd pointer number-of-bytes offset
— Function: platform:pread fd-int pointer number-of-bytes offset

Read at most number-of-bytes from fd, starting at offset from the beginning of the file, and store them in the buffer referenced by pointer. The file position is left untouched. Return the number of bytes actually read.

Writing
— Function: write fd pointer number-of-bytes
— Parameter: write-function
— Function: primitive:write fd pointer number-of-bytes
— Function: platform:write fd-int pointer number-of-bytes

Write to fd, starting at the current file position, at most number-of-bytes from the buffer referenced by pointer. The file position is advanced. Return the number of bytes actually written.

— Function: pwrite fd pointer number-of-bytes offset
— Parameter: pwrite-function
— Function: primitive:pwrite fd pointer number-of-bytes offset
— Function: platform:pwrite fd-int pointer number-of-bytes offset

Write to fd, starting at offset from the beginning of the file, at most number-of-bytes from the buffer referenced by pointer. The file position is left untouched. Return the number of bytes actually written.

Next: fd sync, Previous: fd read write, Up: fd

3.6 Setting the file position

The following functions manage adjusting the current position with file descriptors. Setting the File Position of a Descriptor.

— Function: lseek fd offset whence
— Parameter: lseek-function
— Function: primitive:lseek fd offset whence
— Function: platform:lseek fd-int offset whence

Move the file position of fd at offset from the position selected with whence, which must be a value among SEEK_SET, SEEK_CUR, SEEK_END (see fd constants seek). Return the number of bytes from the beginning of the file to the selected file position.

NOTE It seems that lseek() cannot be interrupted by EINTR.

We can use the return value to acquire the current file position with: 

     (lseek fd 0 SEEK_CUR)

which will leave the file position unchanged. We can determine the file size with: 

     (define (file-size-from-descriptor fd)
       (with-compensations
         (letrec ((pos (compensate
                           (lseek fd 0 SEEK_CUR)
                         (with
                          (lseek fd pos SEEK_SET)))))
            (lseek fd 0 SEEK_END))))

Next: fd control, Previous: fd seek, Up: fd

3.7 Synchronisation

The following functions manage synchronisation between the state of a file descriptor and the underlying device. Synchronizing I/O.

— Function: sync
— Parameter: sync-function
— Function: primitive:sync
— Function: platform:sync

Synchronise data for all the file descriptors with the underlying devices. Does not return until the operation is terminated.

— Function: fsync fd
— Parameter: fsync-function
— Function: primitive:fsync fd
— Function: platform:fsync fd-int

Synchronise data for fd with the underlying device.

— Function: fdatasync fd
— Parameter: fdatasync-function
— Function: primitive:fdatasync fd
— Function: platform:fdatasync fd-int

Flushes the output buffer of fd to the underlying device. This function does not synchronise the file meta data (like the access time).

Next: fd dup, Previous: fd sync, Up: fd

3.8 Control operations

The following functions manage miscellaneous control operations on a file descriptor. Control Operations on Files. I/O Control Operations.

— Function: fcntl fd operation arg
— Parameter: fcntl-function
— Function: primitive:fcntl fd operation arg
— Function: platform:fcntl fd-int operation arg-int
— Function: platform:fcntl/ptr fd-int operation arg-ptr

Perform operation on fd using arg. operation must be an exact integer; arg can be an exact integer, a pointer object or a struct-flock object. fd constants control for the list of the supported operations.

primitive:fcntl assumes that: if the return value of platform:fcntl or platform:fcntl/ptr is -1, an error occurred.

If arg has to be a pointer (like when requesting a lock on the file), we must use platform:fcntl/ptr; if it has to be an exact integer, we must use platform:fcntl. primitive:fcntl dispatches correctly by examining the type of arg.

— Function: ioctl fd operation arg
— Parameter: ioctl-function
— Function: primitive:ioctl fd operation arg
— Function: platform:ioctl fd-int operation arg

Perform operation on fd using arg. operation and arg must be exact integers. fd constants control for the list of the supported operations.

primitive:ioctl assumes that: if the return value of platform:ioctl is -1, an error occurred.

Next: fd lock, Previous: fd control, Up: fd

3.9 Duplicating file descriptors

The following functions manage duplication of file descriptors. Duplicating Descriptors.

— Function: dup fd
— Parameter: dup-function
— Function: primitive:dup fd
— Function: platform:dup fd-int

Duplicate fd, return the new file descriptor object.

— Function: dup2 old-fd new-fd/int
— Parameter: dup2-function
— Function: primitive:dup2 old-fd new-fd/int
— Function: platform:dup2 old-fd-int new-fd-int

Copy old-fd, a file descriptor object, to a file descriptor whose number is new-fd/int, which can be a file descriptor object or an exact integer. Return the new file descriptor object.

Next: fd pipe, Previous: fd dup, Up: fd

3.10 File locks

Locking is performed by fcntl with the F_GETLK, F_SETLK and F_SETLKW operations. When locking, the third argument to fcntl must be a pointer to a structure of type struct flock or a struct-flock object. File Locks.

Usage example: 

     (with-compensations
       (let ((fd     ---)
             (lock   (make-struct-flock malloc-block/c)))
         (with-fields* (((type whence start len) struct-flock* lock))
           (set! lock.type   F_WRLCK)
           (set! lock.whence SEEK_SET)
           (set! lock.start  0)
           (set! lock.len    10))
     
         (compensate
             (fcntl fd F_SETLK lock)
           (with
            (fcntl fd F_UNLCK lock)))
         ---))
