Next: fd scatter, Previous: fd lock, Up: fd

3.11 Pipes and FIFOs

The following functions manage creation of pipes and FIFOs. Creating a Pipe. FIFO Special Files.

This is a meaningless example of FIFO usage; we have to remember that the binding forms in a let have no guaranteed evaluation order, so if we need to open the two ports in a specified order we have to use let*: 

     (with-compensations
         (compensate
             (mkfifo pathname #o600)
           (with
            (delete-file pathname)))
       (let* ((in (open pathname
                        (bitwise-ior O_NONBLOCK O_RDONLY)
                        0))
              (ou (open pathname O_WRONLY 0)))
         (letrec ((inp (compensate
                           (fd->textual-input-port  in)
                         (with
                          (close-port inp))))
                  (oup (compensate
                           (fd->textual-output-port ou)
                         (with
                          (close-port oup)))))
           (put-string oup "ciao\n")
           (flush-output-port oup)
           (get-string-n inp 5))))
— Function: pipe
— Parameter: pipe-function
— Function: primitive:pipe
— Function: platform:pipe pointer

Open a pipe: a pair of file descriptors linked together. Return two values: the first is the reading file descriptor, the second is the writing file descriptor.

— Function: mkfifo pathname mode
— Parameter: mkfifo-function
— Function: primitive:mkfifo mkfifo pathname mode
— Function: platform:mkfifo pathname-cstr mode

Create a named pipe pseudofile: a special file that can be used for interprocess communication. The Scheme string or symbol pathname selects the file pathname. mode is a numeric access permissions mode like the one used by open.

Linux–specific extensions

The following functions are exported by the libraries: 

     (linux fd)
     (linux fd primitives)
     (linux fd platform)
— Function: pipe2 flags
— Parameter: pipe2-function
— Function: primitive:pipe2 flags
— Function: platform:pipe2 fd-ptr flags

Like pipe but accepts configuration flags. flags can be an exact integer or an enumeration set of type pipe2-flags; in the integer case it can be an inclusive OR combination of the following constants: 

          O_CLOEXEC  O_NONBLOCK

Next: fd mmap, Previous: fd pipe, Up: fd

3.12 Scatter/gather input/output

The following functions manage reading/writing from/to file descriptors using an array of data buffers. Fast Scatter–Gather I/O.

— Function: readv fd iovec-array-pointer iovec-array-size
— Parameter: readv-function
— Function: primitive:readv fd iovec-array-pointer iovec-array-size
— Function: platform:readv fd-int iovec-array-pointer iovec-array-size

Read data from fd storing it in the buffers described by the iovec array. Return the total number of bytes read.

— Function: writev fd iovec-array-pointer iovec-array-size
— Parameter: writev-function
— Function: primitive:writev fd iovec-array-pointer iovec-array-size
— Function: platform:writev fd-int iovec-array-pointer iovec-array-size

Write data to fd reading it from the buffers described by the iovec array. Return the total number of bytes written.

The following bindings are exported by the library (posix sizeof).

— Constant: sizeof-iovec
— Constant: alignof-iovec
— Constant: strideof-iovec

Size, structure structure alignment and array stride of data structures of type struct iovec.

— Syntax: sizeof-iovec-array number-of-elements

Expands to the size of an array holding number-of-elements data structures of type struct iovec.

— Syntax: array-ref-c-iovec pointer index

Expands to a pointer to the first byte of the element at index in the array of struct iovec referenced by pointer.

— Syntax: struct-iovec-iov_base-ref pointer
— Syntax: struct-iovec-iov_base-set! pointer value
— Syntax: struct-iovec-iov_len-ref pointer
— Syntax: struct-iovec-iov_len-set! pointer value

Accessors and mutators for the fields of struct iovec.

Usage example, writing strings: 

     (with-compensations
       (letrec ((fd (compensate
                        (open pathname
                              (bitwise-ior O_CREAT O_RDWR)
                              (bitwise-ior S_IRUSR S_IWUSR))
                      (with
                       (close fd)))))
         (let* ((iovec-count 3)
                (iovec**     (malloc-block/c
                               (sizeof-iovec-array iovec-count))))
           (let loop ((i     0)
                      (ell   '("ciao" "salut" "hello")))
             (unless (= i iovec-count)
               (let ((iovec* (array-ref-c-iovec iovec** i))
                     (cstr   (string->cstring/c (car ell))))
                 (struct-iovec-iov_base-set! iovec* cstr)
                 (struct-iovec-iov_len-set!  iovec* (strlen cstr)))
               (loop (+ 1 i) (cdr ell))))
     
           (writev fd iovec** iovec-count))))

Next: fd select, Previous: fd scatter, Up: fd

3.13 Memory mapped input/output

The following functions manage input/output through a file mapped to a region of memory. Memory–mapped I/O.

— Function: mmap address length protect flags fd offset
— Parameter: mmap-function
— Function: primitive:mmap address length protect flags fd offset
— Function: platform:mmap address length protect flags fd-int offset

Create a memory mapping for fd, starting at file position offset, for length bytes starting at address (which can be pointer-null). Return the effective address of the mapping, which may be different from address.

Beware that address and offset must be page aligned or an EINVAL error will be raised; see the original documentation.

The flags and protect arguments must be exact integers composed with bitwise inclusive OR from appropriate constant values. Memory mapped files.

— Function: munmap pointer length
— Parameter: munmap-function
— Function: primitive:munmap pointer length
— Function: platform:munmap pointer length

Unmap a previously created memory mapping.

— Function: msync pointer length flags
— Parameter: msync-function
— Function: primitive:msync pointer length flags
— Function: platform:msync pointer length flags

Synchronise a memory mapped region with the corresponding file on the underlying device.

The flags argument must be an exact integer composed with bitwise inclusive OR from appropriate constant values. Memory mapped files.

— Function: mremap pointer length new-length flags
— Parameter: mremap-function
— Function: primitive:mremap pointer length new-length flags
— Function: platform:mremap pointer length new-length flags

Change the size of an existing memory mapping.

The flags argument must be an exact integer composed with bitwise inclusive OR from appropriate constant values. Memory mapped files.

Usage example: 

     (letrec* ((fd         (compensate
                               (open pathname
                                     (bitwise-ior O_CREAT O_RDWR)
                                     (bitwise-ior S_IRUSR S_IWUSR))
                             (with
                              (close fd))))
               (map-len    4096)
               (address    (compensate
                               (mmap pointer-null map-len
                                     (bitwise-ior PROT_READ PROT_WRITE)
                                     MAP_SHARED fd 0)
                             (with
                              (munmap address map-len)))))
     
       (pointer-ref-c-signed-char address 10))

Next: fd custom, Previous: fd mmap, Up: fd

3.14 Waiting for input or output

The following functions manage waiting for input and outut on file descriptors. Waiting for Input and Output.

In the following descriptions the fdset arguments are fdset objects. File descriptor related data types.

— Function: select max-fd read-fdset write-fdset except-fdset timeout
— Parameter: select-function
— Function: primitive:select max-fd read-fdset write-fdset except-fdset timeout
— Function: platform:select max-fd read-fdset write-fdset except-fdset timeout

Wait for an event on the file descriptors in the sets referenced by the fdset arguments. timeout must be a struct-timeval object.

NOTE This function can be interrupted and return with errno set to EINTR; the library does not automatically reinvoke it, rather it raises an error with raise-errno-error.

— Function: FD_ZERO fdset
— Function: primitive:FD_ZERO fdset
— Function: platform:FD_ZERO fdset

Initialises the file descriptor set referenced by fdset. The return value is undefined, platform function included.

— Function: FD_SET fd fdset
— Function: primitive:FD_SET fd fdset
— Function: platform:FD_SET fd fdset

Add fd to the file descriptor set referenced by fdset. The return value is undefined, platform function included.

— Function: FD_CLR fd fdset
— Function: primitive:FD_CLR fd fdset
— Function: platform:FD_CLR fd fdset

Remove fd from the file descriptor set referenced by fdset. The return value is undefined, platform function included.

— Function: FD_ISSET fd fdset
— Function: primitive:FD_ISSET fd fdset
— Function: platform:FD_ISSET fd fdset

Return true if fd is a member of the file descriptor set referenced by fdset. platform:FD_ISSET returns a single value, an integer with C language true/false meaning.

Usage example: 

     (import (except (rnrs) read write)
       (records)
       (compensations)
       (foreign memory)
       (posix fd)
       (posix sizeof)
       (for (posix typedefs) expand run)
       (for (posix extensions) expand))
     
     (with-compensations
       (let ((fd        ---)
             (rd-fdset  (make-fdset malloc-block/c))
             (wr-fdset  (make-fdset malloc-block/c))
             (ex-fdset  (make-fdset malloc-block/c))
             (timeout   (make-struct-timeval malloc-block/c)))
     
         (with-fields* (((sec usec) struct-timeval* timeout))
           (set! timeout.sec  1)
           (set! timeout.usec 0))
     
         (FD_ZERO rd-fdset)
         (FD_ZERO wr-fdset)
         (FD_ZERO ex-fdset)
     
         (FD_SET fd rd-fdset)
     
         (select FD_SETSIZE rd-fdset wr-fdset ex-fdset timeout)
         (when (FD_ISSET fd rd-fdset)
           ---)))

Previous: fd select, Up: fd

3.15 Custom Scheme ports

The following bindings are exported by the (posix fd) library.

— Function: fd->binary-input-port fd
— Function: fd->binary-output-port fd
— Function: fd->binary-input/output-port fd
— Function: fd->textual-input-port fd
— Function: fd->textual-output-port fd
— Function: fd->textual-input/output-port fd

Wrap the given file descriptor with a Scheme port; return the port. Closing the Scheme port closes the file descriptor too.

— Function: pipe-binary-ports
— Function: pipe-textual-ports

Invoke pipe then wrap the file descriptors with Scheme ports. Return 2 values: the reading port and the writing port.

Position handling (seeking) is not implemented for pipe ports.

Everyone should mind his own buffers

Unfortunately there are Scheme implementations that insist in implementing buffering for custom ports. One can say that they are called “custom” to let the customers (that is us) decide how to handle the underlying device, buffering included. This is not the opinion of some Scheme implementers.

So with some implementations we have to turn off buffering and turn on non-blocking mode for the device.

Do it yourself

If we feel the need to implement our own wrappers, we may find useful to know that a custom read function can be implemented like this: 

     (define (custom-binary-read fd bv start count)
       (with-compensations
         (let* ((p   (malloc-block/c count))
                (len (read fd p count)))
           (do ((i 0 (+ 1 i)))
               ((= i len)
                len)
             (bytevector-u8-set! bv (+ start i)
                                 (peek-unsigned-char p i))))))
     
     (define (custom-textual-read fd str start count)
       (with-compensations
         (let* ((p   (malloc-block/c count))
                (len (read fd p count)))
           (do ((i 0 (+ 1 i)))
               ((= i len)
                len)
             (string-set! str (+ start i)
                          (integer->char (peek-unsigned-char p i)))))))

and a custom write function can be implemented like this: 

     (define (custom-binary-write fd bv start count)
       (with-compensations
         (let ((p (malloc-block/c count)))
           (do ((i 0 (+ 1 i)))
               ((= i count)
                (write fd p count))
             (poke-char! p i (bytevector-u8-ref bv (+ start i)))))))
     
     (define (custom-textual-write fd str start count)
       (with-compensations
         (let ((p (malloc-block/c count)))
           (do ((i 0 (+ 1 i)))
               ((= i count)
                (write fd p count))
             (poke-char! p i
                (char->integer (string-ref str (+ start i))))))))

Then the following implementations are possible: 

     (define (fd->binary-input-port fd)
       (make-custom-binary-input-port
        "fd input port"
        (lambda (bv start count)
          (custom-binary-read fd bv start count))
        (lambda ()
          (lseek fd 0 SEEK_CUR))
        (lambda (pos)
          (lseek fd pos SEEK_SET))
        (lambda ()
          (close fd))))
     
     (define (fd->binary-output-port fd)
       (make-custom-binary-output-port
        "fd output port"
        (lambda (bv start count)
          (custom-binary-write fd bv start count))
        (lambda ()
          (lseek fd 0 SEEK_CUR))
        (lambda (pos)
          (lseek fd pos SEEK_SET))
        (lambda ()
          (close fd))))
     
     (define (fd->binary-input/ouput-port fd)
       (make-custom-binary-input-port
        "fd input/output port"
        (lambda (bv start count)
          (custom-binary-read fd bv start count))
        (lambda (bv start count)
          (custom-binary-write fd bv start count))
        (lambda ()
          (lseek fd 0 SEEK_CUR))
        (lambda (pos)
          (lseek fd pos SEEK_SET))
        (lambda ()
          (close fd))))
     
     (define (fd->textual-input-port fd)
       (make-custom-textual-input-port
        "fd input port"
        (lambda (str start count)
          (custom-textual-read fd str start count))
        (lambda ()
          (lseek fd 0 SEEK_CUR))
        (lambda (pos)
          (lseek fd pos SEEK_SET))
        (lambda ()
          (close fd))))
     
     (define (fd->textual-output-port fd)
       (make-custom-textual-output-port
        "fd output port"
        (lambda (str start count)
          (custom-textual-write fd str start count))
        (lambda ()
          (lseek fd 0 SEEK_CUR))
        (lambda (pos)
          (lseek fd pos SEEK_SET))
        (lambda ()
          (close fd))))
     
     (define (fd->textual-input/ouput-port fd)
       (make-custom-textual-input-port
        "fd input/output port"
        (lambda (str start count)
          (custom-textual-read fd str start count))
        (lambda (str start count)
          (custom-textual-write fd str start count))
        (lambda ()
          (lseek fd 0 SEEK_CUR))
        (lambda (pos)
          (lseek fd pos SEEK_SET))
        (lambda ()
          (close fd))))
     
     (define (pipe-binary-ports)
       (let-values (((in ou) (pipe)))
         (values (make-custom-binary-input-port
                  "fd pipe binary reading port"
                  (lambda (bv start count)
                    (custom-binary-read in bv start count))
                  #f
                  #f
                  (lambda ()
                    (close in)))
                 (make-custom-binary-output-port
                  "fd pipe binary writing port"
                  (lambda (bv start count)
                    (custom-binary-write ou bv start count))
                  #f
                  #f
                  (lambda ()
                    (close ou))))))
     
     (define (pipe-textual-ports)
       (let-values (((in ou) (pipe)))
         (values (make-custom-textual-input-port
                  "fd pipe textual reading port"
                  (lambda (bv start count)
                    (custom-textual-read in bv start count))
                  #f
                  #f
                  (lambda ()
                    (close in)))
                 (make-custom-textual-output-port
                  "fd pipe textual writing port"
                  (lambda (bv start count)
                    (custom-textual-write ou bv start count))
                  #f
                  #f
                  (lambda ()
                    (close ou))))))

Next: streams, Previous: fd, Up: Top

4 Sockets

Unless otherwise specified, the functions documented in this chapter are exported by the following libraries: 

     (posix sockets)
     (posix sockets primitives)
     (posix sockets platform)
  • sockets intro: Introduction.
  • sockets constants: Constant values.
  • sockets enumerations: Enumeration type definitions.
  • sockets structs: Accessing data structures.
  • sockets records: Record types mirroring data structures.
  • sockets ifaces: Network interfaces.
  • sockets inet: Internet addresses.
  • sockets open close: Opening and closing sockets.
  • sockets connect: Connection operations on sockets.
  • sockets address: Network addresses.
  • sockets send: Sending data through stream sockets.
  • sockets recv: Receiving data from through stream sockets.
  • sockets sendto: Sending data through datagram sockets.
  • sockets recvfrom: Receiving data from through datagram sockets.
  • sockets options: Configuring sockets behaviour.
  • sockets examples: Client and server examples.

Next: sockets constants, Up: sockets

4.1 Introduction

Sockets programming is a bit complex task, so we want to read documentation to learn how to do it. First there is the GNU C Library chapter on sockets (Sockets), then there are the Unix/Linux manual pages. Each function documented in this chapter has a manual page we may want to read; additionally the following manual pages, available on Linux systems, report useful informations:

socket(7)
unix(7)
Details about the sockets for local interprocess communications; these are the sockets with namespace AF_LOCAL.
raw(7)
packet(7)
capabilities(7)
credentials(7)
ip(7)

Next: sockets enumerations, Previous: sockets intro, Up: sockets

4.2 Constant values

Unless otherwise specified, the following bindings are exported by the (posix sizeof) library.

— Constant: SOCK_STREAM
— Constant: SOCK_DGRAM
— Constant: SOCK_RAW
— Constant: SOCK_RDM

Communication styles.

— Constant: IPPORT_RESERVED
— Constant: IPPORT_USERRESERVED

Port number limits reserved for superuser or explicit allocation. Ports.

— Constant: SHUT_RD
— Constant: SHUT_WR
— Constant: SHUT_RDWR

Values for the how argument to shutdown().

— Constant: IFNAMSIZ

Maximum buffer size needed to hold an interface name, including the terminating zero byte. Interface Naming.

— Constant: AF_LOCAL
— Constant: PF_LOCAL
— Constant: AF_UNIX
— Constant: PF_UNIX
— Constant: AF_FILE
— Constant: PF_FILE
— Constant: AF_INET
— Constant: PF_INET
— Constant: AF_INET6
— Constant: PF_INET6
— Constant: AF_UNSPEC
— Constant: PF_UNSPEC

Address formats.

— Constant: MSG_OOB
— Constant: MSG_PEEK
— Constant: MSG_ONROUTE

Flag values for the flags argument to send and recv.

— Constant: SOL_SOCKET
— Constant: SO_DEBUG
— Constant: SO_REUSEADDR
— Constant: SO_KEEPALIVE
— Constant: SO_DONTROUTE
— Constant: SO_LINGER
— Constant: SO_BROADCAST
— Constant: SO_OOBINLINE
— Constant: SO_SNDBUF
— Constant: SO_RCVBUF
— Constant: SO_STYLE
— Constant: SO_TYPE
— Constant: SO_ERROR

Constants for socket options and the getsockopt and setsockopt functions.

— Constant: INADDR_LOOPBACK
— Constant: INADDR_ANY
— Constant: INADDR_BROADCAST
— Constant: INADDR_NONE

Predefined Internet IPv4 addresses.

— Constant: INET_ADDRSTRLEN
— Constant: INET6_ADDRSTRLEN

Maximum length of strings required to hold Internet addresses in presentation format.

Next: sockets structs, Previous: sockets constants, Up: sockets

4.3 Enumeration type definitions

Unless otherwise specified, the following bindings are exported by the (posix typedefs) library.

  • sockets enumerations namespace: Socket namespace.
  • sockets enumerations style: Socket styles.
  • sockets enumerations addrfrm: Socket address formats.
  • sockets enumerations shutdown: Socket shutdown modes.
  • sockets enumerations dataopts: Socket data options.
  • sockets enumerations options: Socket options.

Next: sockets enumerations style, Up: sockets enumerations

4.3.1 Socket namespaces

— Enumeration Type: enum-socket-namespace

Enumeration type for the symbols representing socket communication namespaces; it has the following members: 

          local  unix   file
          inet   inet6  unspec

local, unix and file are synonyms.

— Syntax: socket-namespace <symbol>

Expand to an enumeration set of type enum-socket-namespace holding the given symbol argument.

— Function: socket-namespace->value set
— Function: value->socket-namespace value

Convert to and from an enumeration set of type enum-socket-namespace holding a single element and the corresponding exact integer value, one among: 

          PF_LOCAL  PF_UNIX   PF_FILE
          PF_INET   PF_INET6  PF_UNSPEC

PF_LOCAL, PF_UNIX and PF_FILE are synonyms.

— Function: socket-namespace->socklen set

Given an enumeration set of type enum-socket-namespace holding a single element, return the size in bytes of the C language structure required to hold an address of the selected namespace.

The size may not be significant, see the original documentation.

Next: sockets enumerations addrfrm, Previous: sockets enumerations namespace, Up: sockets enumerations

4.3.2 Socket styles

— Enumeration Type: enum-socket-style

Enumeration type for the symbols representing socket communication styles; it has the following members: 

          stream  datagram  raw  seqpacket
— Syntax: socket-style <symbol>

Expand to an enumeration set of type enum-socket-style holding the given symbol argument.

— Function: socket-style->value set
— Function: value->socket-style value

Convert to and from an enumeration set of type enum-socket-style holding a single element and the corresponding exact integer value, one among: 

          SOCK_STREAM  SOCK_DGRAM  SOCK_RAW  SOCK_SEQPACKET

Next: sockets enumerations shutdown, Previous: sockets enumerations style, Up: sockets enumerations

4.3.3 Socket address formats

— Enumeration Type: enum-socket-address-format

Enumeration type for the symbols representing socket address formats; it has the following members: 

          local  unix   file
          inet   inet6  unspec
— Syntax: socket-address-format <symbol>

Expand to an enumeration set of type enum-socket-address-format holding the given symbol argument.

— Function: socket-address-format->value set
— Function: value->socket-address-format value

Convert to and from an enumeration set of type enum-socket-address-format holding a single element and the corresponding exact integer value, one among: 

          AF_LOCAL  AF_UNIX   AF_FILE
          AF_INET   AF_INET6  AF_UNSPEC

Next: sockets enumerations dataopts, Previous: sockets enumerations addrfrm, Up: sockets enumerations

4.3.4 Socket shutdown modes

— Enumeration Type: enum-shutdown-mode

Enumeration type for the symbols representing socket shutdown modes; it has the following members: 

          read    write   both
— Syntax: shutdown-mode <symbol>

Expand to an enumeration set of type enum-shutdown-mode holding the given symbol argument.

— Function: socket-shutdown-mode->value set
— Function: value->socket-shutdown-mode value

Convert to and from an enumeration set of type enum-shutdown-mode holding a single element and the corresponding exact integer value, one among: 

          SHUT_RD  SHUT_WR  SHUT_RDWR

Next: sockets enumerations options, Previous: sockets enumerations shutdown, Up: sockets enumerations

4.3.5 Socket data options

— Enumeration Type: enum-socket-data-options

Enumeration type for the symbols representing socket data options; it has the following members: 

          oob  peek  dontroute
— Syntax: socket-data-options <symbol> ...

Expand to an enumeration set of type enum-socket-data-options holding the given argument symbols.

— Function: socket-data-options->value set
— Function: value->socket-data-options value

Convert to and from an enumeration set of type enum-socket-data-options and the corresponding exact integer value representing a inclusive bitwise OR combination of the following constants: 

          MSG_OOB  MSG_PEEK  MSG_DONTROUTE

Previous: sockets enumerations dataopts, Up: sockets enumerations

4.3.6 Socket options

— Enumeration Type: enum-socket-option

Enumeration type for the symbols representing socket options; it has the following members: 

          debug           reuseaddr
          keepalive       dontroute
          linger          broadcast
          oobinline       sndbuf
          rcvbuf          style
          type            error

type and style are synonyms.

— Syntax: socket-option <symbol>

Expand to an enumeration set of type enum-socket-option holding the given symbol argument.

— Function: socket-option->value set
— Function: value->socket-option value

Convert to and from an enumeration set of type enum-socket-option holding a single element and the corresponding exact integer value, one among: 

          SO_DEBUG        SO_REUSEADDR
          SO_KEEPALIVE    SO_DONTROUTE
          SO_LINGER       SO_BROADCAST
          SO_OOBINLINE    SO_SNDBUF
          SO_RCVBUF       SO_STYLE
          SO_TYPE         SO_ERROR

SO_TYPE and SO_STYLE are synonyms.

— Function: socket-option->symbol set

Convert an enumeration set of type enum-socket-option holding a single element to the element itself.

Next: sockets records, Previous: sockets enumerations, Up: sockets

4.4 Accessing data structures

Unless otherwise specified, the following bindings are exported by the (posix sizeof) library.

  • sockets structs sockaddr: Structure sockaddr.
  • sockets structs sockaddr_un: Structure sockaddr_un.
  • sockets structs sockaddr_in: Structure sockaddr_in.
  • sockets structs sockaddr_in6: Structure sockaddr_in6.
  • sockets structs in_addr: Structure in_addr.
  • sockets structs in6_addr: Structure in6_addr.
  • sockets structs if_nameindex: Structure if_nameindex.
  • sockets structs hostent: Structure hostent.
  • sockets structs netent: Structure netent.
  • sockets structs protoent: Structure protoent.
  • sockets structs servent: Structure servent.

Next: sockets structs sockaddr_un, Up: sockets structs

4.4.1 Structure sockaddr

The struct sockaddr type is used only as “mask”, to access the address format field of structures of type struct sockaddr_un, struct sockaddr_in and struct sockaddr_in6; it is not meant to be instantiated by the client code. Address Formats.

— Constant: sizeof-sockaddr
— Constant: alignof-sockaddr
— Constant: strideof-sockaddr

Size, structure alignment and array stride of struct sockaddr C language data structures.

— Syntax: struct-sockaddr-sa_family-ref pointer
— Syntax: struct-sockaddr-sa_family-set! pointer value
— Syntax: struct-sockaddr-sa_data-ref pointer

Accessors and mutators for the fields of a struct sockaddr C language data structure.

struct-sockaddr-sa_data-ref returns a pointer to the first byte of the sa_data array field, which is embedded in the structure.

Next: sockets structs sockaddr_in, Previous: sockets structs sockaddr, Up: sockets structs

4.4.2 Structure sockaddr_un

The struct sockaddr_un type describes a socket address in the PF_LOCAL namespace. Details of Local Namespace.

— Constant: sizeof-sockaddr_un
— Constant: alignof-sockaddr_un
— Constant: strideof-sockaddr_un

Size, structure alignment and array stride of struct sockaddr_un C language data structures.

— Syntax: struct-sockaddr_un-sun_family-ref pointer
— Syntax: struct-sockaddr_un-sun_family-set! pointer value
— Syntax: struct-sockaddr_un-sun_path-ref pointer
— Syntax: struct-sockaddr_un-sun_path-set! pointer value

Accessors and mutators for the fields of a struct sockaddr_un C language data structure.

Next: sockets structs sockaddr_in6, Previous: sockets structs sockaddr_un, Up: sockets structs

4.4.3 Structure sockaddr_in

The struct sockaddr_in type describes a socket address in the AF_INET namespace. Internet Socket Address Formats.

— Constant: sizeof-sockaddr_in
— Constant: alignof-sockaddr_in
— Constant: strideof-sockaddr_in

Size, structure alignment and array stride of struct sockaddr_in C language data structures.

— Syntax: struct-sockaddr_in-sin_family-ref pointer
— Syntax: struct-sockaddr_in-sin_family-set! pointer value
— Syntax: struct-sockaddr_in-sin_addr-ref pointer
— Syntax: struct-sockaddr_in-sin_port-ref pointer
— Syntax: struct-sockaddr_in-sin_port-set! pointer value

Accessors and mutators for the fields of a struct sockaddr_in C language data structure.

The sin_addr field is an embedded data structure of type struct in_addr; struct-sockaddr_in-sin_addr-ref returns a pointer to its first byte.

The sin_port field holds the port number in network byte order; we have to use the functions htons and ntohs to convert between that number and the host byte order number. For example: the port number 25 in host byte order is equal to number 6400 in network byte order.

Next: sockets structs in_addr, Previous: sockets structs sockaddr_in, Up: sockets structs

4.4.4 Structure sockaddr_in6

The struct sockaddr_in6 type describes a socket address in the AF_INET6 namespace. Internet Socket Address Formats.

— Constant: sizeof-sockaddr_in6
— Constant: alignof-sockaddr_in6
— Constant: strideof-sockaddr_in6

Size, structure alignment and array stride of struct sockaddr_in6 C language data structures.

— Syntax: struct-sockaddr_in6-sin6_family-ref pointer
— Syntax: struct-sockaddr_in6-sin6_family-set! pointer value
— Syntax: struct-sockaddr_in6-sin6_addr-ref pointer
— Syntax: struct-sockaddr_in6-sin6_port-ref pointer
— Syntax: struct-sockaddr_in6-sin6_port-set! pointer value

Accessors and mutators for the fields of a struct sockaddr_in6 C language data structure.

The sin6_addr field is an embedded data structure of type struct in6_addr; struct-sockaddr_in6-sin6_addr-ref returns a pointer to its first byte.

The sin6_port field holds the port number in network byte order; we have to use the functions htons and ntohs to convert between that number and the host byte order number. For example: the port number 25 in host byte order is equal to number 6400 in network byte order.

Next: sockets structs in6_addr, Previous: sockets structs sockaddr_in6, Up: sockets structs

4.4.5 Structure in_addr

The struct in_addr type describes an IPv4 address; it is an opaque structure which is not meant to be instantiated by the client code. Host Address Data Type.

— Constant: sizeof-in_addr
— Constant: alignof-in_addr
— Constant: strideof-in_addr

Size, structure alignment and array stride of struct in_addr C language data structures.

Next: sockets structs if_nameindex, Previous: sockets structs in_addr, Up: sockets structs

4.4.6 Structure in6_addr

The struct in6_addr type describes an IPv6 address; it is an opaque structure which is not meant to be instantiated by the client code. Host Address Data Type.

— Constant: sizeof-in6_addr
— Constant: alignof-in6_addr
— Constant: strideof-in6_addr

Size, structure alignment and array stride of struct in6_addr C language data structures.

Next: sockets structs hostent, Previous: sockets structs in6_addr, Up: sockets structs

4.4.7 Structure if_nameindex

The struct if_nameindex type describes the mapping between network interface names and indexes. Interface Naming.

— Constant: sizeof-if_nameindex
— Constant: alignof-if_nameindex
— Constant: strideof-if_nameindex

Size, structure alignment and array stride of struct if_nameindex C language data structures.

— Syntax: struct-if_nameindex-if_index-ref pointer
— Syntax: struct-if_nameindex-if_index-set! pointer value
— Syntax: struct-if_nameindex-if_name-ref pointer
— Syntax: struct-if_nameindex-if_name-set! pointer value

Accessors and mutators for the fields of a struct if_nameindex C language data structure.

Next: sockets structs netent, Previous: sockets structs if_nameindex, Up: sockets structs

4.4.8 Structure hostent

The struct hostent type describes an entry in the system's networks database. Host Names.

— Constant: sizeof-hostent
— Constant: alignof-hostent
— Constant: strideof-hostent

Size, structure alignment and array stride of struct hostent C language data structures.

— Syntax: struct-hostent-h_name-ref pointer
— Syntax: struct-hostent-h_name-set! pointer value
— Syntax: struct-hostent-h_aliases-ref pointer
— Syntax: struct-hostent-h_aliases-set! pointer value
— Syntax: struct-hostent-h_addrtype-ref pointer
— Syntax: struct-hostent-h_addrtype-set! pointer value
— Syntax: struct-hostent-h_length-ref pointer
— Syntax: struct-hostent-h_length-set! pointer value
— Syntax: struct-hostent-h_addr_list-ref pointer
— Syntax: struct-hostent-h_addr_list-set! pointer value
— Syntax: struct-hostent-h_h_addr-ref pointer
— Syntax: struct-hostent-h_h_addr-set! pointer value

Accessors and mutators for the fields of a struct hostent C language data structure.

Next: sockets structs protoent, Previous: sockets structs hostent, Up: sockets structs

4.4.9 Structure netent

The struct netent type describes an entry in the system's networks database. Networks Database.

— Constant: sizeof-netent
— Constant: alignof-netent
— Constant: strideof-netent

Size, structure alignment and array stride of struct netent C language data structures.

— Syntax: struct-netent-n_name-ref pointer
— Syntax: struct-netent-n_name-set! pointer value
— Syntax: struct-netent-n_aliases-ref pointer
— Syntax: struct-netent-n_aliases-set! pointer value
— Syntax: struct-netent-n_addrtype-ref pointer
— Syntax: struct-netent-n_addrtype-set! pointer value
— Syntax: struct-netent-n_net-ref pointer
— Syntax: struct-netent-n_net-set! pointer value

Accessors and mutators for the fields of a struct netent C language data structure.

Next: sockets structs servent, Previous: sockets structs netent, Up: sockets structs

4.4.10 Structure protoent

The struct protoent type describes an entry in the system's protocols database. Protocols Database.

— Constant: sizeof-protoent
— Constant: alignof-protoent
— Constant: strideof-protoent

Size, structure alignment and array stride of struct protoent C language data structures.

— Syntax: struct-protoent-n_name-ref pointer
— Syntax: struct-protoent-n_name-set! pointer value
— Syntax: struct-protoent-n_aliases-ref pointer
— Syntax: struct-protoent-n_aliases-set! pointer value
— Syntax: struct-protoent-n_proto-ref pointer
— Syntax: struct-protoent-n_proto-set! pointer value

Accessors and mutators for the fields of a struct protoent C language data structure.

Previous: sockets structs protoent, Up: sockets structs

4.4.11 Structure servent

The struct servent type describes an entry in the system's services database. The Services Database.

— Constant: sizeof-servent
— Constant: alignof-servent
— Constant: strideof-servent

Size, structure alignment and array stride of struct servent C language data structures.

— Syntax: struct-servent-s_name-ref pointer
— Syntax: struct-servent-s_name-set! pointer value
— Syntax: struct-servent-s_aliases-ref pointer
— Syntax: struct-servent-s_aliases-set! pointer value
— Syntax: struct-servent-s_port-ref pointer
— Syntax: struct-servent-s_port-set! pointer value
— Syntax: struct-servent-s_proto-ref pointer
— Syntax: struct-servent-s_proto-set! pointer value

Accessors and mutators for the fields of a struct servent C language data structure.

NOTE The s_port field holds the port number in network byte order; we have to use the functions htons and ntohs to convert between that number and the host byte order number. For example: the port number 25 in host byte order is equal to number 6400 in network byte order.

Next: sockets ifaces, Previous: sockets structs, Up: sockets

4.5 Record types mirroring data structures

Unless otherwise specified, the following bindings are exported by the (posix typedefs) library.

  • sockets records socket: Socket file descriptor.
  • sockets records sockaddr: Socket address.
  • sockets records sockaddr-in: Internet namespace socket address IPv4.
  • sockets records sockaddr-in6: Internet namespace socket address IPv6.
  • sockets records sockaddr-un: Local namespace socket address.
  • sockets records if-nameindex: Interface name.
  • sockets records hostent: Host database entry.
  • sockets records netent: Network database entry.
  • sockets records protoent: Protocols database entry.
  • sockets records servent: Services database entry.

Next: sockets records sockaddr, Up: sockets records

4.5.1 Socket file descriptor

— Record Type Name: <socket>
— Record Type Descriptor: <socket-rtd>

Record type used to wrap socket file descriptors; it is derived from <fd> and it adds the following immutable fields:

namespace
An enumeration set of type enum-socket-namespace holding a single element.
style
An enumeration set of type enum-socket-style holding a single element.
protocol
An integer selecting the protocol. Reading the protocols database.

— Function: make-<socket> fd namespace style protocol
— Function: <socket>? obj

Constructor and predicate for records of type <socket>. The constructor does not validate its arguments: it is not meant to be used by client code in normal operations.

— Function: <socket>-namespace sockaddr
— Function: <socket>-namespace-set! sockaddr value
— Function: <socket>-style sockaddr
— Function: <socket>-style-set! sockaddr value
— Function: <socket>-protocol sockaddr
— Function: <socket>-protocol-set! sockaddr value

Accessors and mutators for records of type <socket>.

Next: sockets records sockaddr-in, Previous: sockets records socket, Up: sockets records

4.5.2 Socket address

— Record Type Name: <sockaddr>
— Record Type Descriptor: <sockaddr-rtd>

Record type used as base for the <sockaddr-in>, <sockaddr-in6> and <sockaddr-un> types; it is not meant to be instantiated directly. It has the following immutable field:

family
An enumeration set of type enum-socket-address-format holding a single symbol.

— Function: make-<sockaddr> family
— Function: <sockaddr>? obj

Constructor and predicate for records of type <sockaddr>. The constructor is not meant to be used by client code in normal operations.

— Function: <sockaddr>-family sockaddr

Accessors for records of type <sockaddr>.

Next: sockets records sockaddr-in6, Previous: sockets records sockaddr, Up: sockets records

4.5.3 Internet namespace socket address IPv4

— Record Type Name: <sockaddr-in>
— Record Type Descriptor: <sockaddr-in-rtd>

Record type used to mirror struct sockaddr_in C language data structures; it is derived from <sockaddr>. It has the following mutable fields:

addr
A Scheme bytevector holding a struct in_addr structure.
port
An exact integer representing the port number in host byte order.

The field family, inherited from <sockaddr>, must be set to an enumeration set of type enum-socket-address-format holding the single symbol inet.

— Function: make-<sockaddr-in> addr port
— Function: <sockaddr-in>? obj

Constructor and predicate for records of type <sockaddr-in>. addr and port are the values of the addr and port fields; the family field is automatically set to an enumeration set of type enum-socket-address-format holding the single symbol inet.

— Function: <sockaddr-in>-family sockaddr-in
— Function: <sockaddr-in>-addr sockaddr-in
— Function: <sockaddr-in>-addr-set! sockaddr-in value
— Function: <sockaddr-in>-port sockaddr-in
— Function: <sockaddr-in>-port-set! sockaddr-in value

Accessors and mutators for records of type <sockaddr-in>.

— Function: primitive:pointer-><sockaddr-in> pointer

Given a pointer object to a struct sockaddr_in data structure, build and return a record of type <sockaddr-in> which mirrors it. This function takes care of converting the port number from network byte order to host byte order.

This function is exported by the (posix sockets primitives) library.

Next: sockets records sockaddr-un, Previous: sockets records sockaddr-in, Up: sockets records

4.5.4 Internet namespace socket address IPv6

— Record Type Name: <sockaddr-in6>
— Record Type Descriptor: <sockaddr-in6-rtd>

Record type used to mirror struct sockaddr_in6 C language data structures; it is derived from <sockaddr>. It has the following mutable fields:

addr
A Scheme bytevector holding a struct in6_addr structure.
port
An exact integer representing the port number in host byte order.

The field family, inherited from <sockaddr>, must be set to an enumeration set of type enum-socket-address-format holding the single symbol inet6.

— Function: make-<sockaddr-in6> addr port
— Function: <sockaddr-in6>? obj

Constructor and predicate for records of type <sockaddr-in6>. addr and port are the values of the addr and port fields; the family field is automatically set to an enumeration set of type enum-socket-address-format holding the single symbol inet.

— Function: <sockaddr-in6>-family sockaddr-in6
— Function: <sockaddr-in6>-addr sockaddr-in6
— Function: <sockaddr-in6>-addr-set! sockaddr-in6 value
— Function: <sockaddr-in6>-port sockaddr-in6
— Function: <sockaddr-in6>-port-set! sockaddr-in6 value

Accessors and mutators for records of type <sockaddr-in6>.

— Function: primitive:pointer-><sockaddr-in6> pointer

Given a pointer object to a struct sockaddr_in6 data structure, build and return a record of type <sockaddr-in6> which mirrors it. This function takes care of converting the port number from network byte order to host byte order.

This function is exported by the (posix sockets primitives) library.

Next: sockets records if-nameindex, Previous: sockets records sockaddr-in6, Up: sockets records

4.5.5 Local namespace socket address

— Record Type Name: <sockaddr-un>
— Record Type Descriptor: <sockaddr-un-rtd>

Record type used to mirror struct sockaddr_un C language data structures; it is derived from <sockaddr>. It has the following mutable fields:

pathname
A Scheme string representing the pathname of the file to use.

The field family, inherited from <sockaddr>, must be set to an enumeration set of type enum-socket-address-format holding the single symbol local.

— Function: make-<sockaddr-un> pathname
— Function: <sockaddr-un>? obj

Constructor and predicate for records of type <sockaddr-un>. pathname is the value of the path field the family field is automatically set to an enumeration set of type enum-socket-address-format holding the single symbol local.

— Function: <sockaddr-un>-family sockaddr-un
— Function: <sockaddr-un>-pathname sockaddr-un
— Function: <sockaddr-un>-pathname-set! sockaddr-un value

Accessors and mutators for records of type <sockaddr-un>.

— Function: primitive:pointer-><sockaddr-un> pointer

Given a pointer object to a struct sockaddr_un data structure, build and return a record of type <sockaddr-un> which mirrors it.

This function is exported by the (posix sockets primitives) library.

Next: sockets records hostent, Previous: sockets records sockaddr-un, Up: sockets records

4.5.6 Interface name

— Record Type Name: <if-nameindex>
— Record Type Descriptor: <if-nameindex-rtd>

Record type used to mirror struct if_nameindex C language data structures. It has the following immutable fields:

index
An exact integer representing the interface index.
name
A Scheme string representing the interface name.

— Function: make-<if-nameindex> family data
— Function: <if-nameindex>? obj

Constructor and predicate for records of type <if-nameindex>. The constructor does not validate its arguments: it is not meant to be used by client code in normal operations.

— Function: <if-nameindex>-index if-nameindex
— Function: <if-nameindex>-name if-nameindex

Accessors and mutators for records of type <if-nameindex>.

Next: sockets records netent, Previous: sockets records if-nameindex, Up: sockets records

4.5.7 Host database entry

— Record Type Name: <hostent>
— Record Type Descriptor: <hostent-rtd>

Record type used to mirror struct hostent C language data structures. It has the following immutable fields:

name
A Scheme string representing the official host name.
aliases
A list of Scheme strings representing alternative names for the host.
addrtype
An enumeration set of type enum-socket-address-format representing the type of the addresses.
addrlist
A list of Scheme bytevectors representing struct in_addr or struct in6_addr values in network byte order.

— Function: make-<hostent> name aliases addrtype addrlist
— Function: <hostent>? obj

Constructor and predicate for records of type <hostent>. The constructor does not validate its arguments: it is not meant to be used by client code in normal operations.

— Function: <hostent>-name record
— Function: <hostent>-aliases record
— Function: <hostent>-addrtype record
— Function: <hostent>-addrlist record

Accessors for records of type <hostent>.

— Function: <hostent>-addr record

Return the first element in the addrlist field value of record.

— Function: primitive:pointer-><hostent> pointer

Build and return a new record of type <hostent> representing the struct hostent value referenced by pointer. This binding is exported by the (posix sockets primitives) library.

Next: sockets records protoent, Previous: sockets records hostent, Up: sockets records

4.5.8 Network database entry

— Record Type Name: <netent>
— Record Type Descriptor: <netent-rtd>

Record type used to mirror struct netent C language data structures. It has the following immutable fields:

name
A Scheme string representing the official name of the network.
aliases
A list of Scheme strings representing the alternative names of the network.
addrtype
An enumeration set of type enum-socket-address-format representing the type of the addresses. The value in the set should be inet for Internet networks.
net
A Scheme bytevector holding the network address number in network byte order.

— Function: make-<netent> name aliases addrtype net
— Function: <netent>? obj

Constructor and predicate for records of type <netent>. The constructor does not validate its arguments.

— Function: <netent>-name netent
— Function: <netent>-aliases netent
— Function: <netent>-addrtype netent
— Function: <netent>-net netent

Accessors for records of type <netent>.

— Function: primitive:pointer-><netent> pointer

Build and return a new record of type <netent> representing the struct netent value referenced by pointer. This binding is exported by the (posix sockets primitives) library.

Next: sockets records servent, Previous: sockets records netent, Up: sockets records

4.5.9 Protocols database entry

— Record Type Name: <protoent>
— Record Type Descriptor: <protoent-rtd>

Record type used to mirror struct protoent C language data structures. It has the following immutable fields:

name
A Scheme string representing the official name of the protocol.
aliases
A list of Scheme strings representing the alternative names of the protocol.
proto
An integer number representing the protocol number.

— Function: make-<protoent> name aliases proto
— Function: <protoent>? obj

Constructor and predicate for records of type <protoent>. The constructor does not validate its arguments.

— Function: <protoent>-name protoent
— Function: <protoent>-aliases protoent
— Function: <protoent>-proto protoent

Accessors for records of type <protoent>.

— Function: primitive:pointer-><protoent> pointer

Build and return a new record of type <protoent> representing the struct protoent value referenced by pointer. This binding is exported by the (posix sockets primitives) library.

Previous: sockets records protoent, Up: sockets records

4.5.10 Services database entry

— Record Type Name: <servent>
— Record Type Descriptor: <servent-rtd>

Record type used to mirror struct servent C language data structures. It has the following immutable fields:

name
A Scheme string representing the official name of the service.
aliases
A list of Scheme strings representing the alternative names of the service.
port
An integer number representing the service port number in host byte order.
protocol
A Scheme string representing the service protocol (examples ‘tcp’ and ‘udp’).

— Function: make-<servent> name aliases port proto
— Function: <servent>? obj

Constructor and predicate for records of type <servent>. The constructor does not validate its arguments.

— Function: <servent>-name servent
— Function: <servent>-aliases servent
— Function: <servent>-port servent
— Function: <servent>-proto servent

Accessors for records of type <servent>.

— Function: primitive:pointer-><servent> pointer

Build and return a new record of type <servent> representing the struct servent value referenced by pointer. This binding is exported by the (posix sockets primitives) library.

This function takes care of converting the port number from network byte order to host byte order.

Next: sockets inet, Previous: sockets records, Up: sockets

4.6 Network interfaces

The following functions manage inspection of network interfaces. Interface Naming.

— Function: if-nametoindex name
— Parameter: if-nametoindex-function
— Function: primitive:if-nametoindex name
— Function: platform:if_nametoindex name-cstr

Convert the Scheme string or symbol name to the corresponding network interface index. Correct indexes should start at 1, with 0 being invalid. Examples: 

          (if-nametoindex "lo")
          ⇒ 1
          
          (if-nametoindex "eth0")
          ⇒ 2
— Function: if-indextoname index
— Parameter: if-indextoname-function
— Function: primitive:if-indextoname index
— Function: platform:if_indextoname index

Convert the exact integer index representing a network interface integer to a Scheme string or symbol representing the corresponding network interface name. Correct indexes should start at 1, with 0 being invalid. Example: 

          (if-indextoname 1)
          ⇒ "lo"
          
          (if-indextoname 2)
          ⇒ "eth0"
— Function: if-nameindex
— Parameter: if-nameindex-function
— Function: primitive:if-nameindex
— Function: platform:if_nameindex
— Function: platform:if_freenameindex nameindex-ptr

Return a list of <if-nameindex> records representing the known network interfaces.

Next: sockets open close, Previous: sockets ifaces, Up: sockets

4.7 Internet addresses

  • sockets inet formats: Converting addresses to and from presentation format.
  • sockets inet names: Acquiring address from host names.
  • sockets inet hosts: Reading the hosts database.
  • sockets inet nets: Reading the networks database.
  • sockets inet protos: Reading the protocols database.
  • sockets inet servs: Reading the services database.
  • sockets inet order: Converting between network byte order and host byte order.

Next: sockets inet names, Up: sockets inet

4.7.1 Converting addresses to and from presentation format

The following functions manage conversion of Internet addresses between different formats. Host Address Functions.

— Function: inet-aton address-name
— Parameter: inet-aton-function
— Function: primitive:inet-aton address-name
— Function: platform:inet_aton name-ptr in-addr-ptr

Convert the Scheme string address-name representing an IPv4 address, in presentation format, to a struct in_addr value stored in a Scheme bytevector. If the address is valid, return the bytevector; else return #f. 

          (inet-aton "127.0.0.1")
          ⇒ #vu8(127 0 0 1)
— Function: inet-pton address-format address-name
— Parameter: inet-pton-function
— Function: primitive:inet-pton address-name
— Function: platform:inet_pton name-ptr in-addr-ptr

Convert the Scheme string address-name representing an IPv4 or IPv6 address, in presentation format, to a struct in_addr or struct in6_addr value stored in a Scheme bytevector. If the address is valid, return the bytevector; else return #f.

address-format must be an enumeration set of type enum-socket-address-format holding a single element representing the address format: inet or inet6.

— Function: inet-ntoa address-bv
— Parameter: inet-ntoa-function address-bv
— Function: primitive:inet-ntoa address-bv
— Function: platform:inet_ntoa in-addr-ptr

Convert the Scheme bytevector address-bv holding a struct in_addr value to a Scheme string holding the address in presentation format; return the string. 

          (inet-aton #vu8(127 0 0 1))
          ⇒ "127.0.0.1"
— Function: inet-ntop address-format address-bv
— Parameter: inet-ntop-function
— Function: inet-ntop address-format address-bv
— Function: inet_ntop family addr-ptr str-ptr str-len

Convert the Scheme bytevector address-bv holding a struct in_addr or struct in6_addr value to a Scheme string holding the address in presentation format; return the string.

address-format must be an enumeration set of type enum-socket-address-format holding a single element representing the address format: inet or inet6.

Next: sockets inet hosts, Previous: sockets inet formats, Up: sockets inet

4.7.2 Acquiring address from host names

The following functions manage acquisition of Internet addresses from the corresponding host names. Host Names.

— Function: gethostbyname host-name
— Parameter: gethostbyname-function
— Function: primitive:gethostbyname host-name
— Function: platform:gethostbyname name-ptr

Acquire the Internet addresses associated to host-name, a Scheme string, and return a record of type <hostent>.

— Function: gethostbyaddr address-bv
— Parameter: gethostbyaddr-function
— Function: primitive:gethostbyaddr address-bv
— Function: platform:gethostbyaddr addr-ptr addr-len address-format-int

Acquire the Internet addresses associated to address-bv, a Scheme bytevector, and return a record of type <hostent>. address-bv must hold a struct in_addr or struct in6_addr address.

GNU C Library extensions

The following bindings are exported by the libraries: 

     (glibc sockets)
     (glibc sockets primitives)
     (glibc sockets platform)
— Function: gethostbyname2 host-name address-format
— Parameter: gethostbyname2-function
— Function: primitive:gethostbyname2 host-name address-format
— Function: platform:gethostbyname2 name-ptr address-format-int

Like gethostbyname, but allows the specification of the address format with the address-format enumeration set, which must be of type enum-socket-address-format.

The following functions are thread–safe.

— Function: gethostbyname_r host-name
— Parameter: gethostbyname_r-function
— Function: primitive:gethostbyname_r host-name
— Function: platform:gethostbyname_r name-ptr hostent-ptr buf-ptr buf-len result-ptr errno-ptr

Acquire the Internet addresses associated to host-name, a Scheme string, and return a record of type <hostent>.

— Function: gethostbyname2_r host-name address-format
— Parameter: gethostbyname2_r-function
— Function: primitive:gethostbyname2_r host-name address-format
— Function: platform:gethostbyname2_r name-ptr address-format-int hostent-ptr buf-ptr buf-len result-ptr errno-ptr

Like gethostbyname, but allows the specification of the address format with the address-format enumeration set, which must be of type enum-socket-address-format.

— Function: gethostbyaddr_r address-bv
— Parameter: gethostbyaddr_r-function
— Function: primitive:gethostbyaddr_r address-bv
— Function: platform:gethostbyaddr_r addr-ptr addr-len address-format-int hostent-ptr buf-ptr buf-len result-ptr errno-ptr

Acquire the Internet addresses associated to address-bv, a Scheme bytevector, and return a record of type <hostent>. address-bv must hold a struct in_addr or struct in6_addr address.

Next: sockets inet nets, Previous: sockets inet names, Up: sockets inet

4.7.3 Reading the hosts database

The following functions manage scanning of the host database of Internet addresses. Host Names.

— Function: sethostent
— Function: sethostent stay-open
— Parameter: sethostent-function
— Function: primitive:sethostent
— Function: primitive:sethostent stay-open
— Function: platform:sethostent stay-open-int

Start a scan operation on the host database file. If the optional stay-open is true, it causes the database file to be kept open by the library; when not used, it defaults to #f.

— Function: gethostent
— Parameter: gethostent-function
— Function: primitive:gethostent
— Function: platform:gethostent

Return a record of type <hostent> representing the next entry from the database, or #f if no more entries are available.

— Function: endhostent
— Parameter: endhostent-function
— Function: primitive:endhostent
— Function: platform:endhostent

Close the host database file.

Example: 

     (with-compensations
         (compensate
             (sethostent #t)
           (with
            (endhostent)))
       (let loop ((ell     '())
                  (hostent (gethostent)))
         (if hostent
             (loop (cons hostent ell) (gethostent))
           (do-something-with ell))))

Next: sockets inet protos, Previous: sockets inet hosts, Up: sockets inet

4.7.4 Reading the networks database

The following functions manage scanning of the networks database. Networks Database.

— Function: getnetbyname net-name
— Parameter: getnetbyname-function
— Function: primitive:getnetbyname net-name
— Function: platform:getnetbyname net-name-ptr

Return a record of type <netent> representing the address of the network net-name, which must be a Scheme string. If the network is unknown, the return value is #f.

— Function: getnetbyaddr address-bv
— Function: getnetbyaddr address-bv address-format
— Parameter: getnetbyaddr-function
— Function: primitive:getnetbyaddr address-bv
— Function: primitive:getnetbyaddr address-bv address-format
— Function: platform:getnetbyaddr address address-format-int

Return a record of type <netent> representing the address of the network selected by address-bv, which must be a Scheme bytevector holding the network number in network byte order. If the network is unknown, the return value is #f.

address-format must be an enumeration set of type enum-socket-address-format selecting the type of address format: inet or inet6; when not used it defaults to inet.

— Function: setnetent
— Function: setnetent stay-open
— Parameter: setnetent-function
— Function: primitive:setnetent
— Function: primitive:setnetent stay-open
— Function: platform:setnetent stay-open-int

Start a scan operation on the networks database file. If the optional stay-open is true, it causes the database file to be kept open by the library; when not used, it defaults to #f.

— Function: getnetent
— Parameter: getnetent-function
— Function: primitive:getnetent
— Function: platform:getnetent

Return a record of type <netent> representing the next entry from the database, or #f if no more entries are available.

— Function: endnetent
— Parameter: endnetent-function
— Function: primitive:endnetent
— Function: platform:endnetent

Close the networks database file.

Example: 

     (with-compensations
         (compensate
             (setnetent #t)
           (with
            (endnetent)))
       (let loop ((ell     '())
                  (netent (getnetent)))
         (if netent
             (loop (cons netent ell) (getnetent))
           (do-something-with ell))))

Next: sockets inet servs, Previous: sockets inet nets, Up: sockets inet

4.7.5 Reading the protocols database

The following functions manage scanning of the protocols database. Protocols Database.

— Function: getprotobyname proto-name
— Parameter: getprotobyname-function
— Function: primitive:getprotobyname proto-name
— Function: platform:getprotobyname proto-name-ptr

Return a record of type <protoent> representing the informations on the protocol proto-name, which must be a Scheme string. If the protocol is unknown, the return value is #f.

— Function: getprotobynumber protocol-number
— Parameter: getprotobynumber-function
— Function: primitive:getprotobynumber protocol-number
— Function: platform:getprotobynumber protocol-number

Return a record of type <protoent> representing the informations on the protocol selected by protocol-number. If the protocol is unknown, the return value is #f.

— Function: setprotoent
— Function: setprotoent stay-open
— Parameter: setprotoent-function
— Function: primitive:setprotoent
— Function: primitive:setprotoent stay-open
— Function: platform:setprotoent stay-open-int

Start a scan operation on the protocols database file. If the optional stay-open is true, it causes the database file to be kept open by the library; when not used, it defaults to #f.

— Function: getprotoent
— Parameter: getprotoent-function
— Function: primitive:getprotoent
— Function: platform:getprotoent

Return a record of type <protoent> representing the next entry from the database, or #f if no more entries are available.

— Function: endprotoent
— Parameter: endprotoent-function
— Function: primitive:endprotoent
— Function: platform:endprotoent

Close the protocols database file.

Example: 

     (with-compensations
         (compensate
             (setprotoent #t)
           (with
            (endprotoent)))
       (let loop ((ell     '())
                  (protoent (getprotoent)))
         (if protoent
             (loop (cons protoent ell) (getprotoent))
           (do-something-with ell))))

Next: sockets inet order, Previous: sockets inet protos, Up: sockets inet

4.7.6 Reading the services database

The following functions manage scanning of the services database. Services Database.

— Function: getservbyname serv-name proto-name
— Parameter: getservbyname-function
— Function: primitive:getservbyname serv-name proto-name
— Function: platform:getservbyname serv-name-ptr proto-name-ptr

Return a record of type <servent> representing the informations on the service serv-name, which must be a Scheme string, under protocol proto-name, which must be a Scheme string. If the service is unknown, the return value is #f.

— Function: getservbyport network-port-number proto-name
— Parameter: getservbyport-function
— Function: primitive:getservbyport network-port-number proto-name
— Function: platform:getservbyport network-port-number proto-name-ptr

Return a record of type <servent> representing the informations on the service selected by network-port-number, which must be an exact non–negative integer, under proto-name, which must be a Scheme string. If the service is unknown, the return value is #f.

NOTE network-port-number is the port number in network byte order; we have to use the functions htons and ntohs to convert between that number and the host byte order number. For example: the port number 25 in host byte order is equal to number 6400 in network byte order. getservbyport* does the conversion automatically, so we probably want to use that function.

— Function: getservbyport* host-port-number proto-name
— Parameter: getservbyport*-function
— Function: primitive:getservbyport* host-port-number proto-name

Like getservbyport*, but accept the port number in host byte order.

— Function: setservent
— Function: setservent stay-open
— Parameter: setservent-function
— Function: primitive:setservent
— Function: primitive:setservent stay-open
— Function: platform:setservent stay-open-int

Start a scan operation on the services database file. If the optional stay-open is true, it causes the database file to be kept open by the library; when not used, it defaults to #f.

— Function: getservent
— Parameter: getservent-function
— Function: primitive:getservent
— Function: platform:getservent

Return a record of type <servent> representing the next entry from the database, or #f if no more entries are available.

— Function: endservent
— Parameter: endservent-function
— Function: primitive:endservent
— Function: platform:endservent

Close the services database file.

Example: 

     (with-compensations
         (compensate
             (setservent #t)
           (with
            (endservent)))
       (let loop ((ell     '())
                  (servent (getservent)))
         (if servent
             (loop (cons servent ell) (getservent))
           (do-something-with ell))))

Previous: sockets inet servs, Up: sockets inet

4.7.7 Converting between network byte order and host byte order

The following functions manage converting non–negative, exact integers between network byte order (big endian) and host byte order. Byte Order Conversion.

— Function: htons host-uint16
— Function: primitive:htons host-uint16
— Function: platform:htons host-uint16

Host–to–network–short: convert a non–negative exact integer, representable with 16 bits, from host byte order to network byte order.

— Function: ntohs network-uint16
— Function: primitive:ntohs network-uint16
— Function: platform:ntohs network-uint16

Network–to–host–short: convert a non–negative exact integer, representable with 16 bits, from network byte order to host byte order.

— Function: htonl host-uint32
— Function: primitive:htonl host-uint32
— Function: platform:htonl host-uint32

Host–to–network–long: convert a non–negative exact integer, representable with 32 bits, from host byte order to network byte order.

— Function: ntohl network-uint32
— Function: primitive:ntohl network-uint32
— Function: platform:ntohl network-uint32

Network–to–host–long: convert a non–negative exact integer, representable with 32 bits, from network byte order to host byte order.

Next: sockets connect, Previous: sockets inet, Up: sockets

4.8 Opening and closing sockets

The following functions manage opening and closing sockets. Opening and Closing Sockets.

— Function: socket namespace style
— Function: socket namespace style protocol
— Parameter: socket-function
— Function: primitive:socket namespace style
— Function: primitive:socket namespace style protocol
— Function: platform:socket namespace-int style-int protocol-int

Create a new socket and return a <socket> record representing it. Arguments description:

namespace
Must be an enumeration set of type enum-socket-namespace holding a single element.
style
Must be an enumeration set of type enum-socket-style holding a single element.
protocol
Must be an integer selecting the protocol; when not used, it defaults to protocol zero. Reading the protocols database.

— Syntax: socket* (namespace <ns>) (style <sty>)
— Syntax: socket* (namespace <ns>) (style <sty>) (protocol <proto>)
— Auxiliary Syntax: namespace
— Auxiliary Syntax: style
— Auxiliary Syntax: protocol

Wrapper for socket which allows a more concise, S–expression like, usage.

— Function: socketpair namespace style
— Function: socketpair namespace style protocol
— Parameter: socketpair-function
— Function: primitive:socketpair namespace style
— Function: primitive:socketpair namespace style protocol
— Function: platform:socketpair namespace-int style-int protocol-int

Create a two interconnected sockets and return two values being <socket> records representing them.

namespace
Must be an enumeration set of type enum-socket-namespace holding a single element; the namespace must be local (or unix or file).
style
Must be an enumeration set of type enum-socket-style holding a single element.
protocol
Must be an integer selecting the protocol; when not used, it defaults to protocol zero. Reading the protocols database.

— Syntax: socketpair* (namespace <ns>) (style <sty>)
— Syntax: socketpair* (namespace <ns>) (style <sty>) (protocol <proto>)
— Auxiliary Syntax: namespace
— Auxiliary Syntax: style
— Auxiliary Syntax: protocol

Wrapper for socketpair which allows a more concise, S–expression like, usage.

— Function: shutdown sock how
— Parameter: shutdown-function
— Function: primitive:shutdown sock how
— Function: platform:shutdown sock-int how-int

Shut down the connection socket sock, which must be a <socket> record, according to the mode selected by how, which must be an enumeration set of type enum-shutdown-mode holding a single element.

This function is an alternative to close, which can be applied to sock, too, and which closes both the channels.

— Syntax: shutdown* <sock> <how>
— Syntax: primitive:shutdown* <sock> <how>

Wrapper for shutdown which allows us not to embed the shutdown mode in the shutdown-mode syntax; it expands to: 

          (shutdown <sock> (shutdown-mode <how>))

Next: sockets address, Previous: sockets open close, Up: sockets

4.9 Connection operations on sockets

The following functions perform operations on sockets. Making a Connection. Setting the Address of a Socket. Listening for Connections. Accepting Connections.

— Function: connect sock sockaddr
— Parameter: connect-function
— Function: primitive:connect sock sockaddr
— Function: platform:connect sock-int sockaddr-ptr socklen

Initiate a connection from sock to the address described by sockaddr. sock must be a <socket> record, sockaddr must be a record of type <sockaddr-un>, <sockaddr-in> or <sockaddr-in6>.

— Function: bind sock sockaddr
— Parameter: bind-function
— Function: primitive:bind sock sockaddr
— Function: platform:bind sock sockaddr-ptr socklen

Assign an address to a socket. sock must be a record of type <socket>. sockaddr must be a record of type <sockaddr-un>, <sockaddr-in> or <sockaddr-in6>.

— Function: listen sock max-pending-connections
— Parameter: listen-function
— Function: primitive:listen sock max-pending-connections
— Function: platform:listen sock-int max-pending-connections

Enable sock to accept connections, making it a server socket; sock must be a record of type <socket>.

The exact positive integer max-pending-connections establishes the length of the queue for pending connections; when this limit is reached, the connection is refused.

— Function: accept sock
— Parameter: accept-function
— Function: primitive:accept sock
— Function: platform:accept sock-int sockaddr-ptr socklen

Accept a connection to the server–socket sock, which must be a <socket> record.

Return two values: a new <socket> record representing the socket connected to the client, a record of type <sockaddr-un>, <sockaddr-in> or <sockaddr-in6> describing the client's address.

Next: sockets send, Previous: sockets connect, Up: sockets

4.10 Network addresses

The following functions manage querying sockets for their associated addresses. Reading the Address of a Socket. Who is Connected to Me?.

— Function: getsockname sock
— Parameter: getsockname-function
— Function: primitive:getsockname sock
— Function: platform:getsockname sock-int sockaddr-ptr socklen-ptr

Return a record of type <sockaddr-un>, <sockaddr-in> or <sockaddr-in6> describing the address bound to sock, which must be a <socket> record.

This is the address associated to sock by bind.

— Function: getpeername sock
— Parameter: getpeername-function
— Function: primitive:getpeername sock
— Function: platform:getpeername sock-int sockaddr-ptr socklen-ptr

Return a record of type <sockaddr-un>, <sockaddr-in> or <sockaddr-in6> describing the address to which sock is connected; sock must be a <socket> record.

This is the address associated to sock by connect or accept.

Next: sockets recv, Previous: sockets address, Up: sockets

4.11 Sending data through stream sockets

The following functions manage sending data through stream sockets. Sending Data.

— Function: send sock ptr len options
— Parameter: send-function
— Function: primitive:send sock ptr len options
— Function: platform:send sock-int ptr len options-int

Write at most len bytes from the buffer referenced by ptr through the socket sock; return the number of bytes actually sent.

sock
Must be a record of type <socket>.
ptr
Must be a pointer object.
len
Must be an exact, non–negative integer.
options
Must be an enumeration set of type enum-socket-data-options; when no options need to be set, it can be (socket-data-options).

For the following functions: when the optional options argument is not used, it defaults to (socket-data-options).

— Function: send/string sock str
— Function: send/string sock str options
— Parameter: send/string-function
— Function: primitive:send/string sock str
— Function: primitive:send/string sock str options

Wrapper for send which sends the Scheme string str. The Scheme string is converted to a memory block holding its UTF8 representation; no terminating zero byte is sent.

— Function: send/bytevector sock bv
— Function: send/bytevector sock bv options
— Parameter: send/bytevector-function
— Function: primitive:send/bytevector sock bv
— Function: primitive:send/bytevector sock bv options

Wrapper for send which sends the Scheme bytevector bv.

— Function: send/memblock sock mb
— Function: send/memblock sock mb options
— Parameter: send/memblock-function
— Function: primitive:send/memblock sock mb
— Function: primitive:send/memblock sock mb options

Wrapper for send which sends data from the memory block referenced by mb, which must be a <memblock> record. Memory blocks.

Next: sockets sendto, Previous: sockets send, Up: sockets

4.12 Receiving data from through stream sockets

The following functions manage receiving data through stream sockets. Receiving Data.

— Function: recv sock ptr len options
— Parameter: recv-function
— Function: primitive:recv sock ptr len options
— Function: platform:recv sock-int ptr len options-int

Read at most len bytes from the socket sock to the buffer referenced by ptr; return the number of bytes actually received.

sock
Must be a record of type <socket>.
ptr
Must be a pointer object.
len
Must be an exact, non–negative integer.
options
Must be an enumeration set of type enum-socket-data-options; when no options need to be set, it can be (socket-data-options).

For the following functions: when the optional options argument is not used, it defaults to (socket-data-options).

— Function: recv/string sock max-len
— Function: recv/string sock max-len options
— Parameter: recv/string-function
— Function: primitive:recv/string sock max-len
— Function: primitive:recv/string sock max-len options

Wrapper for recv which converts the bytes read, at most max-len, to a Scheme string and returns it. The data read is interpreted as a string in UTF8 representation; no terminating zero byte is expected from the socket.

— Function: recv/bytevector sock max-len
— Function: recv/bytevector sock max-len options
— Parameter: recv/bytevector-function
— Function: primitive:recv/bytevector sock max-len
— Function: primitive:recv/bytevector sock max-len options

Wrapper for recv which converts the bytes read, at most max-len, to a Scheme bytevector and returns it.

— Function: recv/memblock sock max-len malloc
— Function: recv/memblock sock max-len options malloc
— Parameter: recv/memblock-function
— Function: primitive:recv/memblock sock max-len malloc
— Function: primitive:recv/memblock sock max-len options malloc

Wrapper for recv which stores the bytes read, at most max-len, into a newly allocated block of memory and returns a <memblock> record referencing it. Memory blocks.

Memory is allocated with the supplied malloc function, which must have an interface compatible with malloc from the (foreign memory) library. Exception raising functions.

Next: sockets recvfrom, Previous: sockets recv, Up: sockets

4.13 Sending data through datagram sockets

The following functions manage sending data through datagram sockets. Sending Datagrams.

— Function: sendto sock ptr len options sockaddr
— Parameter: sendto-function
— Function: primitive:sendto sock ptr len options sockaddr
— Function: platform:sendto sock-int ptr len options-int

Write at most len bytes from the buffer referenced by ptr through the socket sock to the address selected by sockaddr; return the number of bytes actually sent. Arguments description:

sock
Must be a record of type <socket>.
ptr
Must be a pointer object.
len
Must be an exact, non–negative integer.
options
Must be an enumeration set of type enum-socket-data-options; when no options need to be set, it can be (socket-data-options).
sockaddr
Must be a record of type <sockaddr-in>, <sockaddr-in6> or <sockaddr-un>.

For the following functions: when the optional options argument is not used, it defaults to (socket-data-options).

— Function: sendto/string sock str sockaddr
— Function: sendto/string sock str options sockaddr
— Parameter: sendto/string-function
— Function: primitive:sendto/string sock str sockaddr
— Function: primitive:sendto/string sock str options sockaddr

Wrapper for sendto which sends the Scheme string str. The Scheme string is converted to a memory block holding its UTF8 representation; no terminating zero byte is sent.

— Function: sendto/bytevector sock bv sockaddr
— Function: sendto/bytevector sock bv options sockaddr
— Parameter: sendto/bytevector-function
— Function: primitive:sendto/bytevector sock bv sockaddr
— Function: primitive:sendto/bytevector sock bv options sockaddr

Wrapper for sendto which sends the Scheme bytevector bv.

— Function: sendto/memblock sock mb sockaddr
— Function: sendto/memblock sock mb options sockaddr
— Parameter: sendto/memblock-function
— Function: primitive:sendto/memblock sock mb sockaddr
— Function: primitive:sendto/memblock sock mb options sockaddr

Wrapper for sendto which sends data from the memory block referenced by mb, which must be a <memblock> record. Memory blocks.

Next: sockets options, Previous: sockets sendto, Up: sockets

4.14 Receiving data from through datagram sockets

The following functions manage receiving data through datagram sockets. Receiving Datagrams.

— Function: recvfrom sock ptr len options
— Parameter: recvfrom-function
— Function: primitive:recvfrom sock ptr len options
— Function: platform:recvfrom sock-int ptr len options-int

Read at most len bytes from the socket sock to the buffer referenced by ptr. Return two values: the number of bytes actually received; a record of type <sockaddr-in>, <sockaddr-in6> or <sockaddr-un> representing the address from which data is received.

sock
Must be a record of type <socket>.
ptr
Must be a pointer object.
len
Must be an exact, non–negative integer.
options
Must be an enumeration set of type enum-socket-data-options; when no options need to be set, it can be (socket-data-options).

For the following functions: when the optional options argument is not used, it defaults to (socket-data-options).

— Function: recvfrom/string sock max-len
— Function: recvfrom/string sock max-len options
— Parameter: recvfrom/string-function
— Function: primitive:recvfrom/string sock max-len
— Function: primitive:recvfrom/string sock max-len options

Wrapper for recvfrom which converts the bytes read, at most max-len, to a Scheme string and returns it as first value; the second returned value is the same as the one of recvfrom.

The data read is interpreted as a string in UTF8 representation; no terminating zero byte is expected from the socket.

— Function: recvfrom/bytevector sock max-len
— Function: recvfrom/bytevector sock max-len options
— Parameter: recvfrom/bytevector-function
— Function: primitive:recvfrom/bytevector sock max-len
— Function: primitive:recvfrom/bytevector sock max-len options

Wrapper for recvfrom which converts the bytes read, at most max-len, to a Scheme bytevector and returns it as first value; the second returned value is the same as the one of recvfrom.

— Function: recvfrom/memblock sock max-len malloc
— Function: recvfrom/memblock sock max-len options malloc
— Parameter: recvfrom/memblock-function
— Function: primitive:recvfrom/memblock sock max-len malloc
— Function: primitive:recvfrom/memblock sock max-len options malloc
