Wrapper for recvfrom which stores the bytes read, at most max-len, into a newly allocated block of memory and returns a <memblock> record referencing it as first value; the second returned value is the same as the one of recvfrom. Memory blocks.

Memory is allocated with the supplied malloc function, which must have an interface compatible with malloc from the (foreign memory) library. Exception raising functions.

Next: sockets examples, Previous: sockets recvfrom, Up: sockets

4.15 Configuring sockets behaviour

The following functions manage configuration of sockets. Socket Options.

— Function: getsockopt sock option
— Parameter: getsockopt-function
— Function: primitive:getsockopt sock option
— Function: platform:getsockopt sock-int level option optptr optlen

Retrieve the selected option from a socket and return its value. sock must be an object of type <socket>; option must be an enumeration set of type enum-socket-option holding a single element.

— Function: setsockopt sock option value
— Parameter: setsockopt-function
— Function: primitive:setsockopt sock option value
— Function: platform:setsockopt sock-int level option optptr optlen

Set the selected option for a socket. sock must be an object of type <socket>; option must be an enumeration set of type enum-socket-option holding a single element.

The following symbols from enum-socket-option are supported for POSIX systems:

debug
reuseaddr
keepalive
dontroute
broadcast
oobinline
The value is a Scheme boolean. Can be used with both getsockopt and setsockopt.
sndbuf
rcvbuf
The value is an exact non–negative integer, representing the size of send/receive buffers; notice that this appears to be more a “suggestion” to the system, rather than a strict order. Can be used with both getsockopt and setsockopt.
linger
The value is #f or an exact positive integer, representing the linger time out in seconds; #f means no lingering and it is equivalent to zero. Can be used with both getsockopt and setsockopt.
style
type
The value is a socket style, an enumeration set of type enum-socket-style holding a single element. Can be used only with getsockopt.
error
Retrieve and clear the pending socket error. Can be used only with getsockopt.

Previous: sockets options, Up: sockets

4.16 Client and server examples

  • sockets stream server: A simple stream echo server.
  • sockets stream client: A simple stream client.
  • sockets dgram server: A simple datagram echo server.
  • sockets dgram client: A simple datagram client.

Next: sockets stream client, Up: sockets examples

4.16.1 A simple stream echo server

The following is a stream–socket echo server: it accepts a single connection, reads a line, echo the line to the client, exits; using telnet we can have the following session after starting it: 

     $ telnet localhost 8080
     Trying 127.0.0.1...
     Connected to localhost.
     Escape character is '^]'.
     ciao
     ciao
     Connection closed by foreign host.

remember to allow connections to port 8080 in your local firewall rules. 

     (import (rnrs)
       (receive)
       (compensations)
       (only (strings) string-index)
       (pretty-print)
       (foreign errno)
       (prefix (posix typedefs) px:)
       (prefix (posix fd) px:)
       (prefix (posix sockets) px:))
     
     (define addr '#vu8(127 0 0 1))
     (define port 8080)
     (define max-input-len 4096)
     
     (define (main)
       (guard (E ((errno-condition? E)
                  (fatal (condition-message E)))
                 (else
                  (%pretty-print E)))
         (%display "server start\n")
         (with-compensations
           (define hostent
             (or (px:gethostbyaddr addr)
                 (fatal "unable to bind to socket address")))
           (define sockaddr
             (px:make-<sockaddr-in>
              (px:<hostent>-addr hostent) port))
           (define master-sock
             (compensate
                 (px:socket* (namespace inet) (style stream))
               (with
                (px:close master-sock))))
           (px:setsockopt master-sock
                          (px:socket-option reuseaddr) #t)
           (px:bind master-sock sockaddr)
           (%display (string-append
                      "server listening to: "
                      (px:<hostent>-name hostent)
                      ":" (number->string port) "\n"))
           (px:listen master-sock 1)
           (receive (client-sock client-addr)
               (px:accept master-sock)
             (handle-connection client-sock client-addr)
             (exit 0)))))
     
     (define (handle-connection client-sock client-addr)
       (with-compensations
         (define client-hostent
           (px:gethostbyaddr
            (px:<sockaddr-in>-addr client-addr)))
         (define (get-string)
           (px:recv/string client-sock max-input-len))
         (push-compensation (px:close client-sock))
         (%display (string-append
                    "server accepted connection from "
                    (px:<hostent>-name client-hostent)
                    "\n"))
         (let loop ((accu "")
                    (str  (get-string)))
           (when (< max-input-len (string-length accu))
             (fatal "server: input too long\n"))
           (%display (string-append "server received: " str))
           (let ((idx (string-index str #\newline)))
             (if idx
                 (px:send/string client-sock
                                 (substring str 0 idx))
               (loop (string-append accu str) (get-string)))))))
     
     (define (fatal . strings)
       (%display (apply string-append strings))
       (%newline)
       (exit 1))
     
     (define (%display thing)
       (display thing (current-error-port)))
     
     (define (%pretty-print thing)
       (pretty-print thing (current-error-port)))
     
     (define (%newline)
       (newline (current-error-port)))
     
     (main)

Next: sockets dgram server, Previous: sockets stream server, Up: sockets examples

4.16.2 A simple stream client

The following is a stream–socket client: it connects to the hostname and port given on the command line, it works somewhat like telnet. 

     (import (rnrs)
       (receive)
       (compensations)
       (only (strings) string-index)
       (pretty-print)
       (foreign errno)
       (prefix (posix typedefs) px:)
       (prefix (posix fd) px:)
       (prefix (posix sockets) px:))
     
     (define progname "telnet.sps")
     
     (define (main)
       (guard (E ((errno-condition? E)
                  (fatal (condition-message E)))
                 (else
                  (%pretty-print E)))
         (%display "client start (Ctrl-D to exit)\n")
         (with-compensations
           (receive (hostname port)
               (parse-command-line)
             (define hostent
               (or (px:gethostbyname hostname)
                   (fatal "unable to bind to socket address")))
             (define sockaddr
               (px:make-<sockaddr-in>
                (px:<hostent>-addr hostent) port))
             (define sock
               (compensate
                   (px:socket* (namespace inet) (style stream))
                 (with
                  (px:close sock))))
             (%display (string-append
                        "client connecting to: "
                        (px:<hostent>-name hostent)
                        ":" (number->string port) "\n"))
             (px:connect sock sockaddr)
             (let loop ((line (get-line (current-input-port))))
               (when (eof-object? line)
                 (exit 0))
               (px:send/string sock (string-append line "\n"))
               (display (string-append
                         "reply: "
                         (px:recv/string sock 4096)
                         "\n"))
               (loop (get-line (current-input-port))))))))
     
     (define (parse-command-line)
       (let ((args (command-line)))
         (unless (= 3 (length args))
           (fatal "usage: " progname " <hostname> <port>\n"))
         (guard (E (else
                    (fatal "wrong port specification\n")))
           (values (cadr args) (string->number (caddr args))))))
     
     (define (fatal . strings)
       (%display (apply string-append strings))
       (%newline)
       (exit 1))
     
     (define (%display thing)
       (display thing (current-error-port)))
     
     (define (%pretty-print thing)
       (pretty-print thing (current-error-port)))
     
     (define (%newline)
       (newline (current-error-port)))
     
     (main)

Next: sockets dgram client, Previous: sockets stream client, Up: sockets examples

4.16.3 A simple datagram echo server

The following is a datagram–socket echo server: it accepts a single connection, reads a line, echo the line to the client, exits. When trying it, remember to allow connections to port 8080 in your local firewall rules. 

     (import (rnrs)
       (receive)
       (compensations)
       (only (strings) string-index)
       (pretty-print)
       (foreign errno)
       (prefix (posix typedefs) px:)
       (prefix (posix fd) px:)
       (prefix (posix sockets) px:))
     
     (define server-addr     '#vu8(127 0 0 1))
     (define server-port     8080)
     (define max-input-len   4096)
     
     (define (main)
       (guard (E ((errno-condition? E)
                  (fatal (condition-message E)))
                 (else
                  (%pretty-print E)))
         (%display "server start\n")
         (with-compensations
           (define hostent
             (or (px:gethostbyaddr server-addr)
                 (fatal "unable to bind to socket address")))
           (define sockaddr
             (px:make-<sockaddr-in>
              (px:<hostent>-addr hostent) server-port))
           (define sock
             (compensate
                 (px:socket* (namespace inet) (style datagram))
               (with
                (px:close sock))))
           (px:setsockopt sock (px:socket-option reuseaddr) #t)
           (px:bind sock sockaddr)
           (%display (string-append
                      "server listening to: "
                      (px:<hostent>-name hostent)
                      ":" (number->string server-port) "\n"))
           (receive (str client-addr)
               (px:recvfrom/string sock max-input-len)
             (%display (string-append "server received: " str))
             (px:sendto/string sock str client-addr)
             (exit 0)))))
     
     (define (fatal . strings)
       (%display (apply string-append strings))
       (%newline)
       (exit 1))
     
     (define (%display thing)
       (display thing (current-error-port)))
     
     (define (%pretty-print thing)
       (pretty-print thing (current-error-port)))
     
     (define (%newline)
       (newline (current-error-port)))
     
     (main)

Previous: sockets dgram server, Up: sockets examples

4.16.4 A simple datagram client

The following is a datagram–socket client: it connects to the hostname and port given on the command line, it works somewhat like telnet. 

     (import (rnrs)
       (receive)
       (compensations)
       (only (strings) string-index)
       (pretty-print)
       (foreign errno)
       (prefix (posix typedefs) px:)
       (prefix (posix fd) px:)
       (prefix (posix sockets) px:))
     
     (define progname        "telnet.sps")
     (define local-addr      '#vu8(127 0 0 1))
     (define local-port      8081)
     (define max-input-len   4096)
     
     (define (main)
       (guard (E ((errno-condition? E)
                  (fatal (condition-message E)))
                 (else
                  (%pretty-print E)))
         (with-compensations
           (%display "client start (Ctrl-D to exit)\n")
           (receive (hostname remote-port)
               (parse-command-line)
             (define local-hostent
               (px:gethostbyaddr local-addr))
             (define local-sockaddr
               (px:make-<sockaddr-in> local-addr local-port))
             (define remote-hostent
               (or (px:gethostbyname hostname)
                   (fatal "unable to bind to socket address")))
             (define remote-sockaddr
               (px:make-<sockaddr-in>
                (px:<hostent>-addr remote-hostent) remote-port))
             (define sock
               (compensate
                   (px:socket* (namespace inet) (style datagram))
                 (with
                  (px:close sock))))
             (%display (string-append
                        "client local address: "
                        (px:<hostent>-name local-hostent)
                        ":" (number->string local-port) "\n"))
             (%display (string-append
                        "client connecting to: "
                        (px:<hostent>-name remote-hostent)
                        ":" (number->string remote-port) "\n"))
             (px:setsockopt sock (px:socket-option reuseaddr) #t)
             (px:bind sock local-sockaddr)
             (let loop ((line (get-line (current-input-port))))
               (when (eof-object? line)
                 (exit 0))
               (px:sendto/string sock
                                 (string-append line "\n")
                                 remote-sockaddr)
               (receive (str addr)
                   (px:recvfrom/string sock max-input-len)
                 (display (string-append "reply: " str "\n"))
                 (loop (get-line (current-input-port)))))))))
     
     (define (parse-command-line)
       (let ((args (command-line)))
         (unless (= 3 (length args))
           (fatal (string-append
                   "usage: " progname " <hostname> <port>\n"))
           (exit 1))
         (guard (E (else
                    (fatal "wrong port specification")))
           (values (cadr args) (string->number (caddr args))))))
     
     (define (fatal . strings)
       (%display (apply string-append strings))
       (%newline)
       (exit 1))
     
     (define (%display thing)
       (display thing (current-error-port)))
     
     (define (%pretty-print thing)
       (pretty-print thing (current-error-port)))
     
     (define (%newline)
       (newline (current-error-port)))
     
     (main)

Next: time, Previous: sockets, Up: Top

5 Stream functions

Unless otherwise specified, the bindings described in this chapter are exported by the following libraries: 

     (glibc streams)
     (glibc streams primitives)
     (glibc streams platform)
  • streams typedefs: Object type definitions.
  • streams constants: Constants.
  • streams errors: Detecting errors on streams.
  • streams open close: Opening and closing.
  • streams writing: Writing to streams.
  • streams reading: Reading from streams.
  • streams unreading: Unreading to streams.
  • streams seeking: Stream positioning.
  • streams fd: Streams and file descriptors.
  • streams unlocked: Unlocked stream operations.
  • streams extended: Extended stream operations.
  • streams lines: Reading lines.

Next: streams constants, Up: streams

5.1 Object type definitions

Functions from the primitives and high–level stream libraries accept objects of type FILE* as stream arguments. Functions from the platform libraries accept pointer objects as representing stream pointers.

The following bindings are exported by the (posix typedefs) library.

— Object Type: FILE*

Object type representing a FILE * pointer; it is disjoint from all the other Scheme object types.

— Function: FILE*->pointer stream
— Function: pointer->FILE* pointer

Convert between a stream object and a pointer object.

— Function: FILE*? obj

Return true if obj is a stream object.

Next: streams errors, Previous: streams typedefs, Up: streams

5.2 Constants

The following bindings are exported by the (posix sizeof) library. Notice that the seek constants SEEK_SET, SEEK_CUR and SEEK_END are also exported by the same library. File positions

— Constant: EOF

The value of EOF. End–of–file and Errors.

Next: streams open close, Previous: streams constants, Up: streams

5.3 Detecting errors on streams

The following functions manage error detection on streams operations. End–Of–File and Errors.

— Function: ferror stream
— Parameter: ferror-function
— Function: primitive:-ferror stream
— Function: platform:ferror stream

Return #t if the error indicator of stream is set, #f otherwise. platform:ferror returns a single value: The return value of the foreign function call.

— Function: clearerr stream
— Function: primitive:clearerr stream
— Function: platform:clearerr stream

Clear the error and end–of–file indicators for stream. platform:clearerr returns a single value: The return value of the foreign function call.

Next: streams writing, Previous: streams errors, Up: streams

5.4 Opening and closing

The following functions manage opening and closing of streams. Opening Streams. Closing Streams.

— Function: fopen pathname mode
— Parameter: fopen-function
— Function: primitive:fopen pathname mode
— Function: platform:fopen pathname-cstr mode-cstr

Open a file selected by pathname with the given mode and return a FILE* object. pathname and mode must be Scheme strings or symbols.

— Function: fclose stream
— Parameter: fclose-function
— Function: primitive:fclose stream
— Function: platform:fclose stream-ptr

Close the previously opened stream.

— Function: fcloseall
— Parameter: fcloseall-function
— Function: primitive:fcloseall
— Function: platform:fcloseall

Close all the open streams of the process.

Next: streams reading, Previous: streams open close, Up: streams

5.5 Writing to streams

The following functions manage writing data to streams. Block Input/Output. Flushing Buffers.

— Function: fwrite pointer size count stream
— Parameter: fwrite-function
— Function: primitive:fwrite pointer size count stream
— Function: platform:fwrite pointer size count stream-ptr

Write up to count elements of size bytes from the block of memory referenced by pointer to stream. If successful return count.

— Function: fputc char stream
— Parameter: fputc-function
— Function: primitive:fputc char stream
— Function: platform:fputc char stream-ptr

Write a character to stream. char must be a Scheme character with scalar value in the range [0, 255]; the scalar value is computed with char->integer. If successful return the scalar representing char.

— Function: fputs string stream
— Parameter: fputs-function
— Function: primitive:fputs string stream
— Function: platform:fputs cstring stream-ptr

Write a string to stream. string must be a Scheme string or symbol. If successful return the scalar representing char.

— Function: fflush stream
— Parameter: fflush-function
— Function: primitive:fflush stream
— Function: platform:fflush stream-ptr

Flush the contents of the buffer to the underlying device.

Next: streams unreading, Previous: streams writing, Up: streams

5.6 Reading from streams

The following functions manage reading data from streams. Block Input/Output.

— Function: fread pointer size count stream
— Parameter: fread-function
— Function: primitive:fread pointer size count stream
— Function: platform:fread pointer size count stream-ptr

Read up to count elements of size bytes from stream and store them in the block of memory referenced by pointer. Return the number of objects actually read (which may be less than count).

— Function: fgetc stream
— Parameter: fgetc-function
— Function: primitive:fgetc stream
— Function: platform:fgetc stream-ptr

Read a single character from stream. Return a Scheme character.

— Function: fgets pointer count stream
— Parameter: fgets-function
— Function: primitive:fgets pointer count stream
— Function: platform-fgets pointer count stream-ptr

Read a line from stream and store it in the buffer of count bytes referenced by pointer. Return pointer.

Next: streams seeking, Previous: streams reading, Up: streams

5.7 Unreading to streams

The following functions manage “unreading” data from streams. Using ungetc To Do Unreading.

— Function: ungetc char stream
— Parameter: ungetc-function
— Function: primitive:ungetc char stream
— Function: platform:ungetc c-char stream-ptr

Unread a character to stream. char must be a Scheme character with scalar value in the range [0, 255]; the scalar value is computed with char->integer.

Next: streams fd, Previous: streams unreading, Up: streams

5.8 Stream positioning

The following functions manage seeking the current position in streams. File Positioning.

Notice that the seek constants SEEK_SET, SEEK_CUR and SEEK_END are exported by the (posix sizeof) library. File positions

— Function: feof stream
— Parameter: feof-function
— Function: primitive:feof stream
— Function: platform:feof stream-ptr

Return #t if the end–of–file indicator of stream is set, otherwise #f.

— Function: fseek stream offset whence
— Parameter: fseek-function
— Function: primitive:fseek stream offset whence
— Function: platform:fseek stream-ptr offset whence

Change the file position of stream to offset from whence.

— Function: fseeko stream offset whence
— Parameter: fseeko-function
— Function: primitive:fseeko stream offset whence
— Function: platform:fseeko stream-ptr offset whence

Like fseek, but the return value is of type off_t.

— Function: ftell stream
— Parameter: ftell-function
— Function: primitive:ftell stream
— Function: platform:ftell stream-ptr

Return the current file position of stream.

— Function: ftello stream
— Parameter: ftello-function
— Function: primitive:ftello stream
— Function: platform:ftello stream-ptr

Like ftell, but the return value is of type off_t.

— Function: rewind stream
— Parameter: rewind-function
— Function: primitive:rewind stream
— Function: platform:rewind stream-ptr

Change the file position of stream to the beginning of the file.

Next: streams unlocked, Previous: streams seeking, Up: streams

5.9 Streams and file descriptors

The following functions manage conversion of streams to and from raw file descriptors. Descriptors and Streams.

— Function: fdopen fd open-mode
— Parameter: fdopen-function
— Function: primitive:fdopen fd open-mode
— Function: platform:fdopen fd open-mode

Build a new stream referencing the file descriptor fd and return a FILE* object. open-mode must be a Scheme string or symbol representing the open mode of fd; it can have the same values accepted by fopen.

— Function: fileno stream
— Parameter: fileno-function
— Function: primitive:fileno stream
— Function: platform:fileno stream-ptr

Return a <fd> object representing the file descriptor wrapped by stream.

Next: streams extended, Previous: streams fd, Up: streams

5.10 Unlocked stream operations

The following functions manage operation on streams without locking for exclusive access; they are like the corresponding non–_unlocked variants, but they do not implicitly lock the stream.

Errors
— Function: ferror_unlocked stream
— Parameter: ferror_unlocked-function
— Function: primitive:ferror_unlocked stream
— Function: platform:ferror_unlocked stream-ptr

Like ferror.

— Function: clearerr_unlocked stream
— Function: primitive:clearerr_unlocked stream
— Function: platform:clearerr_unlocked stream-ptr

Like clearerr.

Writing
— Function: fwrite_unlocked pointer size count stream
— Parameter: fwrite_unlocked-function
— Function: primitive:fwrite_unlocked pointer size count stream
— Function: platform:fwrite_unlocked pointer size count stream-ptr

Like fwrite.

— Function: fputc_unlocked char stream
— Parameter: fputc_unlocked-function
— Function: primitive:fputc_unlocked c-char stream
— Function: platform:fputc_unlocked c-char stream-ptr

Like fputc.

— Function: fputs_unlocked string stream
— Parameter: fputs_unlocked-function
— Function: primitive:fputs_unlocked cstring stream
— Function: platform:fputs_unlocked cstring stream-ptr

Like fputs.

— Function: fflush_unlocked stream
— Parameter: fflush_unlocked-function
— Function: primitive:fflush_unlocked stream
— Function: platform:fflush_unlocked stream-ptr

Like fflush.

Reading
— Function: fread_unlocked pointer size count stream
— Parameter: fread_unlocked-function
— Function: primitive:fread_unlocked pointer size count stream
— Function: platform:fread_unlocked pointer size count stream-ptr

Like fread.

— Function: fgetc_unlocked stream
— Parameter: fgetc_unlocked-function
— Function: primitive:fgetc_unlocked stream
— Function: platform:fgetc_unlocked stream-ptr

Like fgetc.

— Function: fgets_unlocked pointer count stream
— Parameter: fgets_unlocked-function
— Function: primitive:fgets_unlocked pointer count stream
— Function: platform:fgets_unlocked pointer count stream-ptr

Like fgets.

Seeking
— Function: feof_unlocked stream
— Parameter: feof_unlocked-function
— Function: primitive:feof_unlocked stream
— Function: platform:feof_unlocked stream-ptr

Like feof.

Streams an file descriptors
— Function: fileno_unlocked stream
— Parameter: fileno_unlocked-function
— Function: primitive:fileno_unlocked stream
— Function: platform:fileno_unlocked stream-ptr

Like fileno.

Next: streams lines, Previous: streams unlocked, Up: streams

5.11 Extended stream operations

The following functions implement extended operations on streams.

Inspection
— Function: freadable stream
— Parameter: freadable-function
— Function: primitive:freadable stream
— Function: platform:freadable stream-ptr

Return #t if stream was opened for reading, otherwise return #f. platform:freadable returns a single value: the return value from the foreign function.

— Function: fwritable stream
— Parameter: fwritable-function
— Function: primitive:fwritable stream
— Function: platform:fwritable stream-ptr

Return #t if stream was opened for writing, otherwise return #f. platform:fwritable returns a single value: the return value from the foreign function.

— Function: freading stream
— Parameter: freading-function
— Function: primitive:freading stream
— Function: platform:freading stream-ptr

Return #t if stream was last read from, otherwise return #f. platform:freading returns a single value: the return value from the foreign function.

— Function: fwriting stream
— Parameter: fwriting-function
— Function: primitive:fwriting stream
— Function: platform:fwriting stream-ptr

Return #t if stream was last written to, otherwise return #f. platform:fwriting returns a single value: the return value from the foreign function.

— Function: fwide stream mode
— Parameter: fwide-function
— Function: primitive:fwide stream mode
— Function: platform:fwide stream-ptr mode

Set or query the orientation of stream. mode must be an exact integer. platform:fwide returns a single value: the return value from the foreign function.

  • If mode is zero and the return value is positive: stream is oriented for wide characters.
  • If mode is zero and the return value is negative: stream is oriented for narrow characters.
  • If mode is positive: stream is configured for wide characters.
  • If mode is negative: stream is configured for narrow characters.

Miscellaneous
— Function: fpurge stream
— Parameter: fpurge-function
— Function: primitive:fpurge stream
— Function: platform:fpurge stream-ptr

Discard the contents of the buffer. platform:fpurge returns a single value: the return value from the foreign function.

Previous: streams extended, Up: streams

5.12 Reading lines

The following functions manage reading lines from streams. Line–Oriented Input.

— Function: getline stream
— Parameter: getline-function
— Function: primitive:getline stream
— Function: platform:getline pointer-pointer pointer-count stream-ptr

Read characters from stream until a newline is found, then returns a string holding those characters and a terminating newline.

If end–of–file is encountered before the newline, but some characters where read: The acquired characters are stored in a string without terminating newline, and the string is returned.

If end–of–file is encountered before the newline, and no characters where read: An empty string is returned.

If an error occurs while reading: An exception is raised.

— Function: getdelim stream delimiter
— Parameter: getdelim-function
— Function: primitive:getdelim stream delimiter
— Function: platform:getdelim pointer-pointer pointer-count delimiter stream-ptr

Like getline but reads characters until delimiter is found. delimiter must be a Scheme character with an integer representation in the range [0, 255].

As a usage example, the following code reads one line at a time from a file and accumulates them in the lines variables: 

     (import (rnrs)
       (receive)
       (compensations)
       (foreign memory)
       (foreign cstrings)
       (foreign errno)
       (foreign ffi peekers-and-pokers)
       (glibc streams)
       (prefix (glibc streams platform) platform:))
     
     (let* ((pathname the-pathname))
       (with-compensations
         (letrec* ((S           (compensate
                                    (fopen pathname "w+")
                                  (with
                                   (fclose S))))
                   (*pointer    (malloc-small/c))
                   (*count      (malloc-small/c))
                   (getp        (lambda ()
                                  (pointer-ref-c-pointer *pointer 0)))
                   (free        (lambda ()
                                  (let ((p (getp)))
                                    (unless (pointer-null? p)
                                      (primitive-free p)))))
                   (lines       '()))
           (let loop ()
             (receive (result errno)
                 (platform:getline *pointer *count S)
               (cond ((ferror S)
                      (free)
                      (raise-errno-error 'reading-line errno S))
     ;;; here EOF was found, return the result
                     ((= -1 result)
                      (free)
                      (reverse lines))
     ;;; accumulate the result
                     (else
                      (set! lines
                            (cons (cstring->string (getp) result)
                                  lines))
                      (loop))))))))

Next: process, Previous: streams, Up: Top

6 Date and time

Unless otherwise specified, the bindings documented in this chapter are exported by the following libraries: 

     (posix time)
     (posix time primitives)
     (posix time platform)

it is explicitly stated when bindings are exported by the following libraries: 

     (glibc time)
     (glibc time primitives)
     (glibc time platform)
  • time intro: Introduction.
  • time structs: Data structures.
  • time typedefs: Object type definitions.
  • time records: Record types.
  • time constants: Constant values.
  • time clock: Processor time.
  • time calendar: Simple calendar time.
  • time hires: High resolution calendar.
  • time broken: Broken--down time.
  • time hiaccu: High accuracy clock.
  • time format: Formatting broken--down time.
  • time parsing: Parsing time strings.
  • time alarm: Setting time alarms.
  • time sleep: Sleeping.

Next: time structs, Up: time

6.1 Introduction

Time handling is a complex topic, so we really want to read some discussion on it; for example the introduction in the GNU C Library documentation. Time Basics.

About the time_t type

The time_t type is used by several functions, but it is not fully specified2; it represents the epoch: The number of seconds elapsed since 00:00:00 on January 1, 1970, Coordinated Universal Time.

To solve the representation problem, time_t values are casted to native double values and then converted to Scheme inexact real numbers, whatever they are for the underlying Scheme representation.

Next: time typedefs, Previous: time intro, Up: time

6.2 Data structures

Unless otherwise specified, the bindings documented in this section are exported by the (posix sizeof) library.

  • time structs timeval: struct timeval inspection.
  • time structs timespec: struct timespec inspection.
  • time structs tms: struct tms inspection.
  • time structs timezone: struct timezone inspection.
  • time structs tm: struct tm inspection.
  • time structs ntptimeval: struct ntptimeval inspection.
  • time structs timex: struct timex inspection.
  • time structs itimerval: struct itimerval inspection.

Next: time structs timespec, Up: time structs

6.2.1 struct timeval inspection

— Constant: sizeof-timeval
— Constant: alignof-timeval
— Constant: strideof-timeval

These are: the number of bytes required to hold a struct timeval; the alignment of this structure when embedded into another structure; the number of bytes between two elements in an array of these structures.

— Syntax: struct-timeval-tv_sec-ref pointer
— Syntax: struct-timeval-tv_sec-set! pointer value
— Syntax: struct-timeval-tv_usec-ref pointer
— Syntax: struct-timeval-tv_usec-set! pointer value

Accessors and mutators for the fields of a struct timeval.

Next: time structs tms, Previous: time structs timeval, Up: time structs

6.2.2 struct timespec inspection

— Constant: sizeof-timespec
— Constant: alignof-timespec
— Constant: strideof-timespec

These are: the number of bytes required to hold a struct timespec; the alignment of this structure when embedded into another structure; the number of bytes between two elements in an array of these structures.

— Syntax: struct-timespec-tv_sec-set! pointer value
— Syntax: struct-timespec-tv_sec-ref pointer
— Syntax: struct-timespec-tv_nsec-set! pointer value
— Syntax: struct-timespec-tv_nsec-ref pointer

Accessors and mutators for the fields of a struct timespec.

Next: time structs timezone, Previous: time structs timespec, Up: time structs

6.2.3 struct tms inspection

— Constant: sizeof-tms
— Constant: alignof-tms
— Constant: strideof-tms

These are: the number of bytes required to hold a struct tms; the alignment of this structure when embedded into another structure; the number of bytes between two elements in an array of these structures.

— Function: struct-tms-tms_utime-ref pointer
— Function: struct-tms-tms_utime-set! pointer value
— Function: struct-tms-tms_stime-ref pointer
— Function: struct-tms-tms_stime-set! pointer value
— Function: struct-tms-tms_cutime-ref pointer
— Function: struct-tms-tms_cutime-set! pointer value
— Function: struct-tms-tms_cstime-ref pointer
— Function: struct-tms-tms_cstime-set! pointer value

Accessors for the fields of a struct tms type.

These bindings are exported by the (posix time platform) library.

Next: time structs tm, Previous: time structs tms, Up: time structs

6.2.4 struct timezone inspection

— Constant: sizeof-timezone
— Constant: alignof-timezone
— Constant: strideof-timezone

These are: the number of bytes required to hold a struct timezone; the alignment of this structure when embedded into another structure; the number of bytes between two elements in an array of these structures.

— Syntax: struct-timezone-tz_minuteswest-ref pointer
— Syntax: struct-timezone-tz_minuteswest-set! pointer value
— Syntax: struct-timezone-tz_dsttime-ref pointer
— Syntax: struct-timezone-tz_dsttime-set! pointer value

Peekers and pokers for the fields of a struct timezone.

Next: time structs ntptimeval, Previous: time structs timezone, Up: time structs

6.2.5 struct tm inspection

— Variable: sizeof-tm
— Variable: alignof-tm
— Variable: strideof-tm

These are: the number of bytes required to hold a struct tm; the alignment of this structure when embedded into another structure; the number of bytes between two elements in an array of these structures.

— Syntax: struct-tm-tm_sec-ref pointer
— Syntax: struct-tm-tm_sec-set! pointer value
— Syntax: struct-tm-tm_min-ref pointer
— Syntax: struct-tm-tm_min-set! pointer value
— Syntax: struct-tm-tm_hour-ref pointer
— Syntax: struct-tm-tm_hour-set! pointer value
— Syntax: struct-tm-tm_mday-ref pointer
— Syntax: struct-tm-tm_mday-set! pointer value
— Syntax: struct-tm-tm_mon-ref pointer
— Syntax: struct-tm-tm_mon-set! pointer value
— Syntax: struct-tm-tm_year-ref pointer
— Syntax: struct-tm-tm_year-set! pointer value

— Syntax: struct-tm-tm_wday-set! pointer value
— Syntax: struct-tm-tm_yday-ref pointer
— Syntax: struct-tm-tm_yday-set! pointer value
— Syntax: struct-tm-tm_isdst-ref pointer
— Syntax: struct-tm-tm_isdst-set! pointer value

6.2.6 struct ntptimeval inspection

— Variable: sizeof-ntptimeval
— Variable: alignof-ntptimeval
— Variable: strideof-ntptimeval

These are: the number of bytes required to hold a struct ntptimeval; the alignment of this structure when embedded into another structure; the number of bytes between two elements in an array of these structures.

— Syntax: struct-ntptimeval-time-ref pointer

Given a pointer to a struct ntptimeval instance, evaluates to a pointer to the first byte of the struct timeval time field of the structure.

— Syntax: struct-ntptimeval-maxerror-ref pointer
— Syntax: struct-ntptimeval-maxerror-set! pointer value
— Syntax: struct-ntptimeval-esterror-ref pointer
— Syntax: struct-ntptimeval-esterror-set! pointer value

Accessors and mutators for the fields of a struct ntptimeval type.

Next: time structs itimerval, Previous: time structs ntptimeval, Up: time structs

6.2.7 struct timex inspection

The following bindings implement inspection for the struct timex type. High Accuracy Clock.

— Variable: sizeof-timex
— Variable: alignof-timex
— Variable: strideof-timex

These are: the number of bytes required to hold a struct timex; the alignment of this structure when embedded into another structure; the number of bytes between two elements in an array of these structures.

— Syntax: struct-timex-time-ref pointer

Given a pointer to a struct timex instance, evaluates to a pointer to the first byte of the struct timeval time field of the structure.

— Syntax: struct-timex-modes-ref pointer
— Syntax: struct-timex-modes-set! pointer value
— Syntax: struct-timex-offset-ref pointer
— Syntax: struct-timex-offset-set! pointer value
— Syntax: struct-timex-freq-ref pointer
— Syntax: struct-timex-freq-set! pointer value
— Syntax: struct-timex-maxerror-ref pointer
— Syntax: struct-timex-maxerror-set! pointer value
— Syntax: struct-timex-esterror-ref pointer
— Syntax: struct-timex-esterror-set! pointer value
— Syntax: struct-timex-status-ref pointer
— Syntax: struct-timex-status-set! pointer value
— Syntax: struct-timex-constant-ref pointer
— Syntax: struct-timex-constant-set! pointer value
— Syntax: struct-timex-precision-ref pointer
— Syntax: struct-timex-precision-set! pointer value
— Syntax: struct-timex-tolerance-ref pointer
— Syntax: struct-timex-tolerance-set! pointer value

— Syntax: struct-timex-tick-set! pointer value

— Syntax: struct-timex-ppsfreq-set! pointer value
— Syntax: struct-timex-jitter-ref pointer
— Syntax: struct-timex-jitter-set! pointer value
— Syntax: struct-timex-shift-ref pointer
— Syntax: struct-timex-shift-set! pointer value
— Syntax: struct-timex-stabil-ref pointer
— Syntax: struct-timex-stabil-set! pointer value
— Syntax: struct-timex-jitcnt-ref pointer
— Syntax: struct-timex-jitcnt-set! pointer value
