6.2.8 struct itimerval inspection

The following bindings implement inspection for the struct itimerval type. Setting an Alarm.

— Variable: sizeof-itimerval
— Variable: alignof-itimerval
— Variable: strideof-itimerval

These are: the number of bytes required to hold a struct itimerval; the alignment of this structure when embedded into another structure; the number of bytes between two elements in an array of these structures.

— Syntax: struct-itimerval-it_value-ref pointer
— Syntax: struct-itimerval-it_interval-ref pointer

Given a pointer to a struct itimerval instance, evaluate to a pointer to the first byte of the struct timeval it_interval and struct timeval it_value fields of the structure.

Next: time records, Previous: time structs, Up: time

6.3 Object type definitions

Unless otherwise specified, the bindings described in this section are exported by the (posix typedefs) library.

  • time typedefs timeval: Wrapper for struct timeval.

Up: time typedefs

6.3.1 Wrapper for struct timeval

The following object type is different from the <timeval> record type. struct timeval mirror.

— Object Type: struct-timeval

Object type used to wrap pointers to struct timeval C language data structures. It is disjoint from the other Scheme object types.

— Function: struct-timeval? obj

Return true if obj is of type struct-timeval.

— Function: pointer->struct-timeval pointer
— Function: struct-timeval->pointer timeval

Convert between pointer objects and struct-timeval objects.

— Function: make-struct-timeval malloc

Build and return a new struct-timeval object referencing a newly allocated struct timeval.

Memory for the foreign structure is allocated with the malloc function, whose interface protocol must match the one of malloc from the (foreign memory) library. Exception raising functions.

Next: time constants, Previous: time typedefs, Up: time

6.4 Record types

Unless otherwise specified, the bindings described in this section are exported by the (posix typedefs) library.

  • time records timeval: struct timeval mirror.
  • time records timespec: struct timespec mirror.
  • time records tms: struct tms mirror.
  • time records timezone: struct timezone mirror.
  • time records tm: struct tm mirror.
  • time records ntptimeval: struct ntptimeval mirror.
  • time records timex: struct timex mirror.
  • time records itimerval: struct itimerval mirror.

Next: time records timespec, Up: time records

6.4.1 struct timeval mirror

The record type described here is used to mirror the C language data type struct timeval. Elapsed Time.

This record type is different from the struct-timeval object. Wrapper for struc timeval.

— Record Type Name: <timeval>
— Record Type Descriptor: <timeval-rtd>

Record type that mirrors the struct timeval type. It has the following fields, one for each field of the struct timeval type: sec, usec.

— Function: make-<timeval> tv_sec tv_usec
— Function: <timeval>? obj

Constructor and predicate for <timeval> records.

— Function: <timeval>-sec timeval-record
— Function: <timeval>-sec-set! timeval-record value
— Function: <timeval>-usec timeval-record
— Function: <timeval>-usec-set! timeval-record value

Accessors and mutators <timeval> records.

— Function: pointer-><timeval> struct-timeval-pointer
— Function: <timeval>->pointer timeval-record malloc

Convert between a pointer to a struct timeval instance and a record of type <timeval>.

Memory for the foreign structure is allocated with the malloc function, whose interface protocol must match the one of malloc from the (foreign memory) library. Exception raising functions.

These bindings are exported by the (posix time primitives) library.

Next: time records tms, Previous: time records timeval, Up: time records

6.4.2 struct timespec mirror

The record type described here is used to mirror the C language data type struct timespec. Elapsed Time.

— Record Type Name: <timespec>
— Record Type Descriptor: <timespec-rtd>

Record type that mirrors the struct timespec type. It has the following fields, one for each field of the struct timespec type: sec, nsec.

— Function: make-<timespec> tv_sec tv_nsec
— Function: <timespec>? obj

Constructor and predicate for <timespec> records.

— Function: <timespec>-sec timespec-record
— Function: <timespec>-sec-set! timespec-record value
— Function: <timespec>-nsec timespec-record
— Function: <timespec>-nsec-set! timespec-record value

Accessors and mutators <timespec> records.

— Function: pointer-><timespec> struct-timespec-pointer
— Function: <timespec>->pointer timespec-record malloc

Convert between a pointer to a struct timespec instance and a record of type <timespec>.

Memory for the foreign structure is allocated with the malloc function, whose interface protocol must match the one of malloc from the (foreign memory) library. Exception raising functions.

These bindings are exported by the (posix glibc primitives) library.

Next: time records timezone, Previous: time records timespec, Up: time records

6.4.3 struct tms mirror

The record type described here is used to mirror the C language data type struct tms. Processor Time Inquiry.

— Record Type Name: <tms>
— Record Type Descriptor: <tms-rtd>

A Scheme record used to hold normalised results of times invocations. It has the following fields, one for each field of the struct tms type: utime, stime, cutime, cstime; all the values are inexact real numbers.

— Function: make-<tms> utime stime cutime cstime
— Function: <tms>? obj

Constructor and predicate for records of type <tms>.

— Function: <tms>-utime tms
— Function: <tms>-utime-set! tms value
— Function: <tms>-stime tms
— Function: <tms>-stime-set! tms value
— Function: <tms>-cutime tms
— Function: <tms>-cutime-set! tms value
— Function: <tms>-cstime tms
— Function: <tms>-cstime-set! tms value

Accessors and mutators for <tms> records.

— Function: pointer-><tms> pointer
— Function: <tms>->pointer record malloc

Convert between a pointer to a struct tms instance and a record of type <tms>.

Memory for the foreign structure is allocated with the malloc function, whose interface protocol must match the one of malloc from the (foreign memory) library. Exception raising functions.

These bindings are exported by the (posix time primitives) library.

Next: time records tm, Previous: time records tms, Up: time records

6.4.4 struct timezone mirror

The record type described here is used to mirror the C language data type struct timezone. High–Resolution Calendar.

— Record Type Name: <timezone>
— Record Type Descriptor: <timezone-rtd>

Record type that mirrors the struct timezone type. It has the following fields, one for each field in the struct timezone type: minuteswest, dsttime.

— Function: make-<timezone> tz_minuteswest tz_dsttime
— Function: <timezone>? obj

Constructor and predicate for <timezone> records.

— Function: <timezone>-minuteswest timezone-record
— Function: <timezone>-minuteswest-set! timezone-record value
— Function: <timezone>-dsttime timezone-record
— Function: <timezone>-dsttime-set! timezone-record value

Accessors and mutators <timezone> records.

— Function: pointer-><timezone> struct-timezone-pointer
— Function: <timezone>->pointer timezone-record malloc

Convert between a pointer to a struct timezone instance and a record of type <timezone>.

Memory for the foreign structure is allocated with the malloc function, whose interface protocol must match the one of malloc from the (foreign memory) library. Exception raising functions.

These bindings are exported by the (posix glibc primitives) library.

Next: time records ntptimeval, Previous: time records timezone, Up: time records

6.4.5 struct tm mirror

The record type described here is used to mirror the C language data type struct tm. Broken–down Time.

— Record Type Name: <tm>
— Record Type Descriptor: <tm-rtd>

Record type that mirrors the struct tm type. It has the following fields, one for each field in the struct tm type: sec, min, hour, mday, mon, year, wday, yday, isdst, gmtoff, zone.

Notice that the zone field is meant to hold a pointer to a C string.

— Function: make-<tm> tm_sec tm_min tm_hour tm_mday tm_mon tm_year tm_wday tm_yday tm_isdst tm_gmtoff tm_zone
— Function: <tm>? obj

Constructor and predicate for <tm> records.

— Function: <tm>-sec tm-record
— Function: <tm>-sec-set! tm-record value
— Function: <tm>-min tm-record
— Function: <tm>-min-set! tm-record value
— Function: <tm>-hour tm-record
— Function: <tm>-hour-set! tm-record value
— Function: <tm>-mday tm-record
— Function: <tm>-mday-set! tm-record value
— Function: <tm>-mon tm-record
— Function: <tm>-mon-set! tm-record value
— Function: <tm>-year tm-record
— Function: <tm>-year-set! tm-record value
— Function: <tm>-wday tm-record
— Function: <tm>-wday-set! tm-record value
— Function: <tm>-yday tm-record
— Function: <tm>-yday-set! tm-record value
— Function: <tm>-isdst tm-record
— Function: <tm>-isdst-set! tm-record value
— Function: <tm>-gmtoff tm-record
— Function: <tm>-gmtoff-set! tm-record value
— Function: <tm>-zone tm-record
— Function: <tm>-zone-set! tm-record value

Accessors and mutators <tm> records.

— Function: pointer-><tm> struct-tm-pointer
— Function: <tm>->pointer tm-record malloc

Convert between a pointer to a struct tm instance and a record of type <tm>.

Memory for the foreign structure is allocated with the malloc function, whose interface protocol must match the one of malloc from the (foreign memory) library. Exception raising functions.

Notice that no conversion is performed on the value in the zone field; we have to explicitly convert between C strings and Scheme strings.

These bindings are exported by the (posix glibc primitives) library.

Next: time records timex, Previous: time records tm, Up: time records

6.4.6 struct ntptimeval mirror

The record type described here is used to mirror the C language data type struct ntptimeval. High Accuracy Clock.

— Record Type Name: <ntptimeval>
— Record Type Descriptor: <ntptimeval-rtd>

Record type that mirrors the struct ntptimeval type. It has the following fields, one for each field in the struct ntptimeval type: time, maxerror, esterror. The time field contains a <timeval> record.

— Function: make-<ntptimeval> time, maxerror, esterror
— Function: <ntptimeval>? obj

Constructor and predicate for <ntptimeval> records.

— Function: <ntptimeval>-time pointer
— Function: <ntptimeval>-time-set! pointer value
— Function: <ntptimeval>-maxerror pointer
— Function: <ntptimeval>-maxerror-set! pointer value
— Function: <ntptimeval>-esterror pointer
— Function: <ntptimeval>-esterror-set! pointer value

Accessors and mutators <ntptimeval> records.

— Function: pointer-><ntptimeval> struct-ntptimeval-pointer
— Function: <ntptimeval>->pointer ntptimeval-record malloc

Convert between a pointer to a struct ntptimeval instance and a record of type <ntptimeval>.

Memory for the foreign structure is allocated with the malloc function, whose interface protocol must match the one of malloc from the (foreign memory) library. Exception raising functions.

These bindings are exported by the (posix glibc primitives) library.

Next: time records itimerval, Previous: time records ntptimeval, Up: time records

6.4.7 struct timex mirror

The record type described here is used to mirror the C language data type struct timex. High Accuracy Clock.

— Record Type Name: <timex>
— Record Type Descriptor: <timex-rtd>

Record type that mirrors the struct timex type. It has the following fields, one for each field in the struct timex type: modes, offset, freq, maxerror, esterror, status, constant, precision, tolerance, time, tick, ppsfreq, jitter, shift, stabil, jitcnt, calcnt, errcnt, stbcnt. The time field contains a <timeval> record.

— Function: <timex>-modes pointer
— Function: <timex>-modes-set! pointer value
— Function: <timex>-offset pointer
— Function: <timex>-offset-set! pointer value
— Function: <timex>-freq pointer
— Function: <timex>-freq-set! pointer value
— Function: <timex>-maxerror pointer
— Function: <timex>-maxerror-set! pointer value
— Function: <timex>-esterror pointer
— Function: <timex>-esterror-set! pointer value
— Function: <timex>-status pointer
— Function: <timex>-status-set! pointer value
— Function: <timex>-constant pointer
— Function: <timex>-constant-set! pointer value
— Function: <timex>-precision pointer
— Function: <timex>-precision-set! pointer value
— Function: <timex>-tolerance pointer
— Function: <timex>-tolerance-set! pointer value
— Function: <timex>-time pointer
— Function: <timex>-time-set! pointer value
— Function: <timex>-tick pointer
— Function: <timex>-tick-set! pointer value
— Function: <timex>-ppsfreq pointer
— Function: <timex>-ppsfreq-set! pointer value
— Function: <timex>-jitter pointer
— Function: <timex>-jitter-set! pointer value
— Function: <timex>-shift pointer
— Function: <timex>-shift-set! pointer value
— Function: <timex>-stabil pointer
— Function: <timex>-stabil-set! pointer value
— Function: <timex>-jitcnt pointer
— Function: <timex>-jitcnt-set! pointer value
— Function: <timex>-calcnt pointer
— Function: <timex>-calcnt-set! pointer value
— Function: <timex>-errcnt pointer
— Function: <timex>-errcnt-set! pointer value
— Function: <timex>-stbcnt pointer
— Function: <timex>-stbcnt-set! pointer value

Accessors and mutators <timex> records.

— Function: make-<timex> modes offset freq maxerror esterror status constant precision tolerance time tick ppsfreq jitter shift stabil jitcnt calcnt errcnt stbcnt
— Function: <timex>? obj

Constructor and predicate for <timex> records.

These bindings are exported by the (posix glibc primitives) library.

— Function: pointer-><timex> struct-timex-pointer
— Function: <timex>->pointer timex-record malloc

Convert between a pointer to a struct timex instance and a record of type <timex>.

Memory for the foreign structure is allocated with the malloc function, whose interface protocol must match the one of malloc from the (foreign memory) library. Exception raising functions.

These bindings are exported by the (posix glibc primitives) library.

Previous: time records timex, Up: time records

6.4.8 struct itimerval mirror

The record type described here is used to mirror the C language data type struct itimerval. Setting an Alarm.

— Record Type Name: <itimerval>
— Record Type Descriptor: <itimerval-rtd>

Record type that mirrors the struct itimerval type. It has the following fields, one for each field in the struct itimerval type: interval, value. Both the fields contain a <timeval> record.

— Function: make-<itimerval> interval value
— Function: <itimerval>? obj

Constructor and predicate for <itimerval> records.

— Function: <itimerval>-interval pointer
— Function: <itimerval>-interval-set! pointer value
— Function: <itimerval>-value pointer
— Function: <itimerval>-value-set! pointer value

Accessors and mutators <itimerval> records.

— Function: pointer-><itimerval> struct-itimerval-pointer
— Function: <itimerval>->pointer itimerval-record malloc

Convert between a pointer to a struct itimerval instance and a record of type <itimerval>.

Memory for the foreign structure is allocated with the malloc function, whose interface protocol must match the one of malloc from the (foreign memory) library. Exception raising functions.

These bindings are exported by the (posix glibc primitives) library.

Next: time clock, Previous: time records, Up: time

6.5 Constant values

The following bindings are exported by the sizeof library.

— Constant: CLOCKS_PER_SEC

The number of clock ticks per second measured by the clock function.

— Constant: ITIMER_REAL
— Constant: ITIMER_VIRTUAL
— Constant: ITIMER_PROF

Timer selection for setitimer.

Next: time calendar, Previous: time constants, Up: time

6.6 Processor time

The following functions handle processor time. CPU Time Inquiry. Processor Time Inquiry.

— Function: clock
— Parameter: clock-function
— Function: primitive:clock
— Function: platform:clock

Return the calling process' current CPU time, casted to a native double number and then to a Scheme inexact real number.

— Function: times
— Parameter: times-function
— Function: primitive:times
— Function: platform:times pointer

Return two values: the return value from the times() call casted to a native double number and then to a Scheme inexact real number; a record of type <tms>.

Next: time hires, Previous: time clock, Up: time

6.7 Simple calendar time

The following functions deal with simple calendar time. Simple Calendar Time.

— Function: time
— Parameter: time-function
— Function: primitive:time
— Function: platform:time

Return the current calendar time represented by a time_t value, casted to a native double value and then converted to a Scheme inexact real number. It is the epoch: the number of seconds elapsed since 00:00:00 on January 1, 1970, Coordinated Universal Time.

These bindings are exported by the POSIX time libraries.

— Function: stime calendar-time
— Parameter: stime-function
— Function: primitive:stime calendar-time
— Function: platform:stime calendar-time-double

Set the system clock using a calendar time specification. Superuser privileges are needed to successfully call this function.

calendar-time must be a Scheme inexact real number, which is converted to a native double and finally casted to a time_t value.

These bindings are exported by the Glibc time libraries.

Next: time broken, Previous: time calendar, Up: time

6.8 High–resolution calendar

The following functions manage high–resolution calendar time; the bindings are exported by the Glibc time libraries. High–Resolution Calendar.

— Function: gettimeofday
— Parameter: gettimeofday-function
— Function: primitive:gettimeofday
— Function: platform:gettimeofday timeval-ptr timezone-ptr

Build and return two values: a record of type <timeval>, a record of type <timezone>; they represent the current time.

— Function: settimeofday timeval timezone
— Parameter: settimeofday-function
— Function: primitive:settimeofday timeval timezone
— Function: platform:settimeofday timeval-ptr timezone-ptr

Set the system clock to the calendar time specified by the timeval and timezone arguments, which must be a <timeval> record and a <timezone> record.

Super user privileges are needed to successfully call this function.

— Function: adjtime timeval-delta
— Parameter: adjtime-function
— Function: primitive:adjtime timeval-delta
— Function: platform:adjtime timeval-delta-ptr timeval-old-delta-ptr

Speed up or slow down the system clock in order to make a gradual adjustment maintaining a monotonic clock value. The time delta is described by timeval-delta, which must be a record of type <timeval>.

The adjtime and primitive:adjtime functions return two values: the return value from the foreign function and a record of type <timeval-delta> describing any previous time adjustment that has yet not completed.

Super user privileges are needed to successfully call this function.

Next: time hiaccu, Previous: time hires, Up: time

6.9 Broken–down time

The following functions manage broken–down time; unless otherwise specified, the bindings are exported by the Glibc time libraries. Broken–down Time.

— Function: localtime time malloc
— Parameter: localtime-function
— Function: primitive:localtime time malloc
— Function: platform:localtime_r time tm-pointer

Allocate a new struct tm instance, then fill it with broken–down values from the calendar time (which can be the return value of time). The return value is the pointer to the struct tm instance (see below about how to get a <tm> record).

Memory for the foreign structure is allocated with the malloc function, whose interface protocol must match the one of malloc from the (foreign memory) library. Exception raising functions.

Despite the names, these functions are wrappers for the localtime_r() foreign function, so they are reentrant.

For example, to get the current year: 

          (define (gimme-year)
            (with-compensations
              (let ((tm* (localtime (time) malloc-block/c)))
                (+ 1900 (struct-tm-tm_year-ref tm*)))))
— Function: localtime* time
— Parameter: localtime*-parameter
— Function: primitive:localtime* time

Wrapper for primitive:localtime which automatically converts the struct tm instance into a <tm> record and returns it. Memory is managed internally.

For example, to get the current year: 

          (define (gimme-year*)
            (+ 1900 (<tm>-year (localtime* (time)))))
— Function: gmtime time malloc
— Parameter: gmtime-function
— Function: primitive:gmtime time malloc
— Function: platform:gmtime time tm-pointer

Like localtime but converts the given time as Coordinated Universal Time (UTC).

— Function: gmtime* time
— Parameter: gmtime*-parameter
— Function: primitive:gmtime* time

Wrapper for primitive:gmtime which automatically converts the struct tm instance into a <tm> record and returns it. Memory is managed internally.

— Function: timelocal tm-pointer
— Parameter: timelocal-function
— Function: primitive:timelocal tm-pointer
— Function: platform:timelocal tm-pointer

Return a calendar time value from the struct tm referenced by tm-pointer; the returned value is a time_t casted to a native double and converted to a Scheme inexact real number. It is the inverse of localtime.

NOTE The mktime() function does the same thing of the timelocal() function; for this reason it is not exported.

— Function: timelocal* tm-record
— Parameter: timelocal*-function
— Function: primitive:timelocal* tm-record

Wrapper for primitive:timelocal which automatically converts tm-record, which must be a <tm> record, into an instance of struct tm. Memory is managed internally.

— Function: timegm tm-pointer
— Parameter: timegm-function
— Function: primitive:timegm tm-pointer
— Function: platform:timegm tm-pointer

Return a calendar time value from the struct tm referenced by tm-pointer; the returned value is a time_t casted to a native double and converted to a Scheme inexact real number. It is the inverse of gmtime.

— Function: timegm* tm-record
— Parameter: timegm*-function
— Function: primitive:timegm* tm-record

Wrapper for primitive:timegm which automatically converts tm-record, which must be a <tm> record, into an instance of struct tm. Memory is managed internally.

Next: time format, Previous: time broken, Up: time

6.10 High accuracy clock

The following functions implement an interface to the system clock; unless otherwise specified, the bindings are exported by the Glibc time libraries. High Accuracy Clock.

— Function: ntp_gettime ntptimeval-pointer
— Parameter: ntp_gettime-function
— Function: primitive:ntp_gettime ntptimeval-pointer
— Function: platform:ntp_gettime ntptimeval-pointer

Fill the struct ntptimeval instance referenced by ntptimeval-pointer with current values from the system's kernel.

— Function: ntp_gettime*
— Parameter: ntp_gettime-function
— Function: primitive:ntp_gettime*

Wrappers for primitive:ntp_gettime which automatically allocate the struct ntptimeval instance and convert it into a <ntptimeval> record; return the record.

— Function: ntp_adjtime timex-pointer
— Parameter: ntp_adjtime-function
— Function: primitive:ntp_adjtime timex-pointer
— Function: platform:ntp_adjtime timex-pointer

Set the struct timex instance referenced by timex-pointer to current values, also set some kernel values with values from the instance. See the original documentation for details.

Superuser privileges are needed to successfully call this function.

— Function: ntp_adjtime* record
— Parameter: ntp_adjtime-function
— Function: primitive:ntp_adjtime* record

Wrappers for primitive:ntp_adjtime which automatically convert the <timex> record into a struct timex instance, hand the structure to primitive:ntp_adjtime, finally convert the modified structure into a new <timex> record and return it.

The original record is not mutated.

Next: time parsing, Previous: time hiaccu, Up: time

6.11 Formatting broken–down time

The following functions format broken–down time specifications into strings; unless otherwise specified, the bindings are exported by the Glibc time libraries. Formatting Calendar Time.

— Function: asctime tm-pointer
— Parameter: asctime-function
— Function: primitive:asctime tm-pointer
— Function: platform:asctime_r tm-pointer cstr

Convert the time specification in the struct tm instance referenced by tm-pointer into a string in a standard format; return a Scheme string.

Despite the names, these are wrappers for asctime_r(), so they are reentrant.

— Function: asctime* tm-record
— Parameter: asctime*-function
— Function: primitive:asctime* tm-record

Wrappers for primitive:asctime which automatically convert the <tm> tm-record into an instance of struct tm and perform the conversion to string.

— Function: ctime calendar-time
— Parameter: ctime-function
— Function: primitive:ctime calendar-time
— Function: platform:ctime_r calendar-time cstr

Convert the time specification of calendar-time into a string in a standard format; return a Scheme string.

Despite the names, these are wrappers for ctime_r(), so they are reentrant.

— Function: strftime template tm-pointer
— Parameter: strftime-function
— Function: primitive:strftime template tm-pointer
— Function: platform:strftime output-cstr output-len template-cstr tm-pointer

Return a Scheme string representing the date and time specification described by template, which must be a Scheme string, and the struct tm instance referenced by tm-pointer.

NOTE At present the maximum length of the output string is 4095 bytes. If the time specification and template require more than that number of bytes, an error is raised.

— Function: strftime* template tm-record
— Parameter: strftime*-function
— Function: primitive:strftime* template tm-record

Wrappers for primitive:strftime which automatically convert the <tm> tm-record into an instance of struct tm, then build and return the output string.

Next: time alarm, Previous: time format, Up: time

6.12 Parsing time strings

The following functions parse strings containing time and date specifications; unless otherwise specified, the bindings are exported by the Glibc time libraries. Interpret string according to given format.

— Function: strptime input template tm-pointer
— Parameter: strptime-function
— Function: primitive:strptime input template tm-pointer
— Function: platform:strptime input-cstr template-cstr tm-pointer

Parse the input Scheme string according to the template Scheme string and store the values in the struct tm instance referenced by tm-pointer.

— Function: strptime* input template
— Parameter: strptime*-function
— Function: primitive:strptime* input template

Wrappers for primitive:strptime which allocate a struct tm instance and convert it to a <tm> record; return the record.

Before calling primitive:strptime all the integer fields of struct tm are initialised to INT_MAX and the zone field is initialised to the NULL pointer.

Next: time sleep, Previous: time parsing, Up: time

6.13 Setting time alarms

The following functions manage time alarms; unless otherwise specified, the bindings are exported by the Glibc time libraries. Setting an Alarm.

— Function: setitimer which itimerval-ptr-new itimerval-ptr-old
— Parameter: setitimer-function
— Function: primitive:setitimer which itimerval-ptr-new itimerval-ptr-old
— Function: platform:setitimer which itimerval-ptr-new itimerval-ptr-old

Set the timer specified by which according to the time specification in the struct itimerval instance referenced by the pointer itimerval-ptr-new; the old timer specification, for the selected type, is stored in the struct itimerval instance referenced by the pointer itimerval-ptr-old.

which can be one among the values bound to ITIMER_REAL, ITIMER_VIRTUAL and ITIMER_PROF.

— Function: setitimer* which new-record
— Parameter: setitimer*-function
— Function: primitive:setitimer* which new-record

Wrappers for primitive:setitimer which internally convert the <itimerval> record new-record to a struct itimerval instance and set the selected timer accordingly; the return value is a <itimerval> record representing the old specification of the selected timer.

— Function: getitimer which itimerval-ptr-old
— Parameter: getitimer-function
— Function: primitive:getitimer which itimerval-ptr-old
— Function: platform:getitimer which itimerval-ptr-old

Store, in the struct itimerval instance referenced by the pointer itimerval-ptr-old, the current timer specification for the selected type. which can be one among the values bound to ITIMER_REAL, ITIMER_VIRTUAL and ITIMER_PROF.

— Function: getitimer* which
— Parameter: getitimer*-function
— Function: primitive:getitimer* which

Wrappers for primitive:getitimer which internally allocate a struct itimerval instance, query the timer status and return a <itimerval> record.

— Function: alarm seconds
— Parameter: alarm-function
— Function: primitive:alarm seconds
— Function: platform:alarm seconds

Set the timer of type ITIMER_REAL to trigger after seconds past the call.

Previous: time alarm, Up: time

6.14 Sleeping

The following bindings halt the process for a short interval; unless otherwise specified, the bindings are exported by the Glibc time libraries. Sleeping.

— Function: sleep seconds
— Function: primitive:sleep seconds
— Function: platform:sleep seconds

Halt the process for seconds; return after the elapsed time or if a signal is received. The return value is zero if the time is elapsed or, if a signal is received, the number of seconds still to wait.

— Function: nanosleep requested-timespec-ptr remaining-timespec-ptr
— Parameter: nanosleep-function
— Function: primitive:nanosleep requested-timespec-ptr remaining-timespec-ptr
— Function: platform:nanosleep requested-timespec-ptr remaining-timespec-ptr

Halt the process for the time specified in the struct timespec instance referenced by the requested-timespec-ptr pointer; return after the elapsed time or if a signal is received. Store in the struct timespec instance referenced by the pointer remaining-timespec-ptr the remaining time.

— Function: nanosleep* requested
— Parameter: nanosleep*-function
— Function: primitive:nanosleep* requested

Wrappers for primitive:nanosleep which internally convert the <timespec> record requested in a struct timespec instance, halt the process and return the remaining time in a <timespec> record.

Next: users, Previous: time, Up: Top

7 Processes

Unless otherwise specified, the bindings described in this chapter are exported by the following libraries: 

     (posix process)
     (posix process primitives)
     (posix process platform)
  • process typedefs: Object type defintions.
  • process id: Process identification.
  • process fork: Creating a process.
  • process exec: Executing a file.
  • process wait: Process completion.
  • process job: Job control.

Next: process id, Up: process

7.1 Object type defintions

Unless otherwise specified, the bindings described in this section are exported by the (posix typedefs) library.

  • process typedefs pid: Process identifier.
  • process typedefs status: Process termination status.

Next: process typedefs status, Up: process typedefs

7.1.1 Process identifier

Functions in the parametrised and primitives libraries accept pid objects as values for the pid arguments. Functions in the platform libraries accept exact integers as values for the pid-int arguments.

— Object Type: pid

Object type used to represent a process identifier. It is disjoint from all the other Scheme object types.

— Function: pid? obj

Return #t if obj is a pid object.

— Function: pid->integer pid
— Function: integer->pid integer

Convert between pid object and exact integers.

— Function: pid-zero? obj

Return #t if obj is a pid object and its integer value is zero.

— Function: pid=? pid1 pid2
— Function: pid<? pid1 pid2
— Function: pid<=? pid1 pid2
— Function: pid>? pid1 pid2
— Function: pid>=? pid1 pid2
— Function: pid<>? pid1 pid2

Comparison operators for pid objects; they work like their counterparts for integer values. pid<>? stands for “not equal”.

Previous: process typedefs pid, Up: process typedefs

7.1.2 Process termination status

— Record Type Name: <process-term-status>
— Record Type Descriptor: <process-term-status-rtd>

Record type describing the details of a process termination. Process Completion Status. It has the following immutable fields: 

          WIFEXITED               WEXITSTATUS
          WIFSIGNALED             WTERMSIG
          WCOREDUMP               WIFSTOPPED
          WSTOPSIG
— Function: make-<process-term-status> WIFEXITED WEXITSTATUS WIFSIGNALED WTERMSIG WCOREDUMP WIFSTOPPED WSTOPSIG
— Function: <process-term-status>? obj

Constructor and predicate for records of type <process-term-status>.

— Function: WIFEXITED? status-record
— Function: WEXITSTATUS? status-record
— Function: WIFSIGNALED? status-record
— Function: WTERMSIG? status-record
— Function: WCOREDUMP? status-record
— Function: WIFSTOPPED? status-record
— Function: WSTOPSIG? status-record

Field accessors for records of type <process-term-status>. The values are all booleans.

Next: process fork, Previous: process typedefs, Up: process

7.2 Process identification

The following functions inspect the process identifier. Process Identification

— Function: getpid
— Parameter: getpid-function
— Function: primitive:getpid
— Function: platform:getpid

Return a pid object representing the identifier of the current process. This function cannot fail, so platform:getpid returns a single value: the return value from the foreign function.

— Function: getppid
— Parameter: getppid-function
— Function: primitive:getppid
— Function: platform:getppid

Return a pid object representing the identifier of the parent process. This function cannot fail, so platform:getppid returns a single value: the return value from the foreign function.

Next: process exec, Previous: process id, Up: process

7.3 Creating a process

The following functions manage process forking. Creating a Process.

NOTE Access to vfork() is not implemented because it is impossible to know what the underlying Scheme implementation does.
— Function: fork
— Parameter: fork-function
— Function: primitive:fork
— Function: platform:fork

Create a new process by forking the current one. If successful fork returns #f in the child process and a pid object representing the child process' id in the parent process.

Next: process wait, Previous: process fork, Up: process

7.4 Executing a file

The following functions manage process execution. Executing a File.

— Function: execv pathname args
— Parameter: execv-function
— Function: primitive:execv pathname args
— Function: platform:execv pathname-cstr argv

Execute the file selected by the Scheme string or symbol pathname using the list of Scheme strings or symbols args as command line arguments. By convention the first value of args must be the name (with no directory pathname) of the executed process. If successful a new process is executed and these functions do not return.

Usage example: 

          (unless (fork)
            (execv '/bin/ls '(ls "-l" /bin)))

notice that command line options like -l have to be strings (not symbols) to prevent a syntax error (because the first char ‘-’ is reserved for numeric datums).

— Function: execve pathname args envs
— Parameter: execve-function
— Function: primitive:execve pathname args envs
— Function: platform:execve pathname-cstr argv envv

Execute the file selected by the Scheme string or symbol pathname using the list of Scheme strings or symbols args as command line arguments. By convention the first value of args must be the name (with no directory part) of the executed process.

envs must be a list of Scheme strings or symbols used to set the process execution environment.

If successful a new process is executed and these functions do not return.

Usage example: 

          (unless (fork)
            (execve '/usr/bin/du
                    '(du /bin/ls)
                    '("BLOCK_SIZE=human-readable")))

notice that command line options like -l have to be strings (not symbols) to prevent a syntax error (because the first char ‘-’ is reserved for numeric datums).

— Function: execvp pathname args
— Parameter: execvp-function
— Function: primitive:execvp pathname args
— Function: platform:execvp pathname-str argv

These functions are like the execv ones, except that pathname can be the name of a file that is searched in the current PATH search path.

— Function: system command
— Parameter: system-function
— Function: primitive:system command
— Function: platform:system command-cstr

Run command using the system shell.

Next: process job, Previous: process exec, Up: process

7.5 Process completion

The following functions manage waiting for spawned processes. Process Completion.

— Function: waitpid pid options
— Parameter: waitpid-function
— Function: primitive:waitpid pid options
— Function: platform:waitpid pid-int pointer options

Wait for a single process or a set of processes in a group; return two values: the return value from the foreign function embedded in a pid object; the process termination status.

For the full documentation we have to refer to the documentation of the foreign function waitpid().

The options argument can be zero or a bitwise-ior of WNOHANG, WUNTRACED and WCONTINUED which are exported by the library (posix sizeof).

The returned process–termination status is in the form of an exact integer; such integer can be analysed with the functions documented below and other functions described in Object type definitions.

— Function: waitpid/any options

A wrapper for watipid that tracks all the child processes.

— Function: waitpid/any-my-group options

A wrapper for watipid that tracks all the child processes in the same group of the caller.

— Function: waitpid/group gpid options

A wrapper for watipid that tracks all the child processes in the group with id gpid.

— Function: integer-><process-term-status> status
— Function: primitive:integer-><process-term-status> status

Given the exact integer status representing a process' termination status, build and return a record of type <process-term-status>.

— Function: platform:WIFEXITED status
— Function: platform:WEXITSTATUS status
— Function: platform:WIFSIGNALED status
— Function: platform:WTERMSIG status
— Function: platform:WCOREDUMP status
— Function: platform:WIFSTOPPED status
— Function: platform:WSTOPSIG status

These are wrappers for the macros that extract a value from the status integer returned by the waitpid functions. They can be used to query the status without building a record.

Previous: process wait, Up: process

7.6 Job control

  • process job terminal: Terminal identification.
  • process job group: Process group functions.
  • process job access: Terminal access.

Next: process job group, Up: process job

7.6.1 Terminal identification

The following functions manage identification of the terminal of the process. Identifying the Controlling Terminal.

— Function: ctermid
— Parameter: ctermid-function
— Function: primitive:ctermid
— Function: platform:ctermid pointer

Return a string representing the pathname of the controlling terminal for this process.

pointer can be pointer-null or a pointer to a buffer of L_ctermid bytes in which the foreign function will store the terminal file pathname as a C string. L_ctermid is exported by (posix sizeof).

Next: process job access, Previous: process job terminal, Up: process job

7.6.2 Process group functions

The following functions manage process groups and sessions. Process Group Functions.

— Function: setsid
— Parameter: setsid-function
— Function: primitive:setsid
— Function: platform:setsid

Create a new session and return a pid object representing the new process group id.

— Function: getsid pid
— Parameter: getsid-function
— Function: primitive:getsid pid
— Function: platform:getsid pid-int

Return a pid object representing the group id of the session leader of the process with pid.

— Function: getpgrp
— Parameter: getpgrp-function
— Function: primitive:getpgrp
— Function: platform:getpgrp

Return a pid object representing the process group id of the group to which the current process belongs.

— Function: setpgid pid pgid
— Parameter: setpgid-function
— Function: primitive:setpgid pid pgid
— Function: platform:setpgid pid-int pgid-int

Put the process pid in the group pgid.

Previous: process job group, Up: process job

7.6.3 Terminal access

The following functions manage process access to the controlling terminal. Functions for Controlling Terminal Access.

— Function: tcgetpgrp fd
— Parameter: tcgetpgrp-function
— Function: primitive:tcgetpgrp fd
— Function: platform:tcgetpgrp fd-int

Return a pid object representing the process group id of the foreground process group associated with the terminal open on descriptor fd.

— Function: tcsetpgrp fd pgid
— Parameter: tcsetpgrp-function
— Function: primitive:tcsetpgrp fd pgid
— Function: platform:tcsetpgrp fd-int pgid-int

Set a terminal's foreground process group id.

— Function: tcgetsid fd
— Parameter: tcgetsid-function
— Function: primitive:tcgetsid fd
— Function: platform:tcgetsid fd-int

Return a pid object representing the process group id of the session for which the file descriptor fd is the controlling terminal.

Next: signals, Previous: process, Up: Top

8 Users and groups

Unless otherwise specified, the bindings described in this chapter are exported by the following libraries: 

     (posix system)
     (posix system primitives)
     (posix system platform)
  • users typedefs: Object type definitions.
  • users accessors: Retrieving user and group identifiers.
  • users mutators: Changing user and group identifiers.
  • users login: Retrieving user login names.
  • users userdb: Users database.
  • users groupdb: Groups database.

Next: users accessors, Up: users

8.1 Object type definitions

The bindings documented in this section are exported by the (posix typedefs) library.

  • users typedefs uid: User identifiers.
  • users typedefs gid: Group identifiers.
  • users typedefs passwd: User informations.
  • users typedefs groups: Groups informations.

Next: users typedefs gid, Up: users typedefs

8.1.1 User identifiers

Functions from the primitives and high–level libraries accept objects of type uid as values for the uid arguments; functions from the platform libraries accept exact integers as representing user identifiers.

— Object Type: uid

Type of user identifiers. It is disjoint from all the other Scheme object types.

— Function: uid? obj

Return true if obj is of type uid.

— Function: uid->integer uid
— Function: integer->uid integer

Convert between uid objects and integer objects.

— Function: uid=? uid1 uid2

Return #t if the two uid objects represent the same user identifier.

Next: users typedefs passwd, Previous: users typedefs uid, Up: users typedefs

8.1.2 Group identifiers

Functions from the primitives and high–level libraries accept objects of type gid as values for the gid arguments; functions from the platform libraries accept exact integers as representing group identifiers.

— Object Type: gid

Type of user identifiers. It is disjoint from all the other Scheme object types.

— Function: gid? obj

Return true if obj is of type gid.

— Function: gid->integer gid
— Function: integer->gid integer

Convert between gid objects and integer objects.

— Function: gid=? gid1 gid2

Return #t if the two gid objects represent the same group identifier.

Next: users typedefs groups, Previous: users typedefs gid, Up: users typedefs

8.1.3 User informations

— Record Type Name: <passwd>
— Record Type Descriptor: <passwd-rtd>

Record type that mirrors struct passwd C language data structures. It has the following mutable fields:

name
Scheme string representing the user's name.
passwd
Scheme string representing the password field content.
uid
A uid object representing the user's identifier.
gid
A gid object representing the user's group identifier.
gecos
A Scheme string representing the user's real name and possibly other informations.
dir
A Scheme string representing the user's home directory or initial working directory. It can be #f.
shell
A Scheme string representing the user's default shell. It can be #f.

— Function: make-<passwd> name passwd uid gid gecos dir shell
— Function: <passwd>? obj

Constructor and predicate for records of type <passwd>.

— Function: <passwd>-name record
— Function: <passwd>-name-set! record value
— Function: <passwd>-passwd record
— Function: <passwd>-passwd-set! record value
— Function: <passwd>-uid record
— Function: <passwd>-uid-set! record value
— Function: <passwd>-gid record
— Function: <passwd>-gid-set! record value
— Function: <passwd>-gecos record
— Function: <passwd>-gecos-set! record value
— Function: <passwd>-dir record
— Function: <passwd>-dir-set! record value
— Function: <passwd>-shell record
— Function: <passwd>-shell-set! record value

Accessors and mutators for records of type <passwd>.

— Function: primitive:pointer-><passwd> pointer

Build and return a new <passwd> record mirroring the struct passwd C language data structure referenced by pointer.

This binding is exported by the library (posix system primitives).

Previous: users typedefs passwd, Up: users typedefs

8.1.4 Groups informations

— Record Type Name: <group>
— Record Type Descriptor: <group-rtd>

Record type that mirrors struct passwd C language data structures. It has the following mutable fields:

name
A Scheme string representing the group name.
gid
A gid object representing the group identifier.
mem
A list of Scheme strings representing the name of the users registered in this group.

— Function: make-<group> name gid mem
— Function: <group>? obj

Constructor and predicate for records of type <group>.

— Function: <group>-name record
— Function: <group>-name-set record value
— Function: <group>-gid record
— Function: <group>-gid-set record value
— Function: <group>-mem record
— Function: <group>-mem-set record value

Accessors and mutators for records of type <group>.

— Function: primitive:pointer-><group> pointer

Build and return a new <group> record mirroring the struct group C language data structure referenced by pointer.

This binding is exported by the library (posix system primitives).

Next: users mutators, Previous: users typedefs, Up: users

8.2 Retrieving user and group identifiers

The following bindings manage acquisition of user and group identifiers. Reading the Persona of a Process.

— Function: getuid
— Parameter: getuid-function
— Function: primitive:getuid
— Function: platform:getuid

Return an uid object representing the real user identifier.

platform:getuid returns a single argument: the return value from the foreign function.

— Function: getgid
— Parameter: getgid-function
— Function: primitive:getgid
— Function: platform:getgid

Return a gid object representing the real group identifier.

platform:getgid returns a single argument: the return value from the foreign function.

— Function: geteuid
— Parameter: geteuid-function
— Function: primitive:geteuid
— Function: platform:geteuid

Return an uid object representing the effective user identifier.

platform:geteuid returns a single argument: the return value from the foreign function.

— Function: getegid
— Parameter: getegid-function
— Function: primitive:getegid
— Function: platform:getegid

Return a gid object representing the effective group identifier.

platform:getegid returns a single argument: the return value from the foreign function.

— Function: getgroups
— Parameter: getgroups-function
— Function: primitive:getgroups
— Function: platform:getgroups count group-array

Return a (possibly empty) list of gid objects representing the supplementary group identifiers of the process.

— Function: getgrouplist user-name gid
— Parameter: getgrouplist-function user-name gid
— Function: primitive:getgrouplist
— Function: platform:getgrouplist user-name-cstr gid-int

Return a (never empty) list of gid objects representing the supplementary group identifiers of groups to which the user with name user-name belongs to. gid is added to the list.

user-name must be a Scheme string or symbol.

Next: users login, Previous: users accessors, Up: users

8.3 Changing user and group identifiers

The following bindings manage setting user and group identifiers. Setting the User ID. Setting the Group IDs.

— Function: setuid uid
— Parameter: setuid-function
— Function: primitive:setuid uid
— Function: platform:setuid uid-int

Set both the real and effective user identifier to uid.

— Function: seteuid uid
— Parameter: seteuid-function
— Function: primitive:seteuid uid
— Function: platform:seteuid uid-int

Set the effective user identifier to uid.

— Function: setgid gid
— Parameter: setgid-function
— Function: primitive:setgid gid
— Function: platform:setgid gid-int

Set both the real and effective group identifier to gid.

— Function: setegid gid
— Parameter: setegid-function
— Function: primitive:setegid gid
— Function: platform:setegid gid-int

Set the effective group identifier to gid.

— Function: setgroups gid-list
— Parameter: setgroups-function
— Function: primitive:setgroups gid-list
— Function: platform:setgroups count group-array

Set the supplementary group identifiers of the process to the given list of identifiers.

— Function: initgroups user-name gid
— Parameter: initgroups-function
— Function: primitive:initgroups user-name gid
— Function: platform:initgroups user-name-cstr gid-int

Set the current supplementary groups to be the default for the user selected by user-name, which must be a Scheme string or symbol. The group identifier gid is automatically included.

Next: users userdb, Previous: users mutators, Up: users

8.4 Retrieving user login names

The following bindings manage retrieval of user's login name. Identifying Who Logged In.

— Function: getlogin
— Parameter: getlogin-function
— Function: primitive:getlogin
— Function: platform:getlogin

Return a Scheme string representing the name of the logged in user; this function is not reentrant.

platform:getlogin returns a single argument: the return value from the foreign function.

— Function: cuserid
— Parameter: cuserid-function
— Function: primitive:cuserid
— Function: platform:cuserid cstr

Return a Scheme string representing the name of the logged in user; this function is reentrant.

platform:cuserid returns a single argument: the return value from the foreign function.

Next: users groupdb, Previous: users login, Up: users

8.5 Users database

The following bindings manage access to the users database. Looking Up One User. Scanning the List of All Users.

— Function: getpwuid uid
— Parameter: getpwuid-function
— Function: primitive:getpwuid uid
— Function: platform:getpwuid uid-int
— Function: platform:getpwuid_r uid-int pwd-ptr buf-ptr buf-len result-ptr

Return a record of type <passwd> representing data about the user identified by uid. This function is reentrant.

— Function: getpwnam user-name
— Parameter: getpwnam-function
— Function: primitive:getpwnam user-name
— Function: platform:getpwnam name-cstr
— Function: platform:getpwnam_r name-cstr pwd-ptr buf-ptr buf-len result-ptr

Return a record of type <passwd> representing data about the user whose name is user-name, a Scheme string or symbol. This function is reentrant.

— Function: fgetpwent stream
— Parameter: fgetpwent
— Function: primitive:fgetpwent stream
— Function: platform:fgetpwent stream-ptr
— Function: platform:fgetpwent_r stream-ptr pwd-ptr buf-ptr buf-len result-ptr

Return a record of type <passwd> representing data about the next user from the database file referenced by stream, a FILE* object. When the iteration over the database ends, the return value is #f. This function is reentrant. 

          (let ((pwds (with-compensations
                        (letrec
                            ((file* (compensate
                                        (glibc:fopen "/etc/passwd" "r")
                                      (with
                                       (glibc:fclose file*)))))
                          (let loop ((pwds '()))
                            (let ((pwd (posix:fgetpwent file*)))
                              (if pwd
                                  (loop (cons pwd pwds))
                                pwds)))))))
            ---)

Previous: users userdb, Up: users

8.6 Groups database

The following bindings manage access to the groups database. Looking Up One Group. Scanning the List of All Groups.

— Function: getgrgid gid
— Parameter: getgrgid-function
— Function: primitive:getgrgid gid
— Function: platform:getgrgid gid-int
— Function: platform:getgrgid_r gid-int pwd-ptr buf-ptr buf-len result-ptr

Return a record of type <group> representing data about the group identified by gid. This function is reentrant.

— Function: getgrnam group-name
— Parameter: getgrnam-function
— Function: primitive:getgrnam group-name
— Function: platform:getgrnam name-cstr
— Function: platform:getgrnam_r name-cstr pwd-ptr buf-ptr buf-len result-ptr

Return a record of type <group> representing data about the group whose name is group-name, a Scheme string or symbol. This function is reentrant.

— Function: fgetgrent stream
— Parameter: fgetgrent
— Function: primitive:fgetgrent stream
— Function: platform:fgetgrent stream-ptr
— Function: platform:fgetgrent_r stream-ptr pwd-ptr buf-ptr buf-len result-ptr

Return a record of type <group> representing data about the next group from the database file referenced by stream, a FILE* object. When the iteration over the database ends, the return value is #f. This function is reentrant.

Next: strings, Previous: users, Up: Top

9 Interprocess signals

Unless otherwise specified, the functions documented in this chapter are exported by the following libraries: 

     (posix signal)
     (posix signal primitive)
     (posix signal platform)

it is explicitly stated when the functions are exported by the following libraries: 

     (glibc signal)
     (glibc signal primitive)
     (glibc signal platform)
  • signals constants: Constant values.
  • signals enumerations: Enumeration definitions.
  • signals messages: Signal descriptions.
  • signals bub: Block/unblock signals handling.
  • signals sending: Sending signals.
  • signals waiting: Waiting for signals.

Next: signals enumerations, Up: signals

9.1 Constant values

The following bindings are exported by the (posix sizeof) library. We have to remember that some of the signals listed below are not defined on some platforms, in this case the binding is to #f. Standard Signals.

— Constant: NSIG

Maximum number of defined signal constants.

— Constant: SIGFPE
— Constant: SIGILL
— Constant: SIGSEGV
— Constant: SIGBUS
— Constant: SIGABRT
— Constant: SIGIOT
— Constant: SIGTRAP
— Constant: SIGEMT
— Constant: SIGSYS

Program error signals.

— Constant: SIGTERM
— Constant: SIGINT
— Constant: SIGQUIT
— Constant: SIGKILL
— Constant: SIGHUP

Termination signals.

— Constant: SIGALRM
— Constant: SIGVRALRM
— Constant: SIGPROF

Alarm signals.

— Constant: SIGIO
— Constant: SIGURG
— Constant: SIGPOLL

Asynchronous input/output signals.

— Constant: SIGCHLD
— Constant: SIGCLD
— Constant: SIGCONT
— Constant: SIGSTOP
— Constant: SIGTSTP
— Constant: SIGTTIN
— Constant: SIGTTOU

Job control signals.

— Constant: SIGPIPE
— Constant: SIGLOST
— Constant: SIGXCPU
— Constant: SIGXSFZ

Operation error signals.

— Constant: SIGUSR1
— Constant: SIGUSR2
— Constant: SIGWINCH
— Constant: SIGINFO

Miscellaneous signals.

Next: signals messages, Previous: signals constants, Up: signals

9.2 Enumeration definitions

The following bindings are exported by the (posix typedefs) library. Standard Signals.

— Enumeration Type: enum-unix-signals

Enumeration type for the Scheme symbols of the known interprocess signals. All the symbols which appear as bindings in Constant values are part of this enumeration.

— Syntax: unix-signals <symbol> ...

Expand to an enumeration set of type enum-unix-signal with the <symbol> arguments as elements.

— Syntax: unix-signal <symbol>

Expand to an enumeration set of type enum-unix-signal with the single <symbol> argument as element.

— Function: unix-signal->value sig-set
— Function: value->unix-signal signum

Convert to and from a signal number and its corresponding enumeration set of type enum-unix-signals.

— Function: unix-signal-symbol->value symbol
— Function: value->unix-signal-symbol signum

Convert to and from a signal number and its corresponding Scheme symbol.

Next: signals bub, Previous: signals enumerations, Up: signals

9.3 Signal descriptions

The following bindings are exported by the Glibc signals libraries. Signal Messages.

— Function: strsignal signum
— Function: primitive:strsignal signum
— Function: platform:strsignal signum

Return a Scheme string representing a description of the signal signum.

— Function: psignal signum message-prefix
— Function: primitive:psignal signum message-prefix
— Function: platform:psignal signum message-prefix-cstr

Print a Scheme string representing a description of the signal signum to stderr.

Next: signals sending, Previous: signals messages, Up: signals

9.4 Block/unblock signals handling

The BUB API is a simplified interface to detect the arrival of interprocess signals; if it does not suit the application's model, we should just ignore it. It is impossible to use the BUB API along with other interprocess signal APIs. Here is a meaningless usage example: 

     (with-compensations
       (compensate
           (signal-bub-init)
         (with
          (signal-bub-final)))
       (signal-raise SIGUSR1)
       (signal-bub-acquire)
       (list (signal-bub-delivered? SIGUSR1)
             (signal-bub-delivered? SIGUSR2)))
     ⇒ (#t #f)
— Function: signal-bub-init
— Function: primitive:signal-bub-init

Block all the signals and initialise the BUB interface.

— Function: signal-bub-final
— Function: primitive:signal-bub-final

Set all the signal handlers to SIG_IGN, then unblock all the signals and finalise the BUB interface.

— Function: signal-bub-acquire
— Function: primitive:signal-bub-acquire

Unblock all the signals, then block them again. This should allow all the pending signals to be delivered to the process.

— Function: signal-bub-delivered? signum
— Function: primitive:signal-bub-delivered? signum

Return #t if the signal signum has been delivered at least once before the last call to signal-bub-acquire. Calling this function with signum clears the internal flag for this signal, so calling it again without acquiring new signals always returns #f.

This function interferes with signal-bub-all-delivered.

— Syntax: signal-bub-delivered*? <sig-set>
— Syntax: primitive:signal-bub-delivered*? <sig-set>

Wrapper for signal-bub-delivered? accepting as argument an enumeration set of type enum-unix-signals holding a single argument.

— Function: signal-bub-all-delivered
— Function: primitive:signal-bub-all-delivered

Return an enumeration set of type enum-unix-signals representing the signals delivered before the last call to signal-bub-acquire. Calling this function clears the internal flags for all the signals, so calling it again without acquiring new signals always returns the empty enumeration set.

This function interferes with signal-bub-delivered?.

Next: signals waiting, Previous: signals bub, Up: signals

9.5 Sending signals

The following functions manage sending interprocess signals. Generating Signals.

— Function: signal-raise signum
— Parameter: signal-raise-function
— Function: primitive:signal-raise signum
— Function: platform:signal_raise signum

Send the signal signum to this process.

This is a wrapper for the raise() foreign function. signal_raise returns a single value: the return value from the foreign function.

— Syntax: signal-raise* <sig-set>
— Syntax: primitive:signal-raise* <sig-set>

Wrapper for signal-raise accepting as argument an enumeration set of type enum-unix-signals holding a single argument.

— Function: kill pid signum
— Parameter: kill-function
— Function: primitive:kill pid signum
— Function: platform:kill pid-int signum

Send the signal signum to the process or process groups identified by pid, a pid object.

— Syntax: kill* <pid> <sig-set>
— Syntax: primitive:kill* <pid> <sig-set>

Wrapper for kill accepting as argument an enumeration set of type enum-unix-signals holding a single argument.

— Function: killpg pid signum
— Parameter: killpg-function
— Function: primitive:killpg pid signum
— Function: platform:killpg pid-int signum

Send the signal signum to the process group identified by pid, a pid object.

— Syntax: killpg* <pid> <sig-set>
— Syntax: primitive:killpg* <pid> <sig-set>

Wrapper for killpg accepting as argument an enumeration set of type enum-unix-signals holding a single argument.

Previous: signals sending, Up: signals

9.6 Waiting for signals

The following functions manage waiting for the arrival or an interprocess signal. Using pause().

— Function: pause
— Parameter: pause-function
— Function: primitive:pause
— Function: platform:pause

Block the process and wait until the next signal arrives.

Next: system, Previous: signals, Up: Top

10 More C string functions

The library (glibc cstrings platform) exports bindings to callouts for all the string functions exported by the GNU C Library. String and Array Utilities.

NOTE If we find a string function not interfaced by (glibc cstrings platform), we can report it as a bug.

The purpose of this API is to allow some string processing without conversion from C strings to Scheme strings. When importing this library we better prefix its identifiers to avoid collisions; example: 

     (import (rnrs)
       (foreign cstrings)
       (prefix (posix cstrings platform) cstr:))

We have to remember that characters of type char and wchar_t must be handed as integers to the callouts. Also, all the callouts return a single value: the return value of the foreign functions.

Next: Package License, Previous: strings, Up: Top

11 System resources and configuration

Unless otherwise specified, the functions documented in this chapter are exported by the following libraries: 

     (posix system)
     (posix system primitives)
     (posix system platform)
  • system typedefs: Types definition.
  • system constants: Constant values.
  • system environment: Environment variables.
  • system inspection: Inspecting configuration.
  • system host: Host identification.
  • system uname: Platform identification.
  • system mount fstab: Inspecting mountable file systems.
  • system mount mtab: Inspecting mounted file systems.
  • system mount: Mounting file systems.

Next: system constants, Up: system

11.1 Types definition

The bindings documented in this section are exported by the (posix typedefs) library.

  • system typedefs utsname: Platform type informations.
  • system typedefs fstab: Mountable file systems informations.
  • system typedefs mntent: Mounted file systems informations.

Next: system typedefs fstab, Up: system typedefs

11.1.1 Platform type informations

— Record Type Name: <utsname>
— Record Type Descriptor: <utsname-rtd>

Record type used to mirror C language structures of type struct utsname. It has the following mutable fields:

sysname
A Scheme string representing the operating system name.
release
A Scheme string representing the operating system release.
version
A Scheme string representing the operating system version.
machine
A Scheme string representing the hardware.

— Function: make-<utsname> sysname release version machine
— Function: <utsname>? obj

Constructor and predicate for records of type <utsname>.

— Function: <utsname>-sysname record
— Function: <utsname>-sysname-set! record value
— Function: <utsname>-release record
— Function: <utsname>-release-set! record value
— Function: <utsname>-version record
— Function: <utsname>-version-set! record value
— Function: <utsname>-machine record
— Function: <utsname>-machine-set! record value

Accessors and mutators for records of type <utsname>.

— Function: primitive:pointer-><utsname> pointer

Build and return a new record of type <utsname> initialised with data from the C structure of type struct utsname referenced by pointer.

This binding is exported by the library (posix system primitives).

Next: system typedefs mntent, Previous: system typedefs utsname, Up: system typedefs

11.1.2 Mountable file systems informations

— Record Type Name: <fstab>
— Record Type Descriptor: <fstab-rtd>

Record type used to mirror C language structures of type struct fstab. It has the following mutable fields:

spec
A Scheme string representing the device from which the file system is mounted.
file
A Scheme string representing the mount point.
vfstype
A Scheme string representing the type of file system.
mntops
A Scheme string representing the options handed to the kernel when mounting.
type
A Scheme string representing the modes with which the file system is mounted.
freq
An exact integer representing the dump frequency in days.
passno
An exact integer representing the pass number on parallel dumps.

— Function: make-<fstab> spec file vfstype mntops type freq passno
— Function: <fstab>? obj

Constructor and predicate for records of type <fstab>.

— Function: <fstab>-spec record
— Function: <fstab>-spec-set! record value
— Function: <fstab>-file record
— Function: <fstab>-file-set! record value
— Function: <fstab>-vfstype record
— Function: <fstab>-vfstype-set! record value
— Function: <fstab>-mntops record
— Function: <fstab>-mntops-set! record value
— Function: <fstab>-type record
— Function: <fstab>-type-set! record value
— Function: <fstab>-type record
— Function: <fstab>-type-set! record value
— Function: <fstab>-freq record
— Function: <fstab>-freq-set! record value
— Function: <fstab>-passno record
— Function: <fstab>-passno-set! record value

Accessors and mutators for records of type <fstab>.

— Function: primitive:pointer-><fstab> pointer

Build and return a new record of type <fstab> initialised with data from the C structure of type struct fstab referenced by pointer.

This binding is exported by the library (posix system primitives).

Previous: system typedefs fstab, Up: system typedefs

11.1.3 Mounted file systems informations

— Record Type Name: <mntent>
— Record Type Descriptor: <mntent-rtd>

Record type used to mirror C language structures of type struct mntent. It has the following mutable fields:

fsname
A Scheme string representing the device from which the file system is mounted.
dir
A Scheme string representing the mount point.
type
A Scheme string representing the file system type.
opts
A Scheme string representing the mount options.
freq
An exact integer representing the dump frequency in days.
passno
An exact integer representing the pass number on parallel dumps.

— Function: make-<mntent> fsname dir type opts freq passno
— Function: <mntent>? obj

Constructor and predicate for records of type <mntent>.

— Function: <mntent>-fsname record
— Function: <mntent>-fsname-set! record value
— Function: <mntent>-dir record
— Function: <mntent>-dir-set! record value
— Function: <mntent>-type record
— Function: <mntent>-type-set! record value
— Function: <mntent>-opts record
— Function: <mntent>-opts-set! record value
— Function: <mntent>-freq record
— Function: <mntent>-freq-set! record value
— Function: <mntent>-passno record
— Function: <mntent>-passno-set! record value

Accessors and mutators for records of type <mntent>.

— Function: primitive:pointer-><mntent> pointer

Build and return a new record of type <mntent> initialised with data from the C structure of type struct mntent referenced by pointer.

This binding is exported by the library (posix system primitives).

— Function: primitive:<mntent>->pointer mntent malloc

Allocate a new struct mntent C language data structure initialised with values from mntent, which must be a record of type <mntent>.

All the needed memory is allocated with the function malloc, which must have the same protocol of malloc from (memory). Exception raising functions.

This binding is exported by the library (posix system primitives).

Next: system environment, Previous: system typedefs, Up: system

  • system constants inspection: Constant for system inspection.
